title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 3.XPublished on 2025-03-17CompareSDK (Core) for C# [3.7.0] - 2026-01-16 Added Administration service: SetExternalPresenceAsync(), GetExternalPresenceAsync() and Remov
content: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 3.XPublished on 2025-03-17CompareSDK (Core) for C# [3.7.0] - 2026-01-16 Added Administration service: SetExternalPresenceAsync(), GetExternalPresenceAsync() and RemoveExternalPresenceAsync() methods to manage "external presence" Application service: Add optional parameter logoutUrl in LoginWithTokenAsync(), LoginWithTokenWithoutEventPipeAsync(), LoginWithTokenAsync() and LoginWithTokenWithoutEventPipeAsync() methods UserCredentials object: add LogoutUrl and ApplicationToken properties Bubbles service: AutoClearBubbleContentAsync(), ClearBubbleContentAsync() methods ConferenceDetails object: ContentToAutoClear property BubbleAffiliation object: Reason property - possible values: "deactivated", "resumed" or empty Contacts service: CustomStatusUpdated event, CreateCustomStatus(), UpdateCustomStatusAsync(), DeleteCustomStatusAsync() and GetCustomStatusesAsync() methods to manage custom statuses FileStorage service: AddViewerAsync(), RemoveViewerAsync() and GetFileDescriptorSync() methods InstantMessaging service: ForwardMessageAsync() method: add optional parameter anonymously (True by default) Message object: add ForwardedFromContact property Peer object: IsChannel(), IsChannelWithId(), IsChannelWithJid(), IsChannelWithIdAndJid(), static methods IsEntity(), IsEntityWithId(), IsEntityWithJid(), IsEntityWithIdAndJid(), static methods Fixed Application service: if used, ensure to check Turn Servers configuration based on theirs TTL Bubble service: join automatically a bubble which is no more inactive avoid to trigger several times same BubbbleAffiliationChanged event Conferences service: Before to start a conference, ensure to set as active the associated bubble if necessary Contacts service: about presence correctly manage away versus away inactive states FileStorage service: avoid to trigger several times same FileStorageUpdated event InstantMessaging service: Store message in cache only if StorageMode is set to Store Avoid to store message sent with <CDATA> section Mark automatically message as read (if specified) only if StorageMode is Store or NoPermanentStore When forwarding a message with a file, ensure to set the receiver as viewer of this file Before to send a message to a bubble, ensure to set it as active if necessary Removed ConferenceDetails object: Breaking Scheduled, ScheduledStartDate , ScheduledEndDate , ScheduledDuration , MediaType , LastUpdateDate, Sessions properties Breaking ConferenceSession object:: [3.6.0] - 2025-11-20 Info New RPC service (Remote Procedure Call) As client permits to request RPC method of a Peer and get the result As server permits to add / remove new RPC method: possibility to restrict access according RPC method and / or Peer It's possible to be client and server in same time Interaction between CPaaS Rainbow client (Web Client, Desktop Client) and SDK CPaaS client offers default RPC Methods (make call for example) which can be requested from SDK CPaaS client can request SDK RPC Methods using custom manifest file Guest updates: Can no more be created using CreateGuestUserAsync() and CreateAnonymousGuestUserAsync() in Administration service Contacts with GuestMode still exist which are created using Bubble Link: see CreateUserWithBubbleLinkAsync() in Administration service Fixed Jingle service: add more tests when sendinq Iq (to avoid use of null value for jid or resource) Added Added .Net 10.0 as target framework Alerts service: RemoveDevicesTagsAsync(), RenameDevicesTagsAsync() and GetDevicesTagsStatisticsAsync() methods AlertFilter object with new field IpAddresses AlertDevicesTagCount, AlertDevicesTagsStatistics, AlertFilterIpAddresses and AlertFilterIpAddresseRange objects Contacts service: IsCompanyAdminAsync() and IsCompanyAdminSync() methods FileStorage service: CreateArchiveAsync() method QuotaConsumption object: add Recordings and Others properties InstantMessaging service: PrivateMessageReceived event SendPrivateMessageAsync(), AnswerToPrivateMessageAsync() methods Message object with new field PrivateMessage JSONNode object: Escape() method Peer object: IsContactWithIdAndJid(), IsBubbleWithIdAndJid() methods Restrictions object: UseRPC property (false by default) RPC service: CallMethodAsync(), ListMethodsAsync(), GetMethodHelpAsync(), GetMethodSignaturesAsync(), RestRequestAsync() methods (for RPC client) AddMethod(), RemoveMethod(), DefineDelegateToAllowRPCRequests(), AllowAllRPCRequests() methods and AllowRestRequestAsRpcMethod property (for RPC server) Base64, RPCRestRequest, RPCRestResponse objects SdkInternalErrorEnum enum: XMPP_IQ_ERROR, XMPP_IQ_TIMEOUT: to provide more error details in IQ context RPC_PARSING_ERROR_METHODCALL_NODE, RPC_PARSING_ERROR_VALUE_NODE_TO_OBJECT, RPC_PARSING_ERROR_OBJECT_TO_VALUE_NODE, RPC_NO_METHOD_FOUND, RPC_NO_METHOD_FOUND_WITH_CORRECT_SIGNATURE, title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationData in cacheLTS release 3.XPublished on 2025-03-17Data storage and connection / reconnection Prerequisite You must first know how to connect and manage auto-reconnection service using th
content: DocumentationData in cacheLTS release 3.XPublished on 2025-03-17Data storage and connection / reconnection Prerequisite You must first know how to connect and manage auto-reconnection service using the SDK: Connect to Rainbow. Auto Reconnection. Introduction The SDK cannot retrieve all data "at once" once connected to the server. In addition, this connection can be interrupted and the data must be synchronized again. This guide aims: To list what data is stored To understand when they are available they depend on the user's license they depend on the options used in the SDK To understand the connection and reconnection problem to synchronize this data The last chapter, via code example, shows how to handle all of this. Connection / Reconnection (REST and Event Pipe) The SDK is connected to the Rainbow server using two different channels: REST API (HTTP requests): asynchonous connection based on secutiry token with a "time to live" XMPP (or eventually S2S) event pipe: web socket connection which needs permanent connection. From a global point of view, REST API is used for static data and event pipe for dynamic data (presence, instant messaging, ...) To be fully operational, the SDK must create a valid link on both channels (authenticated, connected) and have enough data/information (license, settings, ...) after connection or a reconnection. As developper, you only know if the SDK is connected or not using event ConnectionStateChanged event in Application service but you cannot know which one specificalyy is connected/disconnected. To give more details, event pipe disconnection occurs more often. For example, if there is a network trouble for a short period, the event pipe will be disconnected but not the REST API channel. And usually, if the REST API channel is disconnected, the event pipe is also disconnected. Bubbles and how they are managed To receive or send messages or to get dynamic information about a Bubble (for example that there is a conference in progress), the SDK must first join it. It also called a bubble affiliation. The SDK can do it: only when the event pipe connection is operational and join Bubbles one by one. So, the more bubbles you have, the longer it takes to join them all. Contacts presence To know the Aggregated Presence (also called Unified Ptesence) of one contact, the SDK must first receive information of each of his devices: One for each client used: Rainbow Web client, Rainbow Mobile Phone (Adnroid and/or iOS, ...) Optionnaly, one to manage his telephony device (Rainbow Hub or OXO/OXE) Optionnaly, one to manage his calendar presence (Google Calendar, Office 365, ...) Optionnaly, one to manage his Team presence (Google Calendar, Office 365, ...) Now multiply all these by the number of contats in the roster, and you can see that there is a lot of Presence messages to handle. And this messages are received only when the event pipe is connected. Further more, presence Telephony data To ensure to have accurate information, Telephony settings are obtained using the the event pipe. So we must be first connected to it. Once connected, the SDK waits to receive for the telephony system its status before to ask more information. SDK Events The SDK provides a way to know: when the user is well or badly authenticated: AuthenticationFailed or AuthenticationSucceeded events in Application service are raised when the user is connected/authenticated on both channels AND when enough data are retrieved/refreshed, ConnectionStateChanged event in Application service is raised with a state equals to ConnectionState.Connected Each time a Bubble has been joined, BubbleAffiliationChanged event in Bubbles service is raised. when all Bubbles have been joined (and even if current user has no bubble), BubbleAffiliationsPerformed event in Bubbles service is raised. Note: You can start to use the SDK after the step 2 (before it's now allowed). It you need to use a Bubble, ensure to have received event BubbleAffiliationChanged for this Bubble or wait for event BubbleAffiliationsPerformed The delay between step 2 and step 4 is direclty dependent of the number of active bubbles. After step 2, other data are retrieved, see the list in a next chapter for full details. If at least one channel is disconnected, ConnectionStateChanged event in Application service is raised with a state equals to ConnectionState.Disconnected. To resume: If you don't have to manage a lot of Bubbles, using event ConnectionStateChanged is enough. If you have to manage a lot of of Bubbles, uses event BubbleAffiliationsPerformed to ensure that the SDK has already joined all of them. If you have to manage a lot of of Bubbles but the connection/reconnection delay is very critical for you, uses event BubbleAffiliationChanged to check which Bubbles have been already joined before to use them. You can also use the method IsBubbleAffiliated About Presence, you have in Contacts service 2 events to use if you want to manage them: ContactPresenceCh

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: Rainbow SDK for CSharp environmentConnect your desktop application to RainbowEverything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp.Ready to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp ?Everything
content: Rainbow SDK for CSharp environmentConnect your desktop application to RainbowEverything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp.Ready to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp ?Everything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp.First steps with CSharp SDKDownload CSharp SDKCheck CSharp code samplesUseful informationVersion: LTS 3.XPublished: 17 mars 2025Last Updated: 16 janv. 2026Consult the changelogToggle to STS documentationSDK packaged for CSharp environmentThe Rainbow SDK for CSharp is delivered as a Nuget package that can be deployed easily and used in CSharp environment. It's an Assembly available in .Net Standard 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 8.0..NET Core 2.0+.NET Framework 4.6.1+Unity 2018.1+Mono 5.4+Xamarin.iOS 10.14+Xamarin.Android 8.0+Universal Windows Platform 10.0.16299+Once done, your application will be connected to Rainbow and able to use every available Rainbow service.A fully documented CSharp SDKThe Rainbow SDK for CSharp provides you the best API for connecting to Rainbow and integrating with your application. These SDK have been carefully developed and are well-documented with the necessary details to help you build your application.SDK for CSharp at a glance.Learn about the main APIs provided by this SDKAssembly in .NETProvides an highly efficient library for environments .Net Standard 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 8.0Contacts, search and presence APIHandle your contact list and know when they are available, busy on the phone or away. Search for users by name or id to extend your network.One-to-one Chat APIExchange messages with your contacts. Be alerted when contacts send you a message. You can retrieve the whole conversation or only the most recent messages.Bubbles groupchat APICreate and invite users, or reuse your bubbles for talking together. In a bubble, everyone can participate to the conversation.WebRTC audio and video APIYou can initiate audio and video calls to your contacts using your browser without a plug-in. Enhance your call from audio only to video. Choose which device you want to use and control the call (mute/unmute).WebRTC Conference APIYou can join a conference in a bubble. Control the video you want to see and control your device (mute/unmute).Call logs APIRetrieve the history of all calls made from your PBX phone or from you Rainbow application. Be notified in real time of new log.PSTN telephony APIYou can initiate or anwer any call with your PBX phone. The API covers all basic telephony features such as putting a call on hold and retrieving it, diverting a call to voice mail, making a conference call with multiple participants and more.Groups APIGroup your contacts by activity, other... . Make some groups become your favorites groups.Files sharing APIShare files with a user in a one-to-one chat or within a bubble with several participants. You're also able to download files shared by others in your bubble.Channels APISend messages to channels which may have more than thousands suscribers. Subscribe to users public channels to follow them and receive what they publish!Always onOnce started, the SDK is always connected to Rainbow and so can handle requests endlessly.Proxy traversalThe SDK can be used through a HTTP or HTTPS proxy, with or without authentication.ServiceabilityFull and flexible logging capability allowing easy debugging.Interesting linksLearn how to use our SDKsNeed some help?Contact our support teamVisit our homepageFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Medias. This SDK can be used as a standalone package witho
content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Medias. This SDK can be used as a standalone package without the need of Rainbow Account, Rainbow Server or Rainbow Infrastructure. This SDK can be used on these platforms: Windows, MacOs, and Linux. Only x64 platforms are supported. Android and iOS are NOT YET supported. Features It permits to manage Audio and Video streams using: Local / Remote Files IP TV, Live Stream Server Devices like Webcam, Screen/Monitor, Microphone, Speaker, Headset, ... To access remote streams all this protocols are supported. An Audio and/or Video Stream (whatever its source) is calles a Media in this SDK. A Media can be composed of one Audio stream and/or one Video stream. Using a Media it's then possible, for example, to create a Media Player: Start, Stop, Pause, Resume, Seek actions are possible. Using one Media or severals, it's then possible to create a MediaFiltered using a Video filter and/or an Audio filter. Video Filter allows to: scale, crop, pad, resize, change fps, add subtitles create mosaic, overlay, dynamic mask Audio filter is not yet supported. The MediaFiltered will use the Audio stream of the specified Media. On the fly you can change the filter. The Audio/Video stream of the MediaFiltered will be updated in consequence without the need to re-start all Media used. Filter - List, Syntax and Examples Filter - List The list of available Audio filters are available here The list of available Video filters are available here Filter - Syntax Same syntax used in FFmpeg can be used in this package. The best thing to do it's to test first your filter using ffmpeg with a command line using "-vf" parameter (to set video filter). The same value can be used as filter in this SDK. Filter - Examples Here some examples than can be used. Using only one Media To have video in gray: format=gray To blur the video: avgblur=10 To scale the video: scale=400:-2 To crop the video: crop=400:400 To draw a text on the video: drawtext=text=%{localtime\: %X }:fontcolor=white:fontsize=40:y=(main_h-text_h)/2:x=(main_w-text_w)/2 To add subtitles on the video using subtitles from the file "c:\media\TOEFLTest.mp4" subtitles=f=c\\:\\\\medias\\\\TOEFLTest.mp4:si=0 Several options can set in same time, for example, to scale then pad the video: scale=200:-2,pad=320:200:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2 Here, we blur a zone of a video and add also subtitles: [0:v]crop=400:400,avgblur=10[fg];[0:v][fg]overlay=(main_w-overlay_w)/2:(main_h-overlay_h)/2[blured];[blured]subtitles=f=c\\:\\\\media\\\\TOEFLTest.mp4:si=0 Using two Medias To display two videos streams in one stream. Each video stream is first scaled and padde to a 320x240 stream. Then they are displayed vertically. [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-2,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-2,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [a0][a1]xstack=inputs=2:layout=0_0|0_h0[out] The first video stream is scaled then overlay on the second one: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=250:-2[a2]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a1]; [a1][a2]overlay=x=W-w:y=0 The first video stream is scaled then using a circle and a mask we ouse it as overlay on the second one: [0]scale=250:-1,geq='st(3,pow(X-(W/2),2)+pow(Y-(H/2),2))\;if(lte(ld(3),pow(min(W/2,H/2),2)),255,0):128:128'[scaledMask]; [0]scale=250:-1[scaled]; [scaled][scaledMask]alphamerge[cutout]; [cutout]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a2]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a1]; [a1][a2]overlay=x=W-w:y=0 Using more than two Medias Four Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then they are used to create a grid of 2x2: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [2]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a2]; [3]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a3]; [a0][a1][a2][a3]xstack=inputs=4:grid=2x2 Six Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then theyr used to create a grid of 2x3: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [2]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a2]; [3]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a3]; [4]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a4]; [5]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a5]; [a0][a1][a2][a3][a4][a5]xstack=inputs=6:grid=2x3 Nine Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then theyr used to create a grid of 3x3: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240

content: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01CompareSDK.Medias for C# [1.8.0] - 2026-01-16 Changed Update code to remove compilation warnings [1.7.0] - 2025-11-20 Fixed MediaEncoder object CreateMediaVideoEncoder() method: No more use GlobalQuality but GopSize to manage key frame MediaInput, MediaRtpInput, MediaFiltered objects exception could occurred when end of input file is reached Added Added .Net 10.0 as target framework Changed MediaInput, MediaRtpInput, MediaFiltered objects standardizes RaiseOnVideoSample() methods [1.6.0] - 2025-09-01 Fixed MediaFilterd, MediaInput, MediaRtpInput objects: Add more check when frame is converted / encoded Use global lock to avoid crash when objects are released MediaRtpInput object: ensure to read all frames from packet [1.5.0] - 2025-07-07 Added MediaRtpInput object: Add new optional parameters in constructor to allow to set ffmpeg options Default options are now: "reorder_queue_size" set to 32 (from 2048) add "fflags" and set it to "+discardcorrupt+genpts+nofillin+nobuffer" Changed Update Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions dependency package to v9.0.0 (from v8.0.0) [1.4.0] - 2025-04-23 Fixed Noisy sound when using Microphone as audio input stream Changed MediaInput service: in FromScreenDevice() and FromWebcamDevice() methods add loggerPrefix as optional parameter Update Concentus dependency package to v2.2.2 (from v1.1.6) [1.3.0] - 2025-03-12 Fixed Devices service: when plugged/unplugged, store new devices list (screens, webcams, audio inputs and/or audio outputs) before to trigger device added / removed events. So it's possible to know this list when the event is received MediaInput service: change how 'live stream' are managed MediaRtpInput service: fix noisy incoming sound Added MediaInput service: FromScreenDevice(), FromWebcamDevice() methods Helper: InitExternalLibraries() method now allows to initialize video features of SDL2 library SDL2Helper: GetPixelFormat() to get SDL2 pixel format from ffmpeg pixel format SDL2AudioOutput: ClearQueue() SDL2 namespace: it's know totally public. Allow to access to all SDL2 features [1.2.0] - 2024-11-22 Added Devices service: OnWebcamDeviceAdded, OnWebcamDeviceRemoved, OnScreenDeviceAdded, OnScreenDeviceRemoved, OnAudioInputDeviceRemoved, OnAudioInputDeviceAdded, OnAudioOutputDeviceRemoved, OnAudioOutputDeviceAdded events IMedia interface: Device property Changed Breaking IMedia interface: rename Stop() to StopAsync(), Pause() to PauseAsync(), SetVideoBitRate() to SetMaxVideoBitRate() Breaking IMedia interface: remove Context() property Breaking SDL2AudioInput object: needs now a Device in the constructor Breaking SDL2AudioOutput object: needs now a Device in the constructor [1.1.0] - 2024-10-01 Fixed Improve the way to get/calculate Fps. (avoid NaN results) Changed IMediaVideoBase interface: add VideoStreamPixelFormat, VideoStreamTimeBase and VideoStreamSampleAspectRatio properties. MediaFiltered, MediaInput and MediaRtpInput are updated in consequence. MediaFiltered object: add a constructor allowing to use IMediaVideo and/or IMediaAudio MediaFiltered object: add AddMediaVideoInput() and AddMediaAudioInput() [1.0.0] - 2024-07-01 Fixed Improve the way to get/calculate Fps. Avoid to use several streams when grabbing remote videos (for CCTV for example) Changed Use FFmpeg.AutoGen package v7.0.0 (from v6.0.0.2) Use FFmpeg v7.0.1 shared libraries (from v6.0) .Net 6.0 as target plateform has been removed (obsolete). .Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 8.0 are still in targets platform. [0.0.9-STS] - 2024-03-19 Fixed Allow to stream as video a JPG file (already possible with BMP, TIFF, PNG, WEBP (with one image), ...). GIF are also supported but not WEBP with animation due to FFmpeg limitation Changed Use Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions v8.0.0.0 (from v7.0.0.0) [0.0.8-STS] - 2024-01-15 Added Add .Net 8.0 as target plateform (.Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still in targets platform) .Net 6.0 target platform will be removed in April. [0.0.7-STS] - 2023-10-18 Added MediaInput: allow to set widht, height, fps and bit rate used in encoding process. Take into account options set in the device InputStreamDevice: Allow to set options [0.0.6-STS] - 2023-09-05 Added Add SetVideoBitRate() in MediaInput, MediaRtpInput and MediaFiltered Changed Use FFmpeg.AutoGen v6.0.0.2. Use FFmpeg v6.0 libraries. Enhancement in parser used to set filters [0.0.5] - STS - 2023-07-07 .Net Core App 3.1 is no more targetted (already deprecated by Microsoft). .Net Standardd 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still targetted [0.0.4] - STS - 2023-05-26 Fix MediaRTPInput: Some internal values was not resetted correctly MediaFiltered: When a new filter is set, it's necessary to dispose ALL previous objects to ensure to build correct frames [0.0.3] - STS - 2023-02-10 Enhancements It's now possible to decode RTP packets (Audio and/or Video) using MediaRtpInput object. A valid SDP must be provided which describes codecs to use to decode them. It

content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 2.XPublished on 2025-03-17Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC.Abstractions This SDK provides provides common interfaces and objects to implement/use to be compatible with WebRTC features provided by the Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC library. It cannot be used directly except if you want to create a new implementation to support WebRTC features in another environment. Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here This package targets .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1 and .Net 8.0 Implementations available: For the moment, there 2 differents implementations available: Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Desktop library compatible with Windows, MacOs, and Linux Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Unity library (for the moment used in private usage only) On this pageNuget packageImplementations available:Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 2.XPublished on 2025-03-17Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC.Desktop This SDK provides additional services / tools for these platforms: Windows, MacOs, and Linux. Only x64 platform is supported. It uses as dependencies Rainbow.CSharp.SDK, Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.Medias and Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Abstractions libraries. Te be more precise this library is a specific implementation of Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Abstractions which target Desktop platforms (as opposed to mobile platforms like Android or iOS). Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here This package targets .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1 and .Net 8.0 WebRTC features Since this library is a implementation of Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Abstractions, it provides same features than the ones described in Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC library. So please refer to the documentation of this library Third-Party Libraries This implementation is using Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.Medias library. So please refer also to the documentation of this library to know how to use it to manage medias and alos to know which third party libraires must be installed. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 2.XPublished on 2025-03-17Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC ! This SDK provides additional services / features
content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 2.XPublished on 2025-03-17Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC ! This SDK provides additional services / features to the Rainbow CSharp SDK (core) library. So you need first to understand how to use it. Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here This package targets .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1 and .Net 8.0 WebRTC features Permits to manage WebRTC communications: Peer To Peer or in a Conference using Rainbow environment (https://developers.openrainbow.com/home) Peer To Peer communication features: Answer, Decline, Make, Retract, Hang up call Add / Remove Video or Sharing Mute / Unmute Audio, Video or Sharing Call status: Ringing incoming, ringing outgoing, in progress, ... Audio Stream: Output and Input are supported Video Stream: Output is supported. Input is not supported (work still in progress) Conference features: Start, Join Conference Participants list Publishers list Mute / Unmute: current user but also other Peers if current user is a moderator of the conference Call status: Ringing incoming, ringing outgoing, in progress, ... Display Active Talker. Current user of this SDK is never seen as Active Talker (work still in progress) Add / Remove Video or Sharing Subscribe (automatically or manualy) to publication of Peers (Video or Sharing) Request / Refuse / Accept Sharing transfert Conference delegation Audio Stream: Output and Input are supported Video Stream: Ouput is supported. Input is not supported (work still in progress) Abstractions and Implementations This package use abstractions to offer those WebRTC features based on specific implementations. For the moment, two implementations are available: Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC.Desktop Third library used: SIPSorcery, FFmpeg libraries and SDL2 Comptatible Windows, MacOs and Linux platforms Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC.Unity Available only in private access for the moment Third library used: Unity and WebRTC for Unity Comptatible with Windows, MacOs and Linux, Android, iOS platforms Developping with the Rainbow.WebRTC SDK Quick overview on how to use the Rainbow.WebRTC sdk to develop a webrtc enabled application. It is intended to be about general principles and is not specific to the implementation. For specific, check documentation of he implementation you want to use. Instantiation Create a Rainbow.Application object Rainbow Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); Configure application credentials and platform Enable restrictions on Conferences Monitor ConnectionStateChanged and InitializationPerformed Call Login() The SDK will try to connect to the platform using the supplied (application and user) credentials. If it failed you are informed in the optional callback. When it's done initializing and retrieving informations it will raise the InitializationPerformed signal. At this stage the SDK can be used. If your application makes use of bubbles or conferences, when InitializationPerformed is received it should call Bubbles.GetAllBubbles(). It is the right time to instantiate a WebRTCCommunications object, which will make it possible make calls or join conference. You can find more informations about the Rainbow SDK Here. This quick diagram summarizes how to initialize an application who would use WebRTCCommunications. Events in WebRTCCommunications The most importants events to handle to issue webrtc calls in your applications are CallUpdated , MediaPublicationUpdated and OnTrack. When a user receives a call, or is issuing the call, the WebRTCCommunications class informs him of the progression of the call using the CallUpdated events. The event provides you with an instance of the Call class, containing many useful information like The status The local and remote medias established on the call The participants The call Id which is needed to perform actions on this calls, like decline the call, hangup, publish some medias.. The other important event to handle is MediaPublicationUpdated. This happens each time a local or remote media is added to the call. A MediaPublicationUpdated event provides a MediaPublication object which can be used to subscribe to a MediaPublication using the method WebRTCCommunications.SubscribeToMediaPublication. Calling this method means that your application is interested in this media. If you subscribe to a media publication WebRTCommunications will send you the associated MediaStreamTrack using OnTrack event. Making Calls and Receiving Calls Here is a simplified (and incomplete) diagram showing how to use WebRTCCommunications events and methods to establish an audio Peer to peer call, using the MakeCall method. When another user calls your application, WebRTCCommunications emits a CallUpdated with a CallStatus of RINGING_INCOMING . To accept the call use WebRTCCommunications.AnswerCall, and to decline use WebRTCCommunications.RejectCall. What happens after AnswerCall is similar to what happens afte

excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedGetting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Common ! This SDK provides additional services / tools for all platforms (Windows, MacOs, iOs, A
content: DocumentationGetting startedGetting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Common ! This SDK provides additional services / tools for all platforms (Windows, MacOs, iOs, Android, Linux, ...) It uses as core the Rainbow CSharp SDK (core)* library. So you need first to understand how to use it. Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here Dependencies are all managed by Nuget package system. This package targets .Net Standard 2.0 and .Net Core App 3.1 Avatars service This service permits to download Contacts or Bubbles avatar (multiplatform): Avatars If a Bubble has none avatar set, this service create one using Contact avatars based on the bubble members (using 1 to 4 members) If a Contact has none avatar set, this service create one using Contact Initials with background color based on the contact display name. If an avatar is updated on server side, this service download it automatically and raise event to inform in consequence if a Contact or Bubble avatar has been updated. Local folders are used to store avatars. Several types of Avatars are stored (See AvatarType) and it's possible for each to set their sizes. It's possible to allow / disallow avatar download according the situation. ImageTools library Library to manipulate Image (multiplatform): ImageTools Get bitmap from file / Save bitmap to file Get Stream from bitmap Create bitmap Draw bitmap on another Resize bitmap Get SVG from resources in the package Create Bitmap from SVG (colors from original SVG can be changed to others one) Languages service This service permits to get labels in the specified language (multiplatform): Languages By default 'en' is used as language Id. To get the list of languages Id available use GetLanguagesList() method To change the language use SetLanguage() method The event LanguageChanged() permits to know if the language has been changed On this pageGetting StartedNuget packageAvatars serviceImageTools libraryLanguages serviceWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationChangelogSDK.Common for C# [2.6.18-LTS] - 2024-07-01 Changed Colors list used to create Avatars has been changed. .Net 6.0 as target plateform has been removed (obsolete). .Net Std 2.0, 2
content: DocumentationChangelogSDK.Common for C# [2.6.18-LTS] - 2024-07-01 Changed Colors list used to create Avatars has been changed. .Net 6.0 as target plateform has been removed (obsolete). .Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 8.0 are still in targets platform. [2.6.17-LTS] - 2024-05-27 Added ImageTools: GetSvgAsStringFromResourceName() New SVG files added (528 in total) [2.6.16-LTS] - 2024-03-19 Fixed The avatar of a bubble based on the avatars of its members will no longer contain the initials of one or more of these members Changed Breaking GetBitmapFromSvgResourceName() and GetBitmapFromSvgFile(): No longer return a square image but respect the SVG layout. A width parameter replaces the old size parameter. The height is automatically calculated. Avatars: now use logger prefix set in Rainbow.Application to create folder where Avatars are stored - so by default it will be Path.Combine(application.GetIniPathFolder(), "Resources", $"{prefix}Avatars") Files: now use logger prefix set in Rainbow.Application to create folder where Files are stored - so by default it will be Path.Combine(application.GetIniPathFolder(), "Resources", $"{prefix}Files") Update all labels for 22 languages Upgrade package SkiaSharp to 2.88.7 from 2.88.6 (since a rollback of dependencies used in this package has been done in this new version) Use Svg.Skia 1.0.0.13 instead of SkiaSharp.Svg 1.60.0 to allow to manage more type of SVG Added Include more than 500 SVG (before ~60 SVG) [2.6.15-LTS] - 2024-01-15 Added Add .Net 8.0 as target plateform (.Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still in targets platform) .Net 6.0 target platform will be removed in April. Changed Upgrade dependency package SkiaSharp to 2.88.6 from 2.80.3 (due to high security vulnerability) [2.6.14-LTS] - 2023-09-05 Changed Technical delivery to use SDK C# (Core) v2.6.18 [2.6.13] - LTS - 2023-07-07 .Net Core App 3.1 is no more targetted (already deprecated by Microsoft). .Net Standardd 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still targetted [2.6.12] - LTS - 2023-05-26 Dependency no more used: Newtonsoft.Json Update all labels to the most recent version [2.6.11] - LTS - 2023-05-03 Technical delivery due to SDK (core) updates [2.6.10] - LTS - 2022-07-12 Technical delivery to modify the validity date of the SDK [2.6.9] - LTS - 2022-05-10 Enriched documentation Technical delivery to modify the validity date of the SDK [2.6.8] - LTS - 2022-08-23 Enhancements It's now possible to log on different files if several instance of the SDK (Core) is used in sametime (for example if you use several bots in the same process). You need to set to the new parameter loggerPrefix a different value for each instance when Rainbow.Application object is created. You also need to use a different configuration file for your logger. See the online documentation for more details. In consequence the way to create these services have changed: Avatars, Languages and ImageTools: // Create Rainbow.Application - here with a logger prefix String prefix = "BOT01_"; // This can be null or empty if you don't need it var application = new Rainbow.Application(loggerPrefix: prefix); // ------------------------------------------------- // Before Avatars service was created like this: var avatars = Rainbow.Common.Avatars.Instance; avatars.SetApplication(application); // Now we use this to create Avatars service: var avatars = Rainbow.Common.Avatars.CreateInstance(application); // ------------------------------------------------- // Before Languages service was created like this: var languages = Rainbow.Common.Languages.Instance; // Now we use this to create Languages service: var languages = Rainbow.Common.Languages.CreateInstance(application); // ------------------------------------------------- // Before ImageTools service was composed of only static methods. Now you need to create it before to use any methods var imageTools = Rainbow.Common.ImageTools.CreateInstance(application); [2.6.7] - LTS - 2022-06-15 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.6] - LTS - 2022-05-23 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.5] - LTS - 2022-05-04 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.4] - LTS - 2022-04-07 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.3] - LTS - 2022-03-16 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.2] - LTS - 2022-01-27 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.1] - LTS - 2021-12-08 No update since last LTS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages SDK (core) [2.6.0] - LTS - 2021-11-18 No update since last STS version - Increase release versions to be consistent with other packages

content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK (core) ! It's an Assembly library based on CSharp for connecting your application to Rainbow. This assembly is multi-platform: you can use it on Windows, MacOs, Linux but also on Android, iOS and more. Its powerful APIs enable you to create the best application that connect to Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow. This tutorial will help you start with the ALE Rainbow SDK for CSharp (Core) by setting your environment wether you are using Windows, Linux or MacOS. UI Controls according to build quickly / easily an applicatin are provided in others packages specific by platform. But their interface are the same what ever the platform. Prerequisites Assembly in .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1, .Net 6.0 and .Net 8.0 The SDK is an Assembly targeting .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1, .Net 6.0 and .Net 6.0 so it can be used in those environments: .NET and .Net Core 2.0+ .NET Framework 4.6.1+ Mono 5.4+ Xamarin.iOS 10.14+ Xamarin.Android 8.0+ Unity 2018.1+ Universal Windows Platform 10.0.16299+ More details here Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here Dependencies are all managed by Nuget package system. Development environment You can use: "Visual Studio for Windows" - the community edition is free "Visual Studio for Mac" "Visual Studio Code" - Free for Linux, Mac and Windows If you are using a computer running on MacOS, you can follow this guide to setup your development environment. Setup your Visual Studio project Install "Rainbow.CSharp.SDK" as Nuget package In Studio Visual Studio 2019 (or more recent) Use the NuGet Package Manager UI and install the package "Rainbow.CSharp.SDK" Initialize the SDK Step 1 : Create a Rainbow application on the developers web site To use the SDK you need an applicationID and a secretKey from the developers website. These information allow you to identify your application and allow you to use the rainbow platform. For more information, see Applications lifecycle which explains what is the purpose, how to create an application and how to get the application ID and the secret key. The hostname is also necessary to know which server is used: the sandbox or the production server Step 2 : Initialize the SDK In your development environment, create an Rainbow.Application object like this: Rainbow.Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); myApp.SetApplicationInfo(applicationID, secretKey); myApp.SetHostInfo(hostname); Where myApp is your application object: with applicationID / secretKey from your Rainbow application created in step 1. with hostname according the server used (`sandbox.openrainbow.com' or 'openrainbow.com') After that you can Connect to Rainbow. excerpt: DocumentationEvents, Callback and SDKResultLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Events, Callbacks and SDKResult object Events and asynchronous methods The SDK is event-based and most methods are as
content: DocumentationEvents, Callback and SDKResultLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Events, Callbacks and SDKResult object Events and asynchronous methods The SDK is event-based and most methods are asynchronous. An event is a message sent by an object to signal the occurrence of an action. For example at any time, the state of the connection with the server can change: no more network connection for example (lost wifi...). It is therefore necessary to process this type of information at all times The methods are asynchronous because the SDK must request the server using REST requests, which can take some time. A callback is used to inform the user when the operation is finished - normally or with error. So you need to know how events and callback worked in C# if you want to understand how to use the SDK. IF you are already familiar with them you don't need to read all this guide but perhaps just the chapter about the SDKResult object. Register to events To register to an event you have to specify the method which will be used to receive the message raised by the event. This method must have the correct signature according the event used. For example if we focus on InitializationPerformed and ConnectionStateChanged of the Rainbow.Application object, they are defined like this: public event EventHandler<EventArgs> InitializationPerformed; public event EventHandler<Rainbow.Events.ConnectionStateEventArgs> ConnectionStateChanged; So to receive these events we must create a method for each, for example Application_InitializationPerformed and Application_ConnectionStateChanged like this private void Application_InitializationPerformed(object sender, EventArgs e) { // TO DO ... } private void Application_ConnectionStateChanged(object? sender, Rainbow.Events.ConnectionStateEventArgs e) { // TO DO ... } Once we have defined these methods, we must indicate that they must be used when these events are used like this: // Create Rainbow.Application object Rainbow.Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); // Register to event InitializationPerformed myApp.InitializationPerformed += Application_InitializationPerformed; // Register to event InitializationPerformed myApp.ConnectionStateChanged += Application_ConnectionStateChanged; Notice in the previous code the use of += to link the event to the method. Notice also that these methods will be used ONLY when the object myApp need to raise the event InitializationPerformed and ConnectionStateChanged. So the full code will be: // Create Rainbow.Application object Rainbow.Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); // Register to event InitializationPerformed myApp.InitializationPerformed += Application_InitializationPerformed; // Register to event InitializationPerformed myApp.ConnectionStateChanged += Application_ConnectionStateChanged; // Define method Application_InitializationPerformed which will be called when event InitializationPerformed will be raised private void Application_InitializationPerformed(object sender, EventArgs e) { // TO DO ... } // Define method Application_InitializationPerformed which will be called when event ConnectionStateChanged will be raised private void Application_ConnectionStateChanged(object? sender, Rainbow.Events.ConnectionStateEventArgs e) { // TO DO ... } It's possible to register several times to the same event using the same method (in this case the method will be called several times) or a different one still using += Unregister to events It's higly recommended to unregister to events if they are no more necessary - for example in desctructor of objects. For this you just have to use -= with method(s) used to receive the event. So to continue our example, we will use this: // Unregister to event InitializationPerformed myApp.InitializationPerformed -= Application_InitializationPerformed; // Unregister to event InitializationPerformed myApp.ConnectionStateChanged -= Application_ConnectionStateChanged; Manage callback A lot of methods in the SDK use callback mainly when the server is implied to provide the correct reponse. When a callback is used, it means that : The method is asynchronous and the result of the method will be provided in the callback. The code continue immediately after the call to asynchronous method The callback will be called in another thread that the one used to call the method To know if a method is asynchronous just look for Action or Action<...> int its parameters. For example in the Rainbow.Contacts service, we have this public methods available: public Company GetCurrentCompanyFromCache(); public void GetCurrentCompany(Action<SdkResult<Company>> callback); GetCurrentCompanyFromCache() is not asynchronous and will provide a Company object using data in the cache of the SDK. GetCurrentCompany has Action<...> as parameter. So it's an asynchronous method. The result will be provided by a callback. Below an example how to manage these both methods: // Create Rainbow.Application object Rainbow.Application my

excerpt: DocumentationConnect to RainbowLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Connect to Rainbow server Prerequisites To connect to Rainbow Server, you need first to have an applicationID and a secretKey fro
content: DocumentationConnect to RainbowLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Connect to Rainbow server Prerequisites To connect to Rainbow Server, you need first to have an applicationID and a secretKey from the developers website. See first Getting Started if it's not the case. Then you need to have a valid account (i.e. a login and a password). You also need to know how events and callback are managed in C# and also know how to use the SDKResult object. If it's not the case read first this guide Events to handle In order to follow correctly the login process, you have to handle several events from the Rainbow.Application object: AuthenticationFailed: raised when the authentication has failed - bad login/pwd and/or bad applicationID and a secretKey AuthenticationSucceeded: raised when the authentication has succeeded ConnectionStateChanged: raised when the connection stated has changed (ConnectionState.Disconnected, ConnectionState.Connecting, ConnectionState.Connected) InitializationPerformed: one connected this event is raised when the SDK is fully initialized. It will be necessary to wait the event InitializationPerformed before to use the SDK and not just the event ConnectionStateChanged with the status ConnectionState.Connected because internally the SDK needs to get minimal information from the server to be ready. For example, the SDK needs to get features and settings available for the current user before to be fully operationnal. It's done once the SDK is connected. Login process Find here the full code to manage correctly the login process in a Console application. using Rainbow; // Define objects String appId = ""; // To set according your settings String appSecretKey = ""; // To set according your settings String hostName = "openrainbow.com"; // To set according your settings String login = ""; // To set according your settings String password = ""; // To set according your settings // We will use aynschronous login method, so we use the Boolean to quit program only if : // - the authentication failed // - the initialization has been performed // - or we are disconnected Boolean endProgram = false; // Create Rainbow.Application object RbApplication = new Application(); // Set events that we want to follow RbApplication.AuthenticationFailed += RbApplication_AuthenticationFailed; // This method will be called when the authentication process will fail RbApplication.AuthenticationSucceeded += RbApplication_AuthenticationSucceeded; // This method will be called when the authentication process will succeed RbApplication.ConnectionStateChanged += RbApplication_ConnectionStateChanged; // This method will be called when the Connection State will change RbApplication.InitializationPerformed += RbApplication_InitializationPerformed; // This method will be called when the Initialization process will succeed // Set global configuration info RbApplication.SetApplicationInfo(appId, appSecretKey); RbApplication.SetHostInfo(hostName); // Start login RbApplication.Login(login, password); // => Here, the code continues immediately since the Login method is asynchronous. // We need loop until we want to end the program. // If this loop is not done, the program will exit before the login process has ended - due to error (bad pwd for example) or on success do { Thread.Sleep(100); } while (!endProgram); // Now we define methods which will be called by events defined previously void RbApplication_InitializationPerformed(object? sender, EventArgs e) { // Here we just log that the initialization has been performed Console.WriteLine($"InitializationPerformed"); // We can now quit for this sample endProgram = true; } void RbApplication_ConnectionStateChanged(object? sender, Rainbow.Events.ConnectionStateEventArgs e) { // Here we just log connection state in the console Console.WriteLine($"ConnectionStateChanged: [{e.ConnectionState.State}]"); if (e.ConnectionState.State == Rainbow.Model.ConnectionState.Disconnected) { // We can now quit for this sample endProgram = true; } } void RbApplication_AuthenticationSucceeded(object? sender, EventArgs e) { Console.WriteLine($"AuthenticationSucceeded"); } void RbApplication_AuthenticationFailed(object? sender, Rainbow.Events.SdkErrorEventArgs e) { // Authentication failed - we display in the console the reason Console.WriteLine($"AuthenticationFailed\r\n[{e.SdkError}"); // We can now quit for this sample endProgram = true; } On this pageConnect to Rainbow serverPrerequisitesEvents to handleLogin processWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationXMPP or Server to Server events modeLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Server to server (S2S) and XMPP events mode By default, the CSharp SDK uses XMPP to handle events from server using a Web socket. It's also XMPP which is used to send IM messages. It's the standard and official way if you are creating an Desktop or Mobile application or small bots with this SDK. If you want to create advanced bots or high availability and scalable server applications, it's better to use S2S (server to server) event mode. The CSharp SDK allows you, almost transparently, to use one of these event modes without the need for specific code. Only some events and methods are not available/allowed in S2S event mode (Cf. Events and Methods available). In the end of this guide, we explain a development strategy to help you set up your environment. Select an event mode To select a specific event mode, you only need to set if before the login to the Rainbow Server using EventMode property from Restrictions object accessible in Rainbow.Application. By default, the event mode selected is XMPP. If you choose S2S event mode, you also need to specify a callback URL (also called Webhook). See next chapter to understand the architecture involved in S2S and why/how the callback URL is used. String callbackUrl = "https://myWebServer.com/callbackPath"; Rainbow.Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); // Set S2S as event mode myApp.Restrictions.EventMode = Restrictions.SDKEventMode.S2S; // Need to specify in this event mode the Callback URL used to receive events myApp.SetS2SCallbackUrl(callbackUrl); // Now we can specify the Application ID, the Secret Key and the hostnam to use like always myApp.SetApplicationInfo(applicationID, secretKey); myApp.SetHostInfo(hostname); // We want to know when the initialization process has been performed correctly myApp.InitializationPerformed += MyApp_InitializationPerformed; // Finally we can log to the server myApp.Login("@email" , "password", callback => { if(callback.Result.Success) { // The login / pwd is correct // The SDK continue internally initialization process. We need to wait its end. } else { // A pb occurs if(callback.Result.Type == SdkError.SdkErrorType.IncorrectUse) { // Bad parameter(s) used string errMsg = callback.Result.IncorrectUseError.ErrorMsg; } else { // Exception occurs Exception e = callback.Result.ExceptionError; } } }); private void MyApp_InitializationPerformed(object sender, EventArgs e) { if (myApp.IsInitialized()) { // Login process has been performed and the initialization process has been performed correctly // We can now use any features } } XMPP event mode and architecture When XMPP Event mode is used, a WebSocket is created between the SDK and the Rainbow cloud server to receive events from server but also to send data for IM and Presence features. REST API is also used to get data from Server S2S event mode and architecture When S2S Event mode is used, there is no web socket but a callback URL is used (also called Webhook) to received events from Server. REST API is used to get data from Server and also to manage IM and Presence features. So if you want to handle a lot of messages you can scale your architecture using a load balancer. S2S event mode - handle events from Rainbow server In XMPP event mode, you have nothing to do to deal with incoming data from the web socket. They are automatically parsed internally and according the result an event is raised by the SDK. In S2S event mode, it's a little different. It's up to you to configure your web server, set the correct callbackURL and give to SDK the content of data received by this webhook. Your web server will receive data with a specific HTTP verb (GET, POST, PUT, etc...) with a specific absolute path (for example mypath based on the previous screenshoot since the callback URL used is https://my.derver.domain/mypath) with a specific content (JSON content) with a content type You must check that the content type is equal to application/json. For the 3 other data, you don't have to analyse / parse, you just need to provide them to the SDK - then it will parse the information, and, like in XMPP mode, according the result, an event is raised by the SDK. To do this you have to use the method ParseCallbackContent of the S2SEventPipe object. This method returns a boolean to indicate if the parsing has been done correctly or not. If the parsing is done incorrectly, your web server must return an HTTP 406 Not Acceptable answer. If the parsing is done correctly, your web server must return an HTTP 200 Ok answer. Rainbow.Application myApp = new Rainbow.Application(); Rainbow.S2SEventPipe s2sEventPipe = myApp.GetS2SEventPipe(); ... // You log to the Rainbow server using S2S event mode and specifing a callbackURL ... // Your Web server is receiving data from the Rainbow Server // 4 distinct data are necessaries String httpVerb; String urlAbsolutePath; String content; String contentType; // You also need

content: DocumentationSDK and server errorsLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13Errors list Most of SDK methods use SdkResult<T> object to provide a result or the reason of the error If no error occurs SdkResult<T>.Result.Succcess is equals to True. In this case SdkResult<T>.Data contains an object on T type. If an error occurs SdkResult<T>.Result.Succcess is equals to False. To get information about the error the SdkResult<T>.Result (which is a SdkError object) cand be used. There is three type of SdkError - see SdkErrorType: SdkErrorType.NoError: There is no error. You have to use SdkResult<T>.Data SdkErrorType.Exception: An unexpected exception has occurred. To have more information readable information use SdkError.ToString() or use SdkError.Exception object SdkErrorType.IncorrectUse: The way to use the method is not done correctly (network error, server errors, or sdk errors - like invalid parameter). In this case properties you can use ErrorCode, ErrorDetailsCode, ErrorDetails and ErrorDetailsData of the object SdkError.IncorrectUseError for more information. if SdkErrorType.IncorrectUse.ErrorCode is equals to 1000, it means that the SDK itself has raised an error. For other values, it means that the Rainbowserver has raised an error. Find below a full list of potential errors returned by the SDK or by the server. excerpt: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13CompareSDK (Core) for C# [2.6.26-LTS] - 2024-11-22 Fixed Ensure to send one by one message to XMPP server (when XMPP event mode is used) S
content: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 2.6.XPublished on 2021-12-13CompareSDK (Core) for C# [2.6.26-LTS] - 2024-11-22 Fixed Ensure to send one by one message to XMPP server (when XMPP event mode is used) Support by default HTTP Status 204 (No Content) Application service: avoid to set default presence to Offline. Use Online instead AutoReconnection service: badly managed 401 Unauthorized when renewing authentication token Bubbles service: avoid triggering BubbleAffiliationChanged in inappropriate cases. [2.6.25-LTS] - 2024-07-17 Fixed Internally use XmlElement object instead of String to avoid problem of parsing. Bubbles service: GetAllMembers() and GetMembersFromCache() methods - memberPrivilege filter badly used if **memberStatus ** filter is null. Added Company object: AutoAddToUserNetwork property [2.6.24-LTS] - 2024-07-01 Info For simplification and from this version, the SDK always retrieves the list of bubbles and the complete list of their members (if Restrictions.UseBubbles is used) and the list of conversations after connection/reconnection. It is therefore no longer necessary to ask for it. A new guide has been added to describe what data is stored in the cache, and when it is obtained/refreshed during connection or reconnection phases. Fixed Avoid crash in very restrictive environment (like in Alpine linux distribution) where CulturInfo object cannot be created. Ensure to answer to XMPP server on close message (rfc7395 - section 3.6) Application service: LoginWithToken method accepts token as string or ApplicationToken as JSON. Bubbles service: BubbleMemberUpdated event might not be triggered after a reconnection or when a new bubble owner was set. InstantMessaging service: SendAckMessage method now always escapes content. Added Bubble object: LastActivityDate and UsersById (dictionary of Users by Id). Bubbles service: BubbleAffiliationsPerformed() event is fired after login/reconnect when the current user has joined all their bubbles. If it is not a member of any bubble, the event is also triggered. Bubbles service: IsUnsubscribed() to know if user is unsubscribed to a bubble. Bubbles service: GetBubbles() now ensure to provide the full list of members (even if there is more than 100 members). Bubbles service: GetBubbles() and GetAllBubblesFromCache() have a new optional parameter memberStatus (null by default) to filter results. Bubbles service: GetMembers() have two new optionals parameters memberStatus (null by default) and memberPrivilege (null by default) to filter results. Bubbles service: GetOwner(), GetModerators() and IsBubbleAffiliated() methods BubbleMember object: UserJid property HttpClient object: If necessary, check inner-exception to avoid unnecessary disconnection. HttpClient object: To enhance performance, according REST API used and server settings, specific HTTP Headers are added - for example to manage Conference or Teams Presence using the correct Data Center. Restrictions object: UseTelephony and UseBubbles (both to true by default to be backwards compatible) allow to limit the use of Telephony and Bubbles services if they are not necessary. Restrictions object: LogBubbleMembers (false by default) to log also members when a log entry about Bubble is saved Util.LogAnonymously(): To log entries anonomouslys (by default) or not - useful in development phase. Util.RaiseEvent(): permits to log events raised or not raised according values of Restrictions.LogEvent and Restrictions.LogEventRaised (both true by default). If an event is not raised, it means that no code is using it. WebRTCSettings object: Once loggued/connected, if WebRTC is used, settings are retrieved and accessible using Application.WebRTCSettings property Changed Breaking BubbleMemberEventArgs: Member as BubbleMember objects replaces ContactJid, ContactId, Status and Privilege Breaking Restrictions: AlertMessage renamed to UseAlerts for coherency Util.LogString(): Still log first and last caracter but now log also the full length (before caracter '-' was used to replace hidden caracters) Util.Raise(): Now Obsolete, use instead Util.RaiseEvent() Util.SerializeException(): Use standard way to log exception. It permits to have more info (call stack for example) .Net 6.0 as target platform has been removed (obsolete). .Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 8.0 are still in targets platform. [2.6.23.1-LTS] - 2024-05-28 Fixed HttpStatuCode (like 404 or 406) returned by the server can be badly managed - impact only two methods: Bubbles.GetBubbleLink() and Contacts.SearchContactByPhoneNumber() [2.6.23-LTS] - 2024-05-27 Fixed Bubbles service: IsCreator() badly used userid default value Message object: bad use of System.Format() when using Message.ToString() which could prevent to raise event MessageReceived in InstantMessaging Ensure to remove presence level of current user when disconnected from event pipe Support Mono Runtime in .Net Standard 2.1 (already supported using .Net Standdard 2.0) Added Administration service: GetDomainNameF

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: Rainbow SDK for CSharp environmentConnect your desktop application to RainbowEverything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp.This SDK for CSharp is now deprecatedThis release of SDK for
content: Rainbow SDK for CSharp environmentConnect your desktop application to RainbowEverything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for CSharp.This SDK for CSharp is now deprecatedThis release of SDK for CSharp is now deprecated. It will still continue to work, but neither evolutions nor corrections will be provided anymore. We invite you to migrate to release 3. Follow the link below to read the migration guide.Migrate to SDK CSharp V3Useful informationVersion: LTS 2.6.XPublished: 13 déc. 2021Last Updated: 22 nov. 2024Consult the changelogSDK for CSharp at a glance.Learn about the main APIs provided by this SDKAssembly in .NETProvides an highly efficient library for environments .Net Standard 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 8.0 ( .NET Core 2.0+, .NET Framework 4.6.1+, Mono 5.4+, Xamarin.iOS 10.14+, Xamarin.Android 8.0+, Unity 2018.1+, Universal Windows Platform 10.0.16299+ )Contacts, search and presence APIHandle your contact list and know when they are available, busy on the phone or away. Search for users by name or id to extend your network.One-to-one Chat APIExchange messages with your contacts. Be alerted when contacts send you a message. You can retrieve the whole conversation or only the most recent messages.Bubbles groupchat APICreate and invite users, or reuse your bubbles for talking together. In a bubble, everyone can participate to the conversation.WebRTC audio and video APIYou can initiate audio and video calls to your contacts using your browser without a plug-in. Enhance your call from audio only to video. Choose which device you want to use and control the call (mute/unmute).WebRTC Conference APIYou can join a conference in a bubble. Control the video you want to see and control your device (mute/unmute).Call logs APIRetrieve the history of all calls made from your PBX phone or from you Rainbow application. Be notified in real time of new log.PSTN telephony APIYou can initiate or anwer any call with your PBX phone. The API covers all basic telephony features such as putting a call on hold and retrieving it, diverting a call to voice mail, making a conference call with multiple participants and more.Groups APIGroup your contacts by activity, other... . Make some groups become your favorites groups.Files sharing APIShare files with a user in a one-to-one chat or within a bubble with several participants. You're also able to download files shared by others in your bubble.Channels APISend messages to channels which may have more than thousands suscribers. Subscribe to users public channels to follow them and receive what they publish!Always onOnce started, the SDK is always connected to Rainbow and so can handle requests endlessly.Proxy traversalThe SDK can be used through a HTTP or HTTPS proxy, with or without authentication.ServiceabilityFull and flexible logging capability allowing easy debugging.Interesting linksLearn how to use our SDKsNeed some help?Contact our support teamVisit our homepageFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Medias. This SDK can be used as a standalone package witho
content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK Medias. This SDK can be used as a standalone package without the need of Rainbow Account, Rainbow Server or Rainbow Infrastructure. This SDK can be used on these platforms: Windows, MacOs, and Linux. Only x64 platforms are supported. Android and iOS are NOT YET supported. Features It permits to manage Audio and Video streams using: Local / Remote Files IP TV, Live Stream Server Devices like Webcam, Screen/Monitor, Microphone, Speaker, Headset, ... To access remote streams all this protocols are supported. An Audio and/or Video Stream (whatever its source) is calles a Media in this SDK. A Media can be composed of one Audio stream and/or one Video stream. Using a Media it's then possible, for example, to create a Media Player: Start, Stop, Pause, Resume, Seek actions are possible. Using one Media or severals, it's then possible to create a MediaFiltered using a Video filter and/or an Audio filter. Video Filter allows to: scale, crop, pad, resize, change fps, add subtitles create mosaic, overlay, dynamic mask Audio filter is not yet supported. The MediaFiltered will use the Audio stream of the specified Media. On the fly you can change the filter. The Audio/Video stream of the MediaFiltered will be updated in consequence without the need to re-start all Media used. Filter - List, Syntax and Examples Filter - List The list of available Audio filters are available here The list of available Video filters are available here Filter - Syntax Same syntax used in FFmpeg can be used in this package. The best thing to do it's to test first your filter using ffmpeg with a command line using "-vf" parameter (to set video filter). The same value can be used as filter in this SDK. Filter - Examples Here some examples than can be used. Using only one Media To have video in gray: format=gray To blur the video: avgblur=10 To scale the video: scale=400:-2 To crop the video: crop=400:400 To draw a text on the video: drawtext=text=%{localtime\: %X }:fontcolor=white:fontsize=40:y=(main_h-text_h)/2:x=(main_w-text_w)/2 To add subtitles on the video using subtitles from the file "c:\media\TOEFLTest.mp4" subtitles=f=c\\:\\\\medias\\\\TOEFLTest.mp4:si=0 Several options can set in same time, for example, to scale then pad the video: scale=200:-2,pad=320:200:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2 Here, we blur a zone of a video and add also subtitles: [0:v]crop=400:400,avgblur=10[fg];[0:v][fg]overlay=(main_w-overlay_w)/2:(main_h-overlay_h)/2[blured];[blured]subtitles=f=c\\:\\\\media\\\\TOEFLTest.mp4:si=0 Using two Medias To display two videos streams in one stream. Each video stream is first scaled and padde to a 320x240 stream. Then they are displayed vertically. [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-2,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-2,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [a0][a1]xstack=inputs=2:layout=0_0|0_h0[out] The first video stream is scaled then overlay on the second one: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=250:-2[a2]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a1]; [a1][a2]overlay=x=W-w:y=0 The first video stream is scaled then using a circle and a mask we ouse it as overlay on the second one: [0]scale=250:-1,geq='st(3,pow(X-(W/2),2)+pow(Y-(H/2),2))\;if(lte(ld(3),pow(min(W/2,H/2),2)),255,0):128:128'[scaledMask]; [0]scale=250:-1[scaled]; [scaled][scaledMask]alphamerge[cutout]; [cutout]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a2]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[a1]; [a1][a2]overlay=x=W-w:y=0 Using more than two Medias Four Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then they are used to create a grid of 2x2: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [2]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a2]; [3]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a3]; [a0][a1][a2][a3]xstack=inputs=4:grid=2x2 Six Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then theyr used to create a grid of 2x3: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a1]; [2]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a2]; [3]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a3]; [4]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a4]; [5]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a5]; [a0][a1][a2][a3][a4][a5]xstack=inputs=6:grid=2x3 Nine Video streams are scaled then padded to have a 320x240 output. Then theyr used to create a grid of 3x3: [0]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2,format=rgb24[a0]; [1]setpts=PTS-STARTPTS,scale=320:-1,pad=320:240

excerpt: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01CompareSDK.Medias for C# [1.0.0] - 2024-07-01 Fixed Improves the way to get/calculate Fps. Avoid to use several streams when grabbing remote
content: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01CompareSDK.Medias for C# [1.0.0] - 2024-07-01 Fixed Improves the way to get/calculate Fps. Avoid to use several streams when grabbing remote videos (for CCTV for example) Changed Use FFmpeg.AutoGen package v7.0.0 (from v6.0.0.2) Use FFmpeg v7.0.1 shared libraries (from v6.0) .Net 6.0 as target plateform has been removed (obsolete). .Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 8.0 are still in targets platform. [0.0.9-STS] - 2024-03-19 Fixed Allow to stream as video a JPG file (already possible with BMP, TIFF, PNG, WEBP (with one image), ...). GIF are also supported but not WEBP with animation due to FFmpeg limitation Changed Use Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions v8.0.0.0 (from v7.0.0.0) [0.0.8-STS] - 2024-01-15 Added Add .Net 8.0 as target plateform (.Net Std 2.0, 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still in targets platform) .Net 6.0 target platform will be removed in April. [0.0.7-STS] - 2023-10-18 Added MediaInput: allow to set widht, height, fps and bit rate used in encoding process. Take into account options set in the device InputStreamDevice: Allow to set options [0.0.6-STS] - 2023-09-05 Added Add SetVideoBitRate() in MediaInput, MediaRtpInput and MediaFiltered Changed Use FFmpeg.AutoGen v6.0.0.2. Use FFmpeg v6.0 libraries. Enhancement in parser used to set filters [0.0.5] - STS - 2023-07-07 .Net Core App 3.1 is no more targetted (already deprecated by Microsoft). .Net Standardd 2.0 / 2.1 and .Net 6.0 are still targetted [0.0.4] - STS - 2023-05-26 Fix MediaRTPInput: Some internal values was not resetted correctly MediaFiltered: When a new filter is set, it's necessary to dispose ALL previous objects to ensure to build correct frames [0.0.3] - STS - 2023-02-10 Enhancements It's now possible to decode RTP packets (Audio and/or Video) using MediaRtpInput object. A valid SDP must be provided which describes codecs to use to decode them. It possible for the moment to manage only one Audio track and/or one Video Track. If you have several tracks for a same media, it's possible to specify which one to use using an index. [0.0.2] - STS - 2023-01-20 Enhancements Major rework to avoid memory leak. Use of IDisposable interface in objects using unmanaged objects to ensure to dispose them. Rework interfaces (IMedia, IMediaVideo, IMediaAudio, IMediaVideoOutput, IMediaAudioOutput) and inheritances in major objects: MediaInput, MediaFiltered and MediaOutput API In details IMedia interface (now inherits from IDisposable) Loop: added To know if we loop automatically if the end of file is reached Duration: added Duration in seconds of the Media (if not a life stream) LiveStream: added To know the Media is a 'live steam' i.e. a remote stream for a live stream server, live camera or an IPTV for example OnEndOfFile: added Event raised when the Media as reached the end of the file. Init: added To init the media. IMediaVideo interface: Loop: removed Duration: removed LiveStream: removed Init: removed IMediaVideoOutput interface: added GotVideoFrame: added To add Video Frame to this Media Video Output MediaFiltered now inherits from IMediaVideo and IMediaAudio SDL2AudioInput implements IMedia interface SDL2AudioOutput implements IMedia interface MediaFormat static class: remoced data/methods are now in Helper class [0.0.1] - STS - 2022-12-07 This is the first version of this SDK. Please refer to the "getting started" guides for feature details On this pageSDK.Medias for C#[1.0.0] - 2024-07-01[0.0.9-STS] - 2024-03-19[0.0.8-STS] - 2024-01-15[0.0.7-STS] - 2023-10-18[0.0.6-STS] - 2023-09-05[0.0.5] - STS - 2023-07-07[0.0.4] - STS - 2023-05-26Fix[0.0.3] - STS - 2023-02-10Enhancements[0.0.2] - STS - 2023-01-20EnhancementsAPI In details[0.0.1] - STS - 2022-12-07Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 1.XPublished on 2024-07-01Getting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow CSharp SDK WebRTC.Abstractions This SDK provides provides common interfaces and objects to implement/use to be compatible with WebRTC features provided by the Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC library. It cannot be used directly except if you want to create a new implementation to support WebRTC features in another environment. Nuget package The SDK is provided as a Nuget package available here This package targets .Net Standard 2.0, .Net Standard 2.1, .Net Core 6.0 and .Net 8.0 Implementations available: For the moment, there 2 differents implementations available: Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Desktop library compatible with Windows, MacOs, and Linux Rainbow.CSharp.SDK.WebRTC.Unity library (for the moment used in private usage only) On this pageNuget packageImplementations available:Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on
