title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationAdding application ID and secret keyLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Adding Application ID and Secret key To connect to Rainbow, the Web SDK needs to be authenticated. This is done
content: DocumentationAdding application ID and secret keyLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Adding Application ID and Secret key To connect to Rainbow, the Web SDK needs to be authenticated. This is done by injecting an Application ID and a Secret Key. This guide will help you understand how to connect to Rainbow. Preamble For more information on the application lifecycle, you can read the tutorial Application lifecycle. When you want to develop your Rainbow application and use it with real users, it needs to be authenticated by Rainbow and needs an application ID and secret key. If you don't provide an application ID and secret key, your application will not be able to connect to Rainbow and all requests will be refused by Rainbow. Create an application The first thing to do is to create an application on the Rainbow for Developers. Open your browser and navigate to the Rainbow for developers Sign in using your Rainbow account In the Applications panel, click on the button "Create new application" Fill the application information and click on the button "Save" Your application is now created. You can use it on the Rainbow Developers Sandboxed Platform. Get your application ID and secret key Once your application is created, you can retrieve the application ID and secret key by clicking on the button "View Key". Keep this information for yourself and do not share it with anyone. Inject your application ID and secret key <html lang="en"> ... <body> <script> import rainbowSDK from 'rainbow-web-sdk'; /* Callback for handling the event 'RAINBOW_ONREADY' */ var onReady = function onReady() { // Do something with the SDK is ready (e.g. user signed in) ... }; var onLoaded = function onLoaded() { rainbowSDK.initialize("your_application_ID", "your_secret_key").then(function() { // Do something when the SDK is initialized ... }).catch(function() { // Do something if there is an issue in the initialization of the SDK ... }); }; /* Listen to the SDK event RAINBOW_ONREADY */ document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.RAINBOW_ONREADY, onReady) /* Listen to the SDK event RAINBOW_ONLOADED */ document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.RAINBOW_ONLOADED, onLoaded) /* Manually load the SDK */ rainbowSDK.load(); </script> </body> </html> Understanding errors The following errors can be received by your application: CodeDetailed CodeErrorDescription 401401100Request has some problems with basic authentication headerThe format of the application ID or secret key is not good. It should be a String 401401500Unknown application or wrong token for application id <...>No application with that ID has been found or your secret key doesn't match 401401600Wrong env for application id <...>Your application is not deployed. You need to deploy it before connecting to Rainbow 401401700Wrong state for application id <...>Your application is not in state new or active Last updated January, 15th 2020 On this pageAdding Application ID and Secret keyPreambleCreate an applicationGet your application ID and secret keyInject your application ID and secret keyUnderstanding errorsWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21CompareSDK for Web Here is the list of the changes and features provided by the Rainbow-Web-SDK [4.0.0-LTS] - 2022-11-21 contact model - a
content: DocumentationChangelogLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21CompareSDK for Web Here is the list of the changes and features provided by the Rainbow-Web-SDK [4.0.0-LTS] - 2022-11-21 contact model - add new properties related to custom user profile management : fileSharingEnabled, fileStorageEnabled, instantMessagesEnabled, bubblesEnabled, webrtcAudioEnabled, webrtcVideoEnabled, webrtcSharingEnabled, modifyProfileEnabled; contact model - Add also professionalMobileNumber and professionalMobileNumberCan pbxService - Add new APIs: subscribeToCCDEvents and getCurrentCCDAgentStatus for the CCD Agent management [3.4.0-STS] - 2022-10-06 conferenceRecording - add conferenceRecording that allows to record web conferences on server side suggestionsService - add suggestionsService that allows to find contact suggestions in the same company, i.e. "people you may know" BREAKING CHANGE - Message model no longer contains alternativeContent, use additionalContent instead [3.3.0-STS] - 2022-08-25 callsLogService - the maximum number of call logs per request is 250 (both for fetchCallLogs and fetchPaginatedCallLogs) virtualBackground - add virtualBackground Service to manage the virtual background for calls [3.2.0-STS] - 2022-06-14 General bug fixes and stability improvements [3.1.3-STS] - 2022-06-16 Fix HDMI Screens chosen as output device when plugged-in. [3.1.2-STS] - 2022-06-03 Fix dual channel headset issues; Fix STEREO microphone use cases [3.1.1-STS] - 2022-05-18 Fix problems with the audio devices management [3.1.0-STS] - 2022-05-16 WebRTCService - ### BREAKING CHANGE ### remove useSpeaker and useCamera and useMicrophone APIs (user should use the new deviceManagement service) ### BREAKING CHANGE ### remove setChromeExtensionIdForSharing API (and globally deactivate chrome extension for sharing, as no longer needed) deviceManagement - ### BREAKING CHANGE ### Service to be used for the device management (audio input/output and video input devices) [3.0.2-LTS] - 2022-04-27 CallsLogService -- remove deprecated getAll() API [3.0.1-LTS] - 2022-04-22 Fix problems with signout method that sometimes does not resolve the promise [3.0.0-LTS] - 2022-04-21 Support of WebRTC unified plan for all calls and conference Includes all the changes introduced in the STS versions 2+ (see previous changelog entries) [2.13.0-STS] - 2022-04-01 WebRTCService - after removing sharing from a call containing remote video stream, the #large_video element is updated now automatically to the remote video stream webConference - add new Web Conference Service V2 Fix issues with conferencesService [2.12.2-STS] - 2022-03-18 Fix problems with signout() method [2.12.1-STS] contactsService - add new API isCalendarSharingActivated presenceService - add new event RAINBOW_ONMYCONTACTPRESENCECHANGED fired when there's change in the contact presence / status FIX: remote video is added automatically when RAINBOW_ONWEBRTCCALLSTATECHANGED is fired and there are remote streams available [2.12.0-STS] IMPORTANT: deactivated new models by default. Use config or useNewModels API to activate them. Starting this version the old models are recommended for usage ConfigService - add new APIs: setAutoAway and setAutoAwayDelay pbxService - add new event: RAINBOW_ONFORWARDMODEUPDATED pbxService - add new APIs: getForwardMode and setForwardMode callsLogService - fix problems with RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGACKUPDATED event after calling markAllCallsLogsAsRead API conversationsService - fix issues with openConversationForBubble API. It becomes asynchronous now and works with closed conversations. conversationsService - remove @deprecated tag from openConversationForBubble and openConversationForContact [2.11.0-STS] ContactsService - add two new APIs : getUserAutoDndCalendarSetting and updateUserAutoDndCalendarSetting BubblesService - add new API : reactivateInactiveBubble ConnectionService - fix bugs with connection methods. From now on user can not call signin mehtod during another connection process or when the user is already connected. Update TelephonyMode docs PbxService - update docs around the RAINBOW_ONVOICEMESSAGEUPDATED with information about the AVST VoiceMail type ContactsService - fix bug in searchCompanyDirectory API [2.10.1-STS] Fix issues with video calls in Firefox Fix issues with loading the SDK [2.10.0-STS] Bubble / Room model - add new property - isAlertNotificationEnabled. It is true when at least one member of the bubble has the feature enabled. Contact model - add new property - isAlertNotificationEnabled. It is true when the contact has the feature enabled. ChannelsService - signature of createItem changes. url parameter is deleted (no longer used) Add new service - telephonyKeysService allowing user handle speed dial keys TelephonyService - add new methods: getTelephonyMode and setTelephonyMode. They allow the Cloud PBX (Rainbow HUB) user to change telephony mode TelephonyService - remove setNomadicWebRTC after months of deprecation CallsLogService - prevent RAIN

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationChatting in Rainbow bubblesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Chatting in Rainbow bubbles Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can have discussions and share files with several persons
content: DocumentationChatting in Rainbow bubblesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Chatting in Rainbow bubbles Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can have discussions and share files with several persons in a "private" area called a Bubble. A Bubble is a "collaboration space" where you can invite Rainbow users to discuss and share files together. This tutorial will explain in details how to create a new bubble, invite Rainbow users and discuss together. If the objects / models Call, Contact, Conversation aren't accessible in your non-AngularJS application (to access enums), you can get it with this: var Call = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Call'); var Contact = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Contact'); var Conversation = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Conversation'); Creating a new bubble Creating a new bubble can be done using the API createBubble(). You have to provide a name and a description. Create a new bubble without history By default, when you create a bubble, newcomers do not see previous messages exchanged in that bubble before they join. Creating a new bubble without history can be done this way: var ownedBubble; /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ rainbowSDK.bubbles.createBubble("My New Bubble", "The description of my bubble").then(function(bubble) { ownedBubble = bubble; // Do something when the bubble has been created ... }).catch(function(err) { // Do something if there is a server issue when creating the new bubble ... }); Note: You can't create several bubbles with the same name. Create a new bubble with history An optional parameter can be used to specify if the newcomers have the possibility to get the old messages exchanged in the bubble before they join. This example creates a bubble with history. let ownedBubble; /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ rainbowSDK.bubbles.createBubble("My New Bubble with history", "The description of my bubble", true).then(bubble => { ownedBubble = bubble; // Do something when the bubble has been created }).catch(err => { // Do something if there is a server issue while creating a new bubble }); Optional parameters CreateBubble() method accepts a number of optional parameters. Here is the list of them all with a brief explanation: let strName = 'Bubble name' // The name of the bubble let strDescription = 'Bubble Description' // The description of the bubble let boolWithHistory = false // True to have full messages history for newcomers let disableNotifications=false // When set to true, there is no more notifications to be sent by a room in all cases with text body (user join/leave, conference start/end) let urlAvatar=null // The avatar URL or null (in case of invalid URL or image it may fail) let autoAcceptInvitation=false // Set to 'true' to automatically invite other users to the bubble (without asking them to accept the invitation) let ownedBubble; /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ rainbowSDK.bubbles.createBubble(strName, strDescription, boolWithHistory, disableNotifications, urlAvatar, autoAcceptInvitation).then(bubble => { ownedBubble = bubble; // Do something when the bubble has been created }).catch(err => { // Do something if there is a server issue while creating a new bubble }); Inviting Rainbow users in a bubble Once the bubble is created, you have to invite users in order to be able to discuss with them. Users can't join a bubble directly. They must be invited by a moderator of that bubble to become a member. You can invite a Rainbow user as a member with Participant privilege which is the default case or with Moderator privilege. Inviting a new participant To invite a Rainbow user as a participant, add the following code: var invitationBubble; var contact = ... // A contact got using Contacts API /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ rainbowSDK.bubbles.inviteContactToBubble(contact.id, ownedBubble).then(function(updatedBubble) { ownedBubble = updatedBubble; // Do something when the invitation has been sent successfully ... }).catch(function(err) { // Do something if there is a server issue when sending the invitation ... }); Members with participant privilege can only collaborate in the bubble: Sending and receiving messages Sending and downloading files Inviting a new moderator To invite a Rainbow user as a moderator, add the following code: var ownedBubble; var contact = ... // A contact got using Contacts API var asModerator = true; /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ rainbowSDK.bubbles.inviteContactToBubble(contact.id, ownedBubble, asModerator).then(function(updatedBubble) { ownedBubble = updatedBubble; // Do something when the invitation has been sent successfully ... }).catch(function(err) { // Do something if there is a server issue when sending the invitation ... }); Members with moderator privilege can collaborate and administrate the bubble. Ad

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationChatting with Rainbow usersLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Chatting with Rainbow users Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can send and receive messages to Rainbow users. This tuto
content: DocumentationChatting with Rainbow usersLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Chatting with Rainbow users Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can send and receive messages to Rainbow users. This tutorial explains in details how to make it work. Steps To be able to reach someone by chat, you need to do the following steps: Get a reference to the Rainbow Contact object representing the person you want to join. Retrieve the associated Conversation object with that person or create a new one if it is the first interaction with that person. Send the message to that person. Manage the receipts. If the objects / models Call, Contact, Conversation are not accessible in your non-AngularJS application (to access enums), you can get it with this: var Call = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Call'); var Contact = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Contact'); var Conversation = angular.element(document.querySelector('body')).injector().get('Conversation'); Retrieving the contact object There are several possibilities in Rainbow to retrieve a Contact object associated to a person depending on the fact whether or not this person is in your network. The next paragraphs will describe the different methods. Getting a contact from your network If the person is in your network, when the Rainbow SDK is started, you can directly access him by using the following method: getContactById(). If the contact is not in your list, these methods will return null. If you want to iterate through your list of contacts, you can call the method getAll() that will return an array containing the entire list of contacts that are in your network. In the following code sample, imagine your app displays a hardcoded list of contacts with only a name, a photo and a Rainbow Id and when the user clicks on a contact in that list, you want to display the associated conversation for chatting with that person. The function onContactSelected is called with the id of the contact when the user pressed on a contact item in your list. So, from that, it is easy to get the associated Contact object. var selectedContact = null; /* Handler called when user clicks on a contact */ var onContactSelected = function(contactId) { selectedContact = rainbowSDK.contacts.getContactById(contactId) .then(contact => { // Do something with the retrieved contact object }) .catch(err => { // Search failed }); } Searching for a contact If the contact is not in your network, you have to send a request to Rainbow to retrieve it. Depending the information you have you can call different APIs: searchContactById() or searchContactByName(). The two first methods will return the contact or null if it is found and the last one will return potentially several contacts or an empty array. The difference between these methods and the methods seen for getting a network's contact is that searching a contact is an asynchronous task. We need to wait for the answer coming from the server, so these 3 methods here are Promise based methods. The previous code can be updated like that: var selectedContact = null; /* Handler called when the user clicks on a contact */ var onContactSelected = function(contactId) { selectedContact = rainbowSDK.contacts.getContactById(contactId); // Contact not found locally, ask to the server if(!selectedContact) { rainbowSDK.contacts.searchContactById(contactId).then(function(contact) { selectedContact = contact; if(selectedContact) { // Ok, we have the contact object ... } else { // Strange, no contact with that Id. Are you sure that the id is correct? ... } }).catch(function(err) { //Something when wrong with the server. Handle the trouble here ... });; } } Retrieving the conversation object Once we have the contact, the next step is easy, we just have to call the getConversationByContactId() API by passing the contact found previously. This method is asynchronous too. var associatedConversation = null; ... rainbow.conversations.getConversationByContactId(contactId).then(function(conversation) { associatedConversation = conversation; }).catch(function(err) { //Something when wrong with the server. Handle the trouble here }); The retrieved Conversation object will never be null because if there was no previous interaction with that person, a new conversation will automatically be created and returned. Getting the previous messages exchanged By default when receiving the conversation associated to a user and if it exists, you can display the latest message exchanged by accessing the property lastMessageText: ... var lastMessage = conversation.lastMessage; If you need the messages history (messages already exchanged with that person), you need to call the API getMessagesFromConversation() that takes the Conversation object as a parameter and the number of messages to retrieve. By default, you can get the last 30 messages. You can retrieve up to 100 messages at a time. If there is more messages, you need to call t

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationConnecting to RainbowLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Connecting to Rainbow This tutorial will help you understand how to connect to Rainbow and how to call its APIs. Rainbow Knowl
content: DocumentationConnecting to RainbowLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Connecting to Rainbow This tutorial will help you understand how to connect to Rainbow and how to call its APIs. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails Sandbox platform for developersThis Rainbow platform is dedicated to developers. The Sandbox platform for developers is not connected to the Production platform and let developers be familiar with our APIs and SDKs. This platform uses different accounts. Production platformThis Rainbow platform is the official one with all Rainbow services and infrastructures enabling a high availability and accessibility all over the world.This is the platform you use to connect to our Rainbow applications. Preamble In order to better understand how to use the Rainbow Web SDK, here are some technicals points: Rainbow offers REST APIs. When you use the Rainbow Web SDK, you do not have to know how to call them. The Rainbow Web SDK offers methods that hide these API to simplify your work (the SDK calls them internally). Most of these REST APIs coming from Rainbow are asynchronous which means that the server's response do not come immediately. And to not block your application, the request do not wait for the answer to avoid UX issues. To simplify your work, most of the time, the SDK will use JavaScript Promise to let you build build asynchronous requests. If it is not possible, you will have to listen to events for handling late answers or notifications. With all that stuff, your application will be able to handle notifications such as incoming instant messages. If you are not familiar with JavaScript Promise, you can have a look to the example below to see how to implement a Promise based behavior. You can also spend time on the Stack Overflow or search others available tutorials. Once you are logged to Rainbow, a Websocket connection is opened between your application (in fact the SDK for Web) and Rainbow in order to receive notifications that come from people or things (e.g. phone devices, materials etc.). The SDK for Web defines a lot of events that you have to handle in your application to be notified when something happens. Look at the example below to know how to subscribe to these events. Sign in to Rainbow By default, when calling the method signin(), you will sign in to the Rainbow Sandbox platform for developers. So you need to have your Sandbox account enabled. If not, use the Rainbow API Hub to connect and to activate your Sandbox developer account. You will receive an email with your Sandbox credentials shortly. If you want to connect to the Rainbow Production platform, you have to use the API signinOnRainbowOfficial(). You can use your Rainbow credentials to connect. Before being able to sign in, you need to listen to the event RAINBOW_ONREADY to know when the SDK for Web is ready to be used. The following example works using jQuery to catch the event fired by the SDK. Note: Do not forget to add your application ID and secret key when using the method initialize(). In case you need more help, read the guide Injecting Id and secret key var onReady = function onReady() { var myRainbowLogin = "login"; // Replace by your login var myRainbowPassword = "password"; // Replace by your password // The SDK for Web is ready to be used, so you can sign in rainbowSDK.connection.signin(myRainbowLogin, myRainbowPassword) .then(function(account) { // Successfully signed to Rainbow and the SDK is started completely. Rainbow data can be retrieved. ... }) .catch(function(err) { // An error occurs (e.g. bad credentials). Application could be informed that sign in has failed ... }); }; // Listen when the SDK is ready document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.RAINBOW_ONREADY, onReady) } Listen to authentication events During the authentication step, some events are available. Here is the list of these events you could listen to know if your SDK has been correctly signed and started. ServiceEventValue (String)Description sdk.connectionRAINBOW_ONSIGNED"signed"Authentication of the user succeeds sdk.connectionRAINBOW_ONSTARTED"started"All SDK services have been started Event RAINBOW_ONSIGNED This event is fired as soon as the SDK for Web has signed successfully to Rainbow to let you retrieve your account information and token. This event is fired before the event RAINBOW_ONSTARTED. At this stage, the SDK for Web can not retrieve data nor invoke services. You have to wait either for the event RAINBOW_ONSTARTED or for the fulfillment of the signin() promise. Event RAINBOW_ONSTARTED This event is fired when the SDK for Web is connected to Rainbow (i.e. after calling the login API) and when all SDK services are ready to be used. This event is fired just before giving the hand to the application after calling the signin() method. At this stage, the SDK can retrieve data from Rainbow and invoke any services. Code sample Here is a code sample that i

excerpt: DocumentationCreating audio and video conferencesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Creating audio and video conferences You can use Rainbow SDK for Web to create a WebRTC-based audio and video m
content: DocumentationCreating audio and video conferencesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Creating audio and video conferences You can use Rainbow SDK for Web to create a WebRTC-based audio and video multi-party conference. WebRTC is a technology allowing the developers to ensure a real-time communication (RTC) in the browser, should it be a peer-to-peer conversation or a multi-party conference. The goal of this tutorial is to show how easy it is to create and modify an audio and video multi-party conference by using Rainbow SDK for Web. By the end of this tutorial you will be able to: Create an audio and video conference; Use audio stream in your conference; Chat with up to 4 rainbow users using audio and video; Add and remove video streams from your conference; Finish or quit conference; Basic prerequisites In order to proceed to creating audio and video conferences, you would need a thorough understanding of the concepts like Rainbow Connection, Chatting with Rainbow Users or Chatting in Rainbow Bubbles. Shortly, you need to have your application ready and started. Make sure you can connect with your Rainbow accounts, search for contacts, check your browser capabilities (audio, video), etc. Introduction WebRTC call concept presented in the context of Rainbow SDK for Web can be divided into two parts. First one is a peer-to-peer (P2P) connection between two users. This connection is relatively simple to introduce and its idea is quite straightforward. In order to learn how to establish a P2P audio/video connection, read the chapter called Initiating audio and video calls. Second one is a multi-party conference which is the main topic of this tutorial. Checking if user has active conference sessions Rainbow SDK can handle one conference at a time. That means a user which has an active conference session can not start or join any other conference until he finishes (or quits) the existing one. You can check whether the user that is logged in has active conference session by using the function rainbowSDK.conferences.hasActiveConferenceSession() which returns a Boolean. This function is available at any time for the logged in users. //... somewhere in your code if (rainbowSDK.conferences.hasActiveConferenceSession()) { return true; // You are not able to start or join a web conference } else { return false; // You are free to start or join a web conference } The response gives you an important information as a user which has an active conference session can not start or join web conference. Creating a web conference To create a web conference, you need to call the following function: rainbowSDK.conferences.startOrJoinWebConference(bubble), and pass your existing bubble as the argument. startOrJoinWebConference() function returns a promise, so the example of the code would look like that: //... somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.conferences .startOrJoinWebConference(bubble) .then(bubbleWithWebConf => { // Everything went fine, WebRTC conference is launched bubble = bubbleWithWebConf; }) .catch(error => { // Something went wrong, handle the error }); Having a Bubble object is essential to be able to create a WebRTC conference using Rainbow SDK for Web. If you have not created a Bubble yet, please check our tutorial Chatting in Rainbow Bubbles. startOrJoinWebConference() function works both for the conference organizator (Bubble owner) as well as for the members of a Bubble who want to join the conference. Rainbow Web SDK will verify the user role and act accordingly. Listening to the conference events From this moment on you can start receiving the updates on the conferenceSession object. In order to listen to the change events you should use an event listener in your code. var onWebConferenceUpdated = function(event) { // do something with the conference object var conferenceSession = event.detail console.log(conferenceSession); }; //... somewhere in your code document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.conferences.RAINBOW_ONWEBCONFERENCEUPDATED, onWebConferenceUpdated) Event listener is passing a conferenceSession object to your function. You can use this object in order to get the informations about the current state of the conference. Consider it as the entry point to all the operations that you will later perform on your WebRTC conference application. All the important informations about the existing web conference will be passed through that object. It is quite important for many functions that you might potentially want to use in your application, so make sure you have this event listener included in your code. Also, do always keep the latest conferenceSession object for reference. In the following part of the tutorial you will find plenty of references to the conferenceSession object. Other ways of getting the conferenceSession object You can retrieve the conference object by passing conferenceId parameter to the function getConferenceSessionById(conferenceId). One of the ways of getting conferenceId string is lo

content: DocumentationDevelopment KitLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Development Kit The Rainbow SDK for Web contains: A JavaScript library: This file has to be included in your application. Several demo applications to demonstrate how to use the SDK for Web library. An API documentation that describes the available APIs (that you can call from your application) and that contains some tutorials explaining the fundamentals parts. JavaScript SDK library There is no delivery of this file. See the Getting Started guide to understand how to load it. Note: The samples provided here load the SDK for Web library directly from our Rainbow cloud platform. THIS IS FOR DEMO ONLY AND NOT FOR A COMMON USE. We DO NOT recommend to do this way when developing your application and when releasing it to production. You need to follow the Getting Started guide and download a fixed version that you will need to support as for any other third party libraries you use. This is because sometimes some adaptations need to be done when upgrading to a new version. So, this can't be handled automatically. Samples In order to help you discover the Rainbow Web SDK, we have put in place several samples. Each sample can be downloaded. You can then easily look through the source code, adapt-it and finally launch locally. These samples are connected to the Sandbox platform by default so to log-in, you will need some accounts on this platform. Read the guide Managing tests accounts to have more information on how to create accounts on the Sandbox platform. ContentSource code on Github Rainbow IM demo (JavaScript AngularJS)Source on git Rainbow Telephony demo (JavaScript AngularJS)Source on git Rainbow WebRTC audio/video demo (JavaScript AngularJS)Source on git Rainbow Contacts demo (JavaScript AngularJS)Source on git To launch a demo locally on your computer: Clone the GitHub repository Open a shell in the directory Run the following command: npm install You will need an SSL certificate. If you do not have one yet, please install openssl Then launch openssl req -newkey rsa:2048 -new -nodes -x509 -days 3650 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem to generate one locally At the end, all you need to do is to run a npm start command in the shell. That should start a HTTP server and open your default browser on http://localhost:8887 Note: There will be security warnings in your browser. It is normal as we will use a certificate not trusted by an external authority. Respective information considering each of the samples can be found in their respective README.md files. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Getting Started Welcome to the Rainbow Web Software Development Kit! The Rainbow Web SDK (Software Development Kit) is a pure Angula
content: DocumentationGetting startedLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Getting Started Welcome to the Rainbow Web Software Development Kit! The Rainbow Web SDK (Software Development Kit) is a pure AngularJS JavaScript library that works on all modern browsers from IE 11 to the latest version of Chrome, Firefox, Safari and Edge. Its powerful APIs enable you to create the best JavaScript applications that connect to the Rainbow Cloud Services. Getting started with Rainbow Web SDK could not be easier. By adding a single line to your existing JavaScript project, you will have access to the public API of the Rainbow Cloud Services. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails RainbowAlcatel-Lucent Rainbow™ is a cloud-based, enterprise-grade, Unified Communication as a Service (UCaaS) and Communication Platform as a Service (CPaaS) that connects people and systems EventsEvents are asynchronous messages or notifications that come from Rainbow when something related to your data happens. By listening to theses events, your application will be able to react and inform the user of these changes. MethodsMethods are all the SDK functions your application can call to enable Rainbow services such as initiating a WebRTC call, sending a file, etc. In most of the cases, Methods are asynchronous and follow the JavaScript Promise pattern. Preamble Well, well, well... Yet another JavaScript library or SDK... As if it was missing... Yes, but with this one, you will "change the world and make it better"! because it's amazing! With Rainbow Web SDK you have the potential to build your own social network, your own banking, hospitality or whatever app you want with audio and video as well as multi-party chat interactions between your users just by adding this library to your app! Take time to read this first tutorial to understand the basics and then deploy your imagination and your coding spirit to build your app! OS and browsers support The Rainbow Web SDK is based on jQuery and the AngularJS framework. The Rainbow Web SDK works on: Chrome stable channel and Chromium based browser (e.g. Opera) Firefox ESR and stable channel Microsoft Edge Microsoft Internet Explorer 11 Safari The Rainbow Web SDK is supported on Windows (starting from Windows 7) and MacOSX (Starting from 10.10). The Rainbow Web SDK can be integrated into any Web application (i.e.: React, Vue), browser extension or desktop application that embeds a Webview (e.g. QT application, Electron, nw.js). Some integration examples can be found on our Github. What is the Rainbow Web SDK? Rainbow Web SDK is a JavaScript library you have to use in order to connect and access Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow. Once loaded and initialized, you have access to the library by using the variable rainbowSDK. This library is divided in services that let you access tons of methods and connect your app to the Rainbow functionalities. For example, the rainbowSDK.webRTC is the service dedicated to WebRTC (audio/video calls). It will give you access to all the WebRTC available features that you can use. In that service you can use the method rainbowSDK.webRTC.callInVideo() to make a video call with another Rainbow user. To help you discover all the available services, you can have a look at the documentation accessible on the left side of this page. Additionally, each service offers a set of events that you can listen to be notified of asynchronous things (e.g. incoming WebRTC call, etc.) that could occur. Methods There are two kinds of methods: Those that deal with the Rainbow platform: For these APIs, a promise based object is returned in order to allow you to continue the execution of your code once the result of this API is known (good or not). Those that only do things on the client side: For these APIs, the result is returned synchronously. When you do not call the API with the right parameters, you always get a JSON result containing an error code and an error label that is much more explicit (...) /* Example of error code object */ { code: SDK.ERRORBADREQUEST, // -16 label: "Parameter 'contact' can't be null or empty" } Events Events are initiated from the library when something that comes from the server happens. They are asynchronous. It is not mandatory to listen to all the events that come from the server. Choose the right ones you need! See also Injecting Application ID and Secret Key Integrating JavaScript frameworks Integrating AngularJS applications Connecting to Rainbow Last updated May, 24th 2019 On this pageGetting StartedRainbow KnowledgePreambleOS and browsers supportWhat is the Rainbow Web SDK?MethodsEventsSee alsoWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDevelope

excerpt: DocumentationHello World (ES Module)LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Hello, World (but with ESM)! This tutorial will explain how to start a basic Rainbow Web application and use the Rainbow SDK
content:
DocumentationHello World (ES Module)LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Hello, World (but with ESM)! This tutorial will explain how to start a basic Rainbow Web application and use the Rainbow SDK as ES Module. You can learn more about modules from this article. If you wonder how to set up the development environment and basic application structure, you are in the right place. If you have already built an app, this article will reiterate through the fundamental app structure in case you got lost on the way. At the end of this tutorial you will have a working application that could be considered as a starting point for developing an app using Rainbow Web SDK. You will also get the basic notion of the key Rainbow Web SDK concepts. The goal is to keep it simple, therefore we will be using the basic folder structure and vanilla JavaScript. This will be less disturbing for the new developers and expose the Rainbow Web SDK features to the veterans. Set up your development environment Before you start using Rainbow Web SDK, you need to make sure you have installed the required software tools. Install Node.js and NPM Make sure you have installed Node.js and NPM on your computer by running the following commands: $ node --version > v12.14.1 $ npm --version > 6.14.1 If any of those commands does not return a version number, follow the installation guides (Node, NPM) Browser We will be using Chrome or Firefox to develop, but you can use any of the browsers supported by Rainbow Web SDK. Text editor Rainbow Web SDK is a JavaScript library, therefore you can use any text editor or IDE to develop your first project. Create your web application As mentioned above, the project is going to use a basic structure of a simple JavaScript application. We will need a basic HTML structure that would load all the necessary libraries. Go on and create a new folder. We recommend using command line tools. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: $ mkdir myFirstRainbowProject $ cd myFirstRainbowProject $ npm init -y Once finished, you should have your JSON file package.json filled with the information. This step is required to install the required NPM libraries. Install Rainbow Web SDK Now, it's time to install the Rainbow Web SDK library. The SDK for Web is available as an NPM package to make the installation and updates easier. To install it, execute the following command (make sure you navigate to your project folder first): npm i -S rainbow-web-sdk Once Rainbow Web SDK has been installed, your project directory should look like this: . ├── node_modules │ └── rainbow-web-sdk │ ├── src │ │ ├── rainbow-sdk.min.js │ │ └── vendors-sdk.min.js │ ├── LICENSE │ └── package.json └── package.json The Rainbow Web SDK has been added to your folder node_modules. This folder contains all the packages installed from NPM Installing a local Web server To test the basics of your application, you will need an HTTPS Web server. You can install an NPM library HTTP-Server by executing the following command: npm i -D http-server Create a /public folder If you're building a Web application without using tools like Grunt, Gulp, Brunch or Webpack or without using JavaScript framework like React, you need to manually create public directory. You can execute the following command: mkdir public Create your first HTML file We have installed all the basic libraries necessary to create a simple project. We can now focus on creating a HTML skeleton file that would hold our app intact. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: cd public touch index.html cp ../node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/src/* . Loading the Rainbow Web SDK library Open the file public/index.html with your text editor of choice and add the following lines to load the Rainbow Web SDK library: My First Rainbow Application

Rainbow Hello World Application

Rainbow Web SDK depends on some libraries that have to be loaded first like jQuery, moment and AngularJS. To have a complete compatibility with all browsers, the libraries es5-shim and es6-shim are loaded too. Be careful to use the correct version of jQuery, moment and AngularJS specified here to avoid compatibility issues. To simplify this sample, these libraries are loaded from a CDN. Run your local HTTPS server $ cd ..

excerpt: DocumentationHello World (legacy)LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Hello, World! Following the decades-long tradition, we are pleased to present the "Hello, World!" tutorial that will walk you t
content:
DocumentationHello World (legacy)LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Hello, World! Following the decades-long tradition, we are pleased to present the "Hello, World!" tutorial that will walk you through the basic steps required to launch your first application that uses Rainbow Web SDK. If you wonder how to set up the development environment and basic application structure, you are in the right place. If you have already built an app, this article will reiterate through the fundamental app structure in case you got lost on the way. At the end of this tutorial you will have a working application that could be considered as a starting point for developing an app using Rainbow Web SDK. You will also get the basic notion of the key Rainbow Web SDK concepts. The goal is to keep it simple, therefore we will be using the basic folder structure and vanilla JavaScript. This will be less disturbing for the new developers and expose the Rainbow Web SDK features to the veterans. Set up your development environment Before you start using Rainbow Web SDK, you need to make sure you have installed the required software tools. Install Node.js and NPM Make sure you have installed Node.js and NPM on your computer by running the following commands: $ node --version > v8.10.0 $ npm --version > 3.5.2 If any of those commands does not return a version number, follow the installation guides (Node, NPM) Browser We will be using Chrome or Firefox to develop, but you can use any of the browsers supported by Rainbow Web SDK. Text editor Rainbow Web SDK is a JavaScript library, therefore you can use any IDE to develop your first project. Create your web application As mentioned above, the project is going to use a basic structure of a simple JavaScript application. We will need a basic HTML structure that would load all the necessary libraries. Go on and create a new folder. We recommend using command line tools. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: $ mkdir myFirstRainbowProject $ cd myFirstRainbowProject $ npm init Answer the asked questions. Once finished, you should have your JSON file package.json filled with the information. This step is required to install the required NPM libraries. Install Rainbow Web SDK Now, it's time to install the Rainbow Web SDK library. Starting Rainbow 1.29, the SDK for Web is available as an NPM package to make the installation and updates easier. To install it, execute the following command (make sure you navigate to your project folder first): $ npm i -s rainbow-web-sdk Once Rainbow Web SDK has been installed, your project directory should look like this: . ├── node_modules │ └── rainbow-web-sdk │ ├── dist-legacy │ │ └── lib │ │ ├── loader-sdk.min.js │ │ ├── rainbow-sdk.min.js │ │ └── vendors-sdk.min.js │ ├── src │ │ ├── loader-sdk.min.js │ │ ├── rainbow-sdk.min.js │ │ └── vendors-sdk.min.js │ ├── LICENSE │ └── package.json └── package.json The Rainbow Web SDK has been added to your folder node_modules. This folder contains all the packages installed from NPM Installing a local Web server To test your application, you will need an HTTP Web server. You can install one (HTTP-Server) by executing the following command: $ npm i -D http-server Copying SDK files If you're building a Web application without using tools like Grunt, Gulp, Brunch or Webpack or without using JavaScript framework like React, you need to manually copy the Rainbow Web SDK files to your public directory. You can execute the following command: $ mkdir public $ cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist-legacy/vendors-sdk.min.js public/ $ cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist-legacy/rainbow-sdk.min.js public/ Create your first HTML file We have installed all the basic libraries necessary to create a simple project. We can now focus on creating a HTML skeleton file that would hold our app intact. Open a shell console and execute the following commands: $ cd public $ touch index.html Loading the Rainbow Web SDK library Open the file public/index.html with your text editor of choice and add the following lines to load the Rainbow Web SDK library: My First Rainbow Application

My First Rainbow Application

Rainbow Web SDK depends on some libraries that have to be loaded first li

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationInitiating audio and video callsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Initiating Audio and Video calls Using Rainbow Web SDK, you can make audio and video calls towards your contacts th
content: DocumentationInitiating audio and video callsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Initiating Audio and Video calls Using Rainbow Web SDK, you can make audio and video calls towards your contacts thanks to WebRTC. This tutorial will help you understanding how it works and will give you the hints for adding the possibility in your application to communicate in audio and video successfully. You can also start a WebRTC Conference (or desktop sharing) in a given Bubble (only one at a given time). If you want to see how to use Rainbow Web SDK to create a simple conferencing application, please have a look at our public GitHub Repository: Rainbow Web SDK - WebRTC Sample. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails A peerA peer is a participant of a call in a peer-to-peer call or in a conference call. A legA leg is a kind of media shared in a call. It can be: audio, video or sharing WebRTC Peer to Peer CallThis is a call between 2 users. One is the caller, the second is the callee or the recipient. WebRTC Conference callThis is a call between 2 or more users. An audio only CallAn audio only call uses only the microphone for dispatching the audio leg to the recipient. An audio and Video callAn audio and video call uses the microphone and a camera for dispatching both audio and video legs to the recipient. A sharing callA sharing call uses the screen or an application for dispatching a data leg to the recipient. The call can be initiated with or without an audio leg. The audio leg can be added during the call. Escalate to video callWhen in an audio call, you can decide at any time to add a video leg with your recipients. This mechanism is called an escalation (i.e. adding a new leg to an existing call). Be careful, this is not a mutual escalation. Each participant can decide to escalate or not on his own. Preamble Rainbow Web SDK allows to make audio video calls. To do so, the Web SDK relies on the WebRTC stack included in your compliant browser. The Web SDK supports one-to-one audio and video call and conference call. In order to be able to make an audio and video call between you and other recipients, you need: A compliant browser: At this time of writing only Firefox and Chrome browsers are supported by Rainbow Web SDK. Consequently, you have to use one of these browsers to make an audio and video call. HTTPS: In order to use Rainbow audio and video API, you need to serve your application using HTTPS. A negotiation server: A server for exchanging the audio and video negotiation part between all participants of the call. Rainbow will do it, you don't need to care about this part. A signaling protocol: To establish a call between two participants or several ones in a conference, a signaling protocol is used to allow each peer to negotiate all required parameters for exchanging correctly his audio and video legs with the others participants. Rainbow Web SDK integrates this protocol so that you have nothing to do on that part. Relay servers: Depending your network condition, a STUN server could be needed to allow your application to know how to be joined from Rainbow or from a recipient. An additional media relay server (TURN) could be needed for relaying the communication when there are blocking network elements (i.e. a firewall) between the users and between the users and Rainbow when in a conference. Rainbow has several TURN and STUN servers dispatched all around the world that will be used if needed. You don't need to care about this part. As you can see, the Web SDK provides you with all the complicated things you need: no signaling part to manage, no STUN or TURN server to deploy... Detecting your browser compatibility Rainbow Web SDK can help you checking if the browser can do WebRTC calls. Use the method canMakeAudioVideoCall() such as in the following code sample: /* Somewhere in your application... */ /* Call this method to know if your application can make audio and video call */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.canMakeAudioVideoCall()) { /* Your browser is compliant: You can make audio and video call using WebRTC in your application */ } else { /* Your browser is not compliant: Do not propose audio and video call in your application */ } This is the easier way to detect that your browser is compliant with WebRTC. But you can use your own code to do that by calling directly the WebRTC APIs. Once you know that your browser is compliant, you need to know if a webcam or at least a microphone is available in order to make audio or video call. Call the method hasACamera() and hasaMicrophone() to check the device detected by your browser. /* Somewhere in your application... */ /* Call this method to know if a webcam is detected */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.hasACamera()) { /* A webcam is available, you can make video call */ ... } else { /* No webcam detected */ ... } /* Call this method to know if a microphone is detected */ if(rainbowSDK.webRTC.hasAMicro

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationIntegrating Angular 1.x applicationsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Integrating AngularJS 1.x applications The SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library. Internally, JavaScrip
content: DocumentationIntegrating Angular 1.x applicationsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Integrating AngularJS 1.x applications The SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library. Internally, JavaScript modules of the SDK are based on AngularJS Services, Models, etc... If your application is based on AngularJS 1.x too, this tutorial will describe how to integrate and use Rainbow Web SDK. If it's not the case either because your application is based on an other JavaScript framework or a more recent version of AngularJS, you have to read the guide Integrating JS frameworks. Preamble To be able to use our Rainbow SDK for Web in an AngularJS 1.x application you will need to follow the steps below: Install Rainbow Web SDK NPM package Load the SDK Start the SDK Initialize the SDK Subscribe to events Call methods Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails SDK loaderThe SDK Loader is an open-source library made by Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise. It helps loading the SDK for Web and all its dependencies in an AngularJS 1.x application. EventsEvents are asynchronous messages or notifications that come from Rainbow when something related to your data happens. By listening to theses events, your application will be able to react and inform the user of these changes. MethodsMethods are all the SDK functions your application can call to enable Rainbow services such as initiating a WebRTC call, sending a file, etc. In most of the cases, Methods are asynchronous and follow the JavaScript Promise pattern. Rainbow SDK for Web installation Open a shell console and execute the following command in your application directory (application root folder): $ npm install rainbow-web-sdk --save Then copy the files to a directory served by your Web server (e.g. public/). $cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist/vendors-sdk.min.js <your_folder> $cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist/rainbow-sdk.min.js <your_folder> $cp ./node_modules/rainbow-web-sdk/dist/loader-sdk.min.js <your_folder> Loading Rainbow SDK for Web In your AngularJS application, you can load SDK for Web by using our own loader. For more details, have a look to the guide Loading AngularJS applications In your entry HTML file (e.g. index.html), add the following script at the end of your <body> tag. This will get the SDK for Web loader from the Rainbow official cloud and load your configuration file. <!-- Add the following lines to your 'index.html' file --> <html lang="en" ng-controller="sampleController"> <body> ... <script src="<path_to_your_file>/loader-sdk.min.js" data-main="./config.json"></script> ... </body> </html> When the browser executes your HTML file, it will load your config.json file that has to be correctly filled. Once done, the SDK for Web, its dependencies and your application files that use the SDK will be loaded by the browser. Starting the SDK Using the loader, the SDK for Web is started automatically once the files have been loaded by the browser. From your application files (e.g. from your main controller), you can listen when this loading step is complete by adding these lines: /* In your controller file, add the following lines to depend on the SDK module */ var sample = angular.module("sample", ["sdk"]); sample.controller("sampleController", [ "rainbowSDK", function(sdk) { "use strict"; var onLoaded = function onLoaded() { // The SDK has been loaded successfully console.log("[DEMO] :: Rainbow SDK has been loaded!"); }; // Listen when the SDK has been loaded successfully $rootScope.$on(sdk.RAINBOW_ONLOADED, onLoaded); } ]); Initializing the SDK Before you can call SDK methods, you need to initialize the SDK, by calling the method initialize() and listen to the RAINBOW_ONREADY event in order to be sure that the SDK has been started correctly. Simply add the following lines to your application: /* In your controller file, add the following lines to depend on the sdk module */ var sample = angular.module("sample", ["sdk"]); sample.controller("sampleController", [ "rainbowSDK", function(sdk) { "use strict"; var onReady = function onReady() { console.log("[DEMO] :: Rainbow SDK is ready!"); }; var onLoaded = function onLoaded() { console.log("[DEMO] :: Rainbow SDK has been loaded!"); sdk.initialize() .then(function() { console.log("[DEMO] :: Rainbow SDK is initialized!"); }) .catch(function() { console.log("[DEMO] :: Something went wrong with the SDK..."); }); }; $rootScope.$on(sdk.RAINBOW_ONREADY, onReady); $rootScope.$on(sdk.RAINBOW_ONLOADED, onLoaded); } ]); Calling the SDK methods Once your application has been loaded and initialized successfully, you can call Rainbow SDK methods by using the keyword sdk followed by a service name such as contacts or bubbles and a method like getContactById(). For example, you can initiate a webRTC call by using the method sdk.webRTC.callInVideo(Contact). Most of the time, methods are asynchronous and return a JavaScript Promise. Subscribing to SDK

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationIntegrating with FrameworksLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Integrating in JavaScript frameworks Even if the SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library, it can be used in any ki
content: DocumentationIntegrating with FrameworksLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Integrating in JavaScript frameworks Even if the SDK for Web is an AngularJS 1.x based library, it can be used in any kind of JavaScript applications that are either not based on this AngularJS 1.x version or based on libraries like Backbone, React, Ember, Vue, Bootstrap or jQuery. This tutorial helps you integrate the Rainbow SDK for Web in your own JavaScript environment. Preamble Integrating a JavaScript library into an existing Web application is not often an easy step and sometimes takes time. This tutorial is here to help you integrate our Rainbow SDK for Web library in your web site or web application to benefit from our Rainbow services. If you have never used our Rainbow SDK, the best way to start is to follow our Getting Started guide. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understand this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails EventsEvents are asynchronous messages or notifications that come from Rainbow when something related to your data happens. By listening to theses events, your application will be able to react and inform the user of these changes. MethodsMethods are all the SDK functions your application can call to enable Rainbow services such as initiating a WebRTC call, sending a file, etc. In most of the cases, Methods are asynchronous and follow the JavaScript Promise pattern. Installation, loading and initializing Follow Hello World - ESM guide to find out how install, load and initialize Rainbow Web SDK. Calling SDK Methods Once your application has been loaded and initialized successfully, you can call Rainbow SDK methods by using the keyword rainbowSDK followed by a service name such as contacts or bubbles and a method name like getContactById(). rainbowSDK is a global variable accessible from everywhere in your application once you have bootstrapped the SDK. For example, you can initiate a WebRTC call by using the method rainbowSDK.webRTC.callInVideo(aContact). Most of the time methods are asynchronous and return a JavaScript Promise. Access to SDK Constants You can access Call and SDK constant directly from rainbowSDK object: let Call = rainbowSDK.Call; let SDK = rainbowSDK.SDK; Integrating the SDK for Web in React, Vue and Angular We have published several starter kits that can be downloaded from GitHub. You can use them to quickly start a new project using your framework of choice and the Rainbow SDK for Web. The source code of the starter kits can be downloaded from our GitHub. Do not hesitate to enhance them or to propose other integrations. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationInteracting with usersLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Interacting with users, bots and things Rainbow is called a relationship machine because by using our SDKs and APIs you can f
content: DocumentationInteracting with usersLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Interacting with users, bots and things Rainbow is called a relationship machine because by using our SDKs and APIs you can find users, bots and things, keep a link with each of them, make groups and interact with them in a unique way. Additionally, you can create privileged relations with them that let you access to information such as their availability. Doing so let you build a lot of scenarios and could help you knowing the best way to reach them. The Rainbow SDK for Web offers a lot of methods that will be covered in that guide to let you build and manage your relationships. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails A contactA contact is a Rainbow user who is in the network of the connected user. The networkThis is the list of contacts with whom you are sharing mutually your availability such as your phone presence, you activity presence, etc... Network is empty by default and can grow by sending and accepting invitations to Rainbow users. This action is call joining the network. An invitationAn invitation to join the network is a request that can be sent to any Rainbow users who can be found by the search engine. An invitation can be accepted or declined.When accepted, the user is added to the network or other user and inversely. When declined, the request is discarded. A groupUsers in Rainbow can be gathered by defining groups. Groups allow to categorize and organize your relations, friends, colleagues, bots, connected things, etc. Preamble As indicated in the introduction, using Rainbow, you can interact with users, bots or things. Having an interaction means: Being able to discover any entities such a users, bots or things Being able to dialog actively with them for example by making a video call with an user or receiving an instant message from a bot Being able to keep a link to them (e.g. retrieving the conversation or creating groups) And being able to get passive information from them such as their connection presence, phone presence, etc.- which means having a privileged relation. The different kinds of interactions are described in the following paragraphs. Discovering Rainbow entities The first thing to do to interact with users is to be able to find them. This step can be done with the integrated search engine. The SDK for Web has several methods to let you search or get Rainbow users. Searching by name If you know the firstname or the lastname or just some part of those data, you can use the method searchByName(). Using it, you need to specify at least the beginning of the name or the first name. Try to give as much information as you have in order to avoid having too many results. Here is an example of using this method: rainbowSDK.contacts.searchByName("Jon Doe", 10).then(function(usersFound) { if(usersFound.length > 0) { // At least one user has been found usersFound.forEach(function(user) { // Do something with each contact returned }); } else { // No contact returned } If you do not specify any values for the limit parameter, a maximum of 20 results will be returned. No more 1000 results can be returned. This is the common method when searching for a user or a bot. Searching by Id or by Jid If you know either the Rainbow id of the user or his jid, you can use the method searchById() or searchByJid() instead. These methods return the user if found or null elsewhere. rainbowSDK.contacts.searchById("5be9826de3bc5e54c13e00bd").then(function(entityFound) { if(entityFound.) { // Do something with the entity found } else { // No entity returned } There are the common methods when searching for a bot or a connected thing. Interacting with users and things As mentioned previously, users or things are represented by the same structure that is a Contact. Once you have a Contact object representing a Rainbow user, a bot or a connected thing, you can use several methods to interact with. For example: For exchanging instant messages and files: Use the method openConversationForContact() from Conversations service. Once conversation is created or retrieved, you can send messages and files. For calling him in video: To initiate an audio or audio and video call, use the method callInAudio() or callInVideo() from the WebRTC service. For collaborating with him in Bubbles: Use the method inviteContactToBubble() from the Bubbles service to invite him to your bubble. For sending him notifications: Use the method addMembersToChannel() from the Channels service to add him to a channel. For calling him by phone: Use the method callByNumber() from the Telephony service to call him on his phone device. For keeping a direct link: Use the method addContactInGroup() from the Groups service to add him to one of your groups. See the next paragraph for more details on Groups. For sharing your presence Send an invitation to your network by calling the method addToNetwork
