excerpt: DocumentationLoading Angular 1.x applicationsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Loading AngularJS 1.x applications In this tutorial, you will discover how to setup the config.json file right for
content: DocumentationLoading Angular 1.x applicationsLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Loading AngularJS 1.x applications In this tutorial, you will discover how to setup the config.json file right for loading the SDK for Web, its dependencies and your application files. This way of loading is designed to be used in AngularJS 1.x based applications only. If your application is based on an other JavaScript front-end framework like Backbone, React, Ember, jQuery or recent version of Angular, please have a look at the guide Getting Started; this tutorial will help you loading and using the SDK for Web in your specific environment. Preamble In order to propose an easy way for loading and configuring your application, we decided to remove the complexity from the index.html file by keeping only the minimum viable tags. All the others things (i.e. the list of files to load, the settings) will be loaded from a configuration file. Like explained in the previous tutorial, the first thing you have to do is to add the following lines to your HTML file: <!-- Add the following lines to your 'index.html' file --> <html lang="en" ng-controller="sampleController"> <body> ... <script src="/path_to_loader/loader-sdk.min.js" data-main="./config.json"></script> ... </body> </html> By default the file config.json will be used as your configuration file. You can rename it or load it from an other place. Do not forget to update the path! Note: As you can see, the 'ng-app' attribute that lets you bootstrap your application is no more needed (it will be defined inside the configuration file). Understanding the loading steps This configuration file is divided into several parts that are loaded one after the other in order to keep some logical order and avoid for example to load the applications file that depend on the SDK before it. There are 5 steps for loading your application: Step 1: Load the pre-requisites libraries: The first step is to load the libraries needed by the SDK. In most of the cases, you do not have to modify these parts except if you want to remove ones that you have already been loaded by your own Step 2: Load the SDK for Web: Once the prerequisites are loaded, the SDK for Web follows Step 3: Load the others libraries: There part can be empty or contains additional libraries that need to be loaded after the SDK for Web Step 4: Load the applications files: Once all of the "framework" part has been loaded, the applications files are loaded too Step 5: Bootstrap the application: Once all is loaded, the application is bootstrapped and then ready to start which means that your main controller is called (in case of an AngularJS application). The following paragraphs will focus on each of the steps above to help you understand and setup the configuration file. Discovering the configuration file Here is the content of the configuration file you need to have in order to load all your files correctly. You can copy and paste this config.json sample and adapt it to fit your needs. { "libraries": { "prerequisites": [ "//code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.3.min.js", "//cdn.jsdelivr.net/momentjs/2.15.1/moment-with-locales.min.js", "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.5.7/angular.min.js" // for Rainbow Web SDK versions > 1.53 use : "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.7.5/angular.min.js" ], "sdk": { "official": [ "path_to_vendors_file/vendors-sdk.min.js", "path_to_rainbow_file/rainbow-sdk.min.js" ], "default": "official" }, "after": [] }, "app": { "bootstrap": "sample", "key": { "appID": "", "appSecret": "" }, "js": ["./src/js/sdkSampleApp.js", "./src/js/components/connection/connectionCmp.js", "..."], "css": ["src/styles/sdkSampleApp.css", "src/js/components/connection/connectionCmp.css", "..."] }, "settings": { "verboseLog": true, "disableCache": true, "enableLoader": true } } Be careful when modifying the configuration file, it should be a valid JSON file (i.e. no comments). When you are modifying this file, you can open your browser developer console in order to see if all is correct (a lot of logs have been added to help you understand what is going on when something goes wrong). Loading the prerequisites The SDK for Web prerequisites are loaded first. As mentioned before, in most of the cases, you do not have to modify this part because if these files are not loaded first, the SDK for Web will not load and work correctly. { "libraries": { "prerequisites": [ "//code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.3.min.js", "//cdn.jsdelivr.net/momentjs/2.15.1/moment-with-locales.min.js", "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.5.7/angular.min.js" // for Rainbow Web SDK versions > 1.53 use : "//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.7.5/angular.min.js" ], ... } ... } By default these files are loaded from a CDN. You can change the path if you want to load them from a local directory. If your application depends on an other third-party libraries, you can add them in this part. They will be loaded for you. Note: The use of "//" let

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationManaging FavoritesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Managing Favorites Rainbow Web SDK allows you to store links to conversations with Users and Bubbles in a handy list called Favor
content: DocumentationManaging FavoritesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Managing Favorites Rainbow Web SDK allows you to store links to conversations with Users and Bubbles in a handy list called Favorites. Favorites are essentially a JavaScript array containing objects. Each of those objects the following properties: type - describing a type of a Favorite. Can be set either to user or bubble id - representing an ID of a Favorite peerId - a dbId property of a Bubble or User that is linked to Favorite object contact or room - essentially a contact or bubble object that is linked to Favorite item With those four you will have a good peak on what Users or Bubbles are the most used and essential for the application. Retrieving Favorites List You can retrieve Favorites List from the server by calling fetchAllFavorites() method that returns an Array. Favorites Array can be empty when no User or Bubble has been added to Favorites. It is an asynchronous method, therefore it returns a Promise containing the Favorites Array. // somewhere in your code rainbowSDK.favorites.fetchAllFavorites() .then(function (favorites) { // do something with the Favorites Array retrieved from the server }) .catch(function (err) { console.log (err) }) Creating a Favorite To create a Favorite (add a new object to the Favorites list), use the favorites.createFavorite() method which accepts a Bubble or User dbId and type as arguments. createFavorite() returns a Promise due to its asynchronous nature. A snippet below shows how to create a Favorite of each of the types: var user = UserObject; var bubble = BubbleObject; // Create a new Favorite from an User: rainbowSDK.favorites.createFavorite(user.dbId, "user") .then( // do something once the Favorite has been created ) .catch( // do something in case of an error ) // Create a new Favorite from a Bubble: rainbowSDK.favorites.createFavorite(bubble.dbId, "bubble") .then( // do something once the Favorite has been created ) .catch( // do something in case of an error ) Once a new Favorite is created, an event is going to be sent. Think of it as a confirmation of the successful Favorite creation process. // somewhere in your code: favoriteCreatedEventListener(event) { // event.detail contains an object of the freshly-created Favorite console.log("Favorite created", event.detail) } document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.favorites.RAINBOW_ONFAVORITECREATED, favoriteCreatedEventListener) Deleting a Favorite Analogically, it is possible to delete a Favorite from the Favorites list by calling the favorites.deleteFavorite() method which accepts a Favorite ID string. It is asynchronous and it returns a Promise. var favorite = FavoriteObject; // Favorite Object // Delete a Favorite rainbowSDK.favorites.deleteFavorite(favorite.id) .then(// do something once the Favorite has been deleted) .catch(// do something in case of an error) Similarly to creating a Favorite, while deleting one, an event will be dispatched. It is a definite confirmation that a Favorite has been deleted. favoriteDeletedEventListener(event) { // event.detail contains an object of the freshly-created Favorite console.log("Favorite deleted", event.detail) } document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.favorites.RAINBOW_ONFAVORITEDELETED, favoriteDeletedEventListener) Last updated April, 30th 2019 On this pageManaging FavoritesRetrieving Favorites ListCreating a FavoriteDeleting a FavoriteWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationOAuth2 authenticationLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21OAuth Authentication This tutorial shows how you can use OAuth 2.0 authentication method in your application. Rainbow uses OAu
content: DocumentationOAuth2 authenticationLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21OAuth Authentication This tutorial shows how you can use OAuth 2.0 authentication method in your application. Rainbow uses OAuth 2.0 protocol to ensure authentication and authorization. One of the advantages of using OAuth 2.0 protocol is removing the responsibility for storing the user credentials from the third-party applications developers. Also, by outsourcing the authentication flow to Rainbow servers, the developers no longer need to maintain their own servers and ensure the application of numerous security measures. It also provides a set of advantages for the users who want to restrict the usage of their personal data linked to a Rainbow account. With OAuth 2.0 the users can also limit or even revoke the access of the third-party applications to their data. The main principle of OAuth 2.0 protocol is to separate the role of the client from that of the resource owner (Rainbow). Basic Concepts The basic idea behind the OAuth 2.0 is to ensure a protocol flow between the three (optionally four) principal roles explained in the context of Rainbow flow below: Resource owner - user providing an access to his data (protected resource) Resource server - Rainbow server hosting the protected resources Client - Third-party application trying to access resources on behalf of the Resource Owner Authorization server - Server which sends the authorization token to the Resource server Currently Rainbow Web SDK supports the so called Implicit flow which facilitates the authentication process for Single Page Applications written in JavaScript (or one of its frameworks). It excludes the necessity of involving an Authorization Server in the process. However, this approach has some limitations: the token is valid for only one hour. After that time it is required for user to run the sign in procedure again. Access token Access token is a string issued by Resource server (Rainbow server) to the Client (third-party application). It represents the authorization to access Resources. The end goal of the quite complicated OAuth 2.0 protocol process is to issue the token to the client and ensure secure access to the user data. Token replaces username and password by providing and abstraction layer. Therefore, once obtained, Access Token relieve the third-party applications from a duty of securing and keeping user data. Access token is a simplification of the idea of authentication, as it is represented by a single string understood by the Resource server. Requirements In order to use the benefits of OAuth 2.0 protocol in your application using Rainbow Web SDK, you need to follow the process of creating an application in our Rainbow for Developers. You will need two basic pieces of information: Application ID - ID of the application generated by Rainbow for Developers. Redirect URI - a URI of your choice that the user will be redirected to after giving a consent for your application to use his protected resources You can set Redirect URI either via Rainbow for Developers or Rainbow CLI. It is extremely important for the functioning of your application as our server will verify it each time a user will try to connect to Rainbow through your application. It is also the first and foremost layer of security granted by the Implicit flow. To set a redirect_uri attribute and assign it to your application, use rainbow-cli tool: rbw application set-redirecturi YOURAPPID YOURREDIRECTURI For more information on the application lifecycle, you can read the tutorial Application lifecycle. Implicit flow OAuth's implicit flow assumes that the Resource server can provide the protected resource based only on the Application ID. In order to use the implicit flow, you need to fully agree to all the security levels it proposes (see the part about security). To do so, go to rainbow-cli tool and run the following command in your shell: rbw application set-implicitgrant YOURAPPID You can revoke your application's authorization to use implicit flow by running the following command: rbw application unset-implicitgrant YOURAPPID To obtain the Authentication Token via the Implicit Flow, follow the steps below: Direct user to Rainbow authorization URL Your first action is to redirect a user to the Rainbow authorization page. In order to do so, you will need to build the redirect link that will consist of few mandatory parts: Rainbow Host URL - this parameter will always stay the same: https://RAINBOW_SERVER/api/rainbow/authentication/v1.0/oauth/authorize? Response type - parameter defining the type of response. As above, this part will stay the same in all of your requests: response_type=token Application ID - this is the part when you need to provide your application ID in the following format: &client_id=YOURAPPLICATIONID Redirect URI - another parameter that will define and protect your application (see previous step): &redirect_uri=https://YOURREDIRECTURI State - a random string ge

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationRetrieving calls historyLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Retrieving calls history In this tutorial, you will discover how to retrieve your call history. Each time you call a Rainbo
content: DocumentationRetrieving calls historyLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Retrieving calls history In this tutorial, you will discover how to retrieve your call history. Each time you call a Rainbow user using audio or video from your mobile application, your browser or when you call someone using your phone connected to a PBX, a call log entry is generated and added to your call history. This tutorial will help you understand how to deal with these information and manage your call history. Preamble The call history is not limited to audio and video calls done from Rainbow. Each time someone calls you on your phone associated to your Rainbow user or when you call someone with your phone device registered on Rainbow, a call log entry is generated and saved on Rainbow. The call history of the connected user will contain all these call log items. Each entry will contain the following structure: { contact: "318d07bcb19f449ba427b4672722b367@openrainbow.com", // User JID or phone number contactDisplayName: "Jon Smith", contactInitials: "JS", date: Thu Dec 07 2017 14:15:56 GMT+0100 (CET), direction: "incoming", // Or `outgoing` duration: "30m 45s", // 0 for missed call id: "web_83b73bc4-c22d-44ac-9c49-b83558231549", read: true, // false if new (not marked as read) state: "answered", // Or `missed` type: "webrtc" // or `telephone` } Here are some information regarding the parameters in that structure: Regarding the property contact, if the recipient is a Rainbow user, this property will contain the JID information. So using this information you are able to find the associated Rainbow contact information. If the recipient is not a Rainbow user, you can have only a phone number. Regarding the property read. Its value equals to false if it is a new entry that has not been marked as read. Regarding the property state. Its value equals to answered if the call has been established or would be set to missed otherwise. Regarding the property type. Its value equals to webrtc if the call has been done with the computer or the mobile using the WebRTC technology or telephone otherwise (for a PSTN call). Regarding the property direction. Its value equals to incoming when this is a call from a recipient to the connected user or outgoing when the call has been established by the connected user. Retrieving the call history Once the SDK for Web has started, you can retrieve the log history of the connected user by using the API getAll. This operation is not synchronous so to be sure that all the history has been received, you need to listen to the event RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED. Here is an example for retrieving the call history when started: var onCallLogUpdated = function onCallLogUpdated() { var logHistory = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll(); // Do something with the log history }; document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.callsLog.RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED, onCallLogUpdated) The API isInitialized() can be used to check if the initial log history has been retrieved from Rainbow. A true value returned means that the whole call log has been retrieved from Rainbow. Listening to new call history entry The same listener on RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGUPDATED can be used to listen to new call log entry. This new entry will be automatically added to the history. Calling the API Managing call history counter Generally speaking, when a call is missed a new call log entry is added to the history with the property read equals to false. So, when you need to know how many calls you missed, you can use the API getMissedCallLogCounter() such as in the following: var missedCallCounter = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getMissedCallLogCounter(); The variable missedCallCounter will be a number that represents the number of missed calls. And then, using the API getAll(), you will be able to retrieve these calls. In order to decrease this counter, you will have to mark these logs 'as read' (described in the next paragraph). Mark a call history entry as read To mark as read an existing missed call entry, you need to call the API markCallLogAsRead(). var onCallLogAckUpdated = function onCallLogAckUpdated() { //Do something when an acknowledgement has been done on the call history ... } var entry = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll()[0]; rainbowSDK.callsLog.markCallLogAsRead(entry.id); document.addEventListener(rainbowSDK.callsLog.RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGACKUPDATED, onCallLogAckUpdated) Once this has been done, a new event RAINBOW_ONCALLLOGACKUPDATED is fired to inform that at least an acknowledgement has been done on the call history. Calling the API getAll() will give you an update of the call history and the property read of the associated entry has changed to true. By calling the API getMissedCallLogCounter(), you should have a smaller result. Note: The API markAllCallsLogsAsRead() mark all missed call to read in one step. Deleting call history items You can delete a call history item at any time by calling the API deleteOneCallLog() var entry = rainbowSDK.callsLog.getAll()[0]; rainbowSDK.ca

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationSharing filesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Sharing files Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can share any kinds of files (Office documents, images, media, etc...) with a Rainbow
content: DocumentationSharing filesLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Sharing files Using the Rainbow SDK for Web, you can share any kinds of files (Office documents, images, media, etc...) with a Rainbow user or by sharing it within a bubble. This tutorial will explain how to use the FileStorage service for sharing files in Rainbow. Rainbow Knowledge Here are some Rainbow wordings that will help you understanding this guide. Rainbow conceptDetails Rainbow storageRainbow offers to each user a dedicated area where their files can be stored securely. QuotaEach user has a predefined files storage quota depending on his profile. Limits All files shared with others Rainbow users or within bubbles are stored on Rainbow until you decide to remove them. To avoid bad usages, we have introduced the limits To consult the exact limits concerning Rainbow Web SDK, visit this link Knowing the file sharing quota In order to know if you can share a new file, you can call the method getUserQuotaConsumption() rainbowSDK.fileStorage.getUserQuotaConsumption().then(function(quota) { // Do something with the quota }).catch(function(err) { // DO something if there is an error getting the quota }); The quota is a JavaScript Object containing the following properties: { "feature": "FILE_SHARING_QUOTA_GB", // Quota associated to the feature File Sharing "currentValue": 120439, // Current total size of files uploaded "maxValue": 1073741824, // Maximum of size allowed "unit": "octet" // Unit used } Each time you share a file with a user or within a bubble or when you remove a file from Rainbow, you can ask the method getUserQuotaConsumption() to have an update. Sharing a file with a Rainbow user When in a conversation with a Rainbow user, you can share a file by calling the method uploadFileToConversation(). If you get the file from the FileChooser or if you construct yourself the File object from a Blob, you can upload it as follow let contactIdToSearch = "..."; let blob = new Blob(["body { background-color: yellow; }"], { type: "text/css" }); let file = new File([blob], "style.css"); // Retrieve a contact by its id rainbowSDK.contacts.searchById(contactIdToSearch) .then(function(contact) { // Retrieve the associated conversation return rainbowSDK.conversations.openConversationForContact(contact); }).then(function(conversation) { // Share the file return rainbowSDK.fileStorage.uploadFileToConversation(conversation, file, "My file style"); }).then(function(message) { // Do something once the file has been shared }).catch(function(err) { // Do something in case of error }); Blob object can't be used directly. You need to convert it to a File as shown in the previous sample. Uploading a local file If you want to upload a local file from your computer, here is how to do it. First, create an input element of type file in your DOM: <input type="file" id="fileUpload"></input> Then handle the change event that will occur on the element above: /* Somewhere in your code */ let file; let inputElement = document.getElementById("fileUpload"); inputElement.addEventListener("change", handleFiles, false); function handleFiles() { console.log('A file has been chosen') file = inputElement.files[0]; } Once you retrieve your file element, you can inject it into Rainbow Web SDK method as in the following example: var contactIdToSearch = "..."; // Retrieve a contact by its id rainbowSDK.contacts.searchById(contactIdToSearch) .then(function(contact) { // Retrieve the associated conversation return rainbowSDK.conversations.openConversationForContact(contact); }).then(function(conversation) { // Share the file // Please note that "file" below represents a file that we have assigned to a "file" variable above return rainbowSDK.fileStorage.uploadFileToConversation(conversation, file, "My message "); }).then(function(message) { // Do something once the file has been shared }).catch(function(err) { // Do something in case of error }); When you share a file, you will get in return the Message object exchanged with your recipient as for sending a chat message. In this JavaScript object, the property fileId contains the id of the file that can be used to get the description of the file shared: { "filename": "myFile.png", // The file name and extension "filesize": 120439, // The file size "mime": "image/png", // The mime type of the file "url": "https://...5256345rdada" // The URL of the file } Sharing a file within a Bubble Sharing a file within a Bubble can be done as simply as with a contact by calling the method uploadFileToBubble(). You can use either a path to your file as in the following sample or a File object. var bubbleId = "..."; var file = { /* Your file object that you have retrieved as above */ } // Retrieve the bubble var bubble = rainbowSDK.bubbles.getBubbleById(bubbleId); rainbowSDK.fileStorage.uploadFileToBubble(bubble, file, "My message "); }).then(function(message) { // Do something once the file has been shared }).catch(function(err) { // Do somehti

content: DocumentationSupported BrowsersLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Supported Browsers Rainbow Web SDK is supported on all the major browser engines: Google Chrome and Chromium-based browsers like Opera, Brave, Edge (version 56 and higher) Firefox (version 58 and higher) Edge (non-chromium, version 15 and higher) It is strongly recommended to update the browser version to the latest official release. Rainbow team provides support for most of the SDK features. It is best, though, to update to the latest Firefox and Chromium-based browser versions in order to ensure full WebRTC support. title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationSupporting IE11LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Supporting IE11 UPDATE OCTOBER 2019: Rainbow Web SDK does not currently support Internet Explorer 11. It is however possible to deve
content: DocumentationSupporting IE11LTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Supporting IE11 UPDATE OCTOBER 2019: Rainbow Web SDK does not currently support Internet Explorer 11. It is however possible to develop a special version depending on the needs of your project. Please contact your Rainbow representative in order to discuss the details. The details below represent a helpful hints on how to provide the absolute minimum to ensure Internet Explorer 11 capabilities to run special Rainbow Web SDK version tailored for your needs. Adding ES6 compatibility Internet Explorer 11 doesn't support recent standardized specification released in ECMAScript 6 (ECMAScript 2015) like JavaScript Promise implementation, Array advanced methods etc. Consequently, the Rainbow Web application is not compliant with that browser. Regarding the SDK for Web, the compatibility can be provided by adding some extra libraries (aka ECMAScript shim) in your HTML file that are loaded before the SDK for Web. You need to add the following lines in your HTML file: <!-- Add the following lines to your 'index.html' file --> <!DOCTYPE HTML> <html lang="en" ng-controller="sampleController"> <head> <script src="//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/es5-shim/4.5.9/es5-shim.min.js"></script> <script src="//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/es6-promise/4.0.5/es6-promise.min.js"></script> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/promise-polyfill@8/dist/polyfill.min.js"></script> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/string.prototype.startswith@0.2.0/startswith.min.js"></script> <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/jspolyfill-array.prototype.findIndex@0.1.0/findIndex.js"></script> <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/babel-core/5.6.15/browser-polyfill.min.js"></script> </head> </html> Here's an explanation of what those libraries actually do: es5-shim and es6-shim will provide the compatibility with the Internet Explorer 11 by offering all the missing JavaScript features. polyfill for adding Promise polyfill startswith is needed to provide String.prototype.startsWith (if needed) findIndex is needed to provide Array.prototype.findIndex (if needed) Feel free to use your own shim/polyfill if your project needs them. Example for sending a file, for example in a Bubble, thanks to Esben from the Forum As IE11 doesn't support File creator (see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File) an existing way is to use a XMLHttpRequest() to download it function blobToFile(theBlob, fileName) { //A Blob() is almost a File() - it's just missing the two properties below which we will add theBlob.lastModifiedDate = newDate(); theBlob.name = fileName; return theBlob; } function insertImageInBubble(ownedBubble) { var xhr = new XMLHttpRequest(); xhr.open("GET", "https://url.to/image.jpg"); xhr.overrideMimeType("image/jpeg"); xhr.responseType = "blob"; //force the HTTP response, response-type header to be blob xhr.onload = function () { var myFile = blobToFile(xhr.response, "image.jpg"); rainbowSDK.fileStorage.uploadFileToBubble(ownedBubble, myFile, "Demo image"); } xhr.send(); }; WebRTC audio and video limitation When using Internet Explorer 11, you can't access to Rainbow audio and video services based on WebRTC. When calling these methods from the Rainbow SDK for Web, you will receive a JSON error message explaining that this feature is not supported by your browser. Here is the list of methods not supported on IE 11: WebRTCService: callInAudio() WebRTCService: callInVideo() WebRTCService: answerInAudio() WebRTCService: answerInVideo() WebRTCService: showLocalVideo() WebRTCService: hideLocalVideo() WebRTCService: showRemoteVideo() WebRTCService: hideRemoteVideo() WebRTCService: escaladeToVideoCall() WebRTCService: reverseToAudioCall() WebRTCService: muteAudioCall() WebRTCService: muteVideoCall() WebRTCService: unmuteAudioCall() WebRTCService: unmuteVideoCall() Last updated October, 23rd 2019 On this pageSupporting IE11Adding ES6 compatibilityExample for sending a file, for example in a Bubble, thanks to Esben from the ForumWebRTC audio and video limitationWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationUsing ConfigLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Using Config Rainbow Web SDK configuration allows the developers to provide a more fine-grained experience to their users. It is also e
content: DocumentationUsing ConfigLTS release 4.0.0Published on 2022-12-21Using Config Rainbow Web SDK configuration allows the developers to provide a more fine-grained experience to their users. It is also enabling the customization of the project that uses the SDK. This article covers two basic ways of Rainbow Web SDK configuration Method 1: Config File While loading the SDK, you can pass a JavaScript object as an argument. Here's a quick snippet demonstrating the usage of the config object: const rainbowConfig = { verboseLog: false, // Turn on/off all the logs linked to the SDK measurePerformance: false, // Add performance measurement points while loading the SDK videoQuality: "1080p", // Chose default broadcasted video quality credentials: { appID: "", appSecret: "", host: "openrainbow.com" }, // use the credentials logs: { // use fine-grained logs control (verboseLog needs to be true) contactService: true, // set to false to block all contactService logs xmppMessages: true, // set to false to block all XMPP messages xmppService: true, // set to false to block xmppService logs conversationService: true, // set to false to block conversationService logs presence: true, // set to false to block presence logs } } rainbowSDK.load(rainbowConfig); The presented structure of rainbowConfig object above is loaded by the SDK by default. If you want to keep all the properties as they are, but change one - for instance verboseLog - you can just mention only verboseLog in the config object: const rainbowConfig = { verboseLog: true } rainbowSDK.load(rainbowConfig); Method 2: Config Service You can also use ConfigService provided by Rainbow Web SDK, please have a look at the documentation of the service to find out what APIs are available with more details on the implementation. Last updated March, 8th 2021 On this pageUsing ConfigMethod 1: Config FileMethod 2: Config ServiceWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: Rainbow SDK for Web (2nd edition)The perfect choice for your web site or web applicationReady to get started with Rainbow SDK for Web?Everything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for WebFirst s
content: Rainbow SDK for Web (2nd edition)The perfect choice for your web site or web applicationReady to get started with Rainbow SDK for Web?Everything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for WebFirst steps with Webv2 SDKDownload Webv2 SDKUseful informationVersion: LTS 5.0.0Published: 22 juin 2024Last Updated: 21 juin 2024Consult the changelogToggle to STS documentationEasily integrated into your websiteThe Rainbow SDK for Web is easily integrated into any web site or web application just by adding a few lines of code. Once done, your web site or application will be connected to Rainbow and able to use every available Rainbow service.Any browserAny device or OSAny JS FrameworkOffers a friendly debug consoleA fully documented Web SDKThe Rainbow SDK for Web provides you the best API for connecting to Rainbow and integrating with your site. These API have been carefully developed and are well-documented with the necessary details to help you to build your application.Complete collaborative featuresThe Rainbow SDK for Web provides the services you need to build a complete social network. Make your site a relationship machine. Chat or share files with a single recipient or to a group. Have an audio call with someone, enhance it by adding video. Rainbow makes it possible!SDK for Web at a glance.Learn about the main APIs provided by this SDKSimple JS libraryLoad the JavaScript Rainbow SDK from your web site or application and use it in some lines of code. It is compliant with the main JavaScript frameworks such as React, Angular and JQuery.Contacts, search and presence APIHandle your contact list and know when they are available, busy on the phone or away. Search for users by name or id to extend your network.One-to-one Chat APIExchange messages with your contacts. Be alerted when contacts send you a message. You can retrieve the whole conversation or only the most recent messages.Bubbles groupchat APICreate and invite users, or reuse your bubbles for talking together. In a bubble, everyone can participate to the conversation.WebRTC audio and video APIYou can initiate audio and video calls to your contacts using your browser without a plug-in. Enhance your call from audio only to video. Choose which device you want to use and control the call (mute/unmute).WebRTC Conference APIYou can join a conference in a bubble. Control the video you want to see and control your device (mute/unmute).Channels APISend messages to channels which may have more than thousands suscribers. Subscribe to users public channels to follow them and receive what they publish!Interesting linksLearn how to use our SDKsNeed some help?Contact our support teamVisit our homepageFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationBubbleLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / Bubble Interface: Bubble Properties autoAcceptInvitation readonly autoAcceptInvitation: boolean When set to true, allows to automatically add participants in the bubble (default behavior is that participants need to accept the bubble invitation first before being a member of this bubble) avatar readonly avatar: string The bubble avatar avatarContacts readonly avatarContacts: any[] The avatar of each participants of the bubble containerId readonly containerId: string ID of container this bubble belongs to creationDate? optional readonly creationDate: Date The creation date of the bubble customData readonly customData: any Custom data associated to the bubble dbId readonly dbId: string The bubble database Identifier guestPhoneNumbers readonly guestPhoneNumbers: string[] List of guest phonenumbers history readonly history: string Allow newcomers to access or not messages history. If the value is "all", a newcomer can retrieve the full bubble messages history isActive readonly isActive: boolean True if the bubble is actived isAlertNotificationEnabled isAlertNotificationEnabled: boolean If the bubble has alert notification feature enabled isModerator readonly isModerator: boolean True if the bubble is moderated by the connected user isOwnedByGroup isOwnedByGroup: boolean If the bubble is created as part of Rainbow Voice Hunting group jid readonly jid: string The jid associated to this bubble lastActivityDate? optional readonly lastActivityDate: Date last activity date of bubble members readonly members: BubbleUser[] The members of the bubble name readonly name: string The name of the bubble nameForLogs readonly nameForLogs: string The name used in logs of the bubble organizers readonly organizers: BubbleUser[] The organizers of the bubble owner readonly owner: boolean True if the bubble is owned by the connected user ownerContact readonly ownerContact: any The owner of the bubble rxSubject readonly rxSubject: Subject<any> Observable subject for bubble status readonly status: BubbleUserStatus The status of the connected user in the bubble ('invited', 'accepted', 'unsubscribed', 'rejected' or 'deleted') tags readonly tags: any[] Tags describing the bubble topic readonly topic: string The topic of the bubble type readonly type: string The type of the bubble users readonly users: BubbleUser[] The list of users of the bubble (invited, joined and removed) usersReady readonly usersReady: BehaviorSubject<boolean> True when all bubble users have been retreived Methods acceptInvitation() acceptInvitation(): Promise<Bubble> Accept invitation to join a bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> addRainbowTVs() addRainbowTVs(androidTVs): Promise<Bubble> Add rainbow TVs to the bubble; Parameters • androidTVs: User[] users from type Rainbow TV Returns Promise<Bubble> addUser() addUser(user, privilege?, reason?, withoutInvitation?): Promise<Bubble> Add user to the bubble; Can be used to directly add user without invitation or as a moderator Parameters • user: User The user to add in the bubble • privilege?: BubbleUserPrivilege The user privilege in this bubble ('user', 'moderator' or 'guest'), by default is 'user' • reason?: string Text that will be join in the invitation • withoutInvitation?: boolean When set to true no invitation is sent Returns Promise<Bubble> changeOwner() changeOwner(newOwner): Promise<Bubble> Change the owner of the bubble Parameters • newOwner: User The user that should be the new owner Returns Promise<Bubble> createBubbleLink() createBubbleLink(): Promise<string> Method to create bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<string> declineInvitation() declineInvitation(): Promise<Bubble> Decline invitation to join a bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> delete() delete(createArchive?): Promise<Bubble> Delete own bubble. If createArchive is TRUE, the bubble will be archived, i.e. all users can only read the content that's already in the bubble, but no further action can be done inside the bubble All participants in the bubble will go to UNSUBSCRIBED state (read-only) Parameters • createArchive?: boolean If TRUE, the bubble will be archived for all users (i.e. read only mode for all users still inside); Returns Promise<Bubble> deleteBubbleLink() deleteBubbleLink(): Promise<void> Method to delete bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<void> getAllAcceptedUsers() getAllAcceptedUsers(): BubbleUser[] Method to retrieve all users of the bubble that have accepted Returns BubbleUser[] getAutoAcceptInvitation() getAutoAcceptInvitation(): boolean Method to retrieve autoAcceptInvitation status Returns boolean getAutoRegister() getAutoRegister(): string Method to retrieve auto register status Returns string getBubbleLink() getBubbleLink(): Promise<string> Method to get bubble "guest" access code Returns Promise<string> getDialInCode() getDialInCode(): string Method to retrieve conference.dialInCode code Returns string getDisableTime

content: DocumentationBubbleServiceLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / BubbleService Interface: BubbleService The BubbleService interface defines the Rainbow SDK BubbleService API Methods createBubble() createBubble(bubbleName, createBubbleData?): Promise<Bubble> Create a new bubble; This API also sends BubbleServiceEvents.ON_NEW_BUBBLE_CREATED event Parameters • bubbleName: string The name of the bubble • createBubbleData?: CreateBubbleData The name of the bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> demoteAllUsers() demoteAllUsers(bubble): Promise<Bubble> Demote all moderators to Users role. API available only for the owner of the bubble Parameters • bubble: Bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> getAllServerBubbles() getAllServerBubbles(status): Promise<void> Load all bubble from server in a given status Parameters • status: string values: 'invited', 'accepted','unsubscribed' Returns Promise<void> getBubble() getBubble(bubbleRef): Promise<Bubble> Async method -which get get a bubble. The bubble is first search in service cache then server side. Parameters • bubbleRef: string The bubble dbId or bubble JID Returns Promise<Bubble> getBubbleFromCache() getBubbleFromCache(id): Bubble Synchronous method used to get a existing bubble from the cache Parameters • id: string Should be the bubble id or dbId Returns Bubble getBubbleInvitations() getBubbleInvitations(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles where user is currently invited to participants (in "invited" state) Returns Bubble[] getBubbles() getBubbles(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles already in the cache Returns Bubble[] getBubblesWithActiveConference() getBubblesWithActiveConference(): Bubble[] Return an array of all bubbles with an active conference at the moment Returns Bubble[] getMyBubbles() getMyBubbles(): Bubble[] Return an array of all MY bubbles Returns Bubble[] isStarted() isStarted(): boolean Return the service start state Returns boolean promoteAllUsers() promoteAllUsers(bubble): Promise<Bubble> Promote all users to Moderator role. API available only for the owner of the bubble Parameters • bubble: Bubble Returns Promise<Bubble> searchBubbles() searchBubbles(searchPattern, options?): Promise<BubbleSearchResult[]> This API allows to search Rainbow bubbles that match a search criteria applied on some name properties such as the name of the bubble or the names of bubble participants for example. One or more name properties can be optionally specified to define the scope of the search. If no scope is specified, the search is performed by default on the name of the bubble only. It is also possible to optionally specify how the list of bubbles returned as results should be sorted. By default, the bubbles list will be sorted by bubble name. Parameters • searchPattern: string The search criteria • options?: SearchBubblesOptions Options to specify the scope of the search and how the results are to be returned. Returns Promise<BubbleSearchResult[]> subscribe() subscribe(handler, eventNames?): Subscription Subscribe to the invitations updates; All events send to the callback are of type RBEvent Parameters • handler • eventNames?: BubbleServiceEvents | BubbleServiceEvents[] Returns Subscription On this pageMethodscreateBubble()ParametersReturnsdemoteAllUsers()ParametersReturnsgetAllServerBubbles()ParametersReturnsgetBubble()ParametersReturnsgetBubbleFromCache()ParametersReturnsgetBubbleInvitations()ReturnsgetBubbles()ReturnsgetBubblesWithActiveConference()ReturnsgetMyBubbles()ReturnsisStarted()ReturnspromoteAllUsers()ParametersReturnssearchBubbles()ParametersReturnssubscribe()ParametersReturnsWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationBubbleSettingsLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / BubbleSettings Interface: BubbleSettings This interface defines the settings that can be send to the updateSettings bubble API Properties autoAcceptInvitation? optional autoAcceptInvitation: boolean Invited users will be auto-added in the bubble autoRegister? optional autoRegister: string A user can create a bubble and not have to register users. He can share instead a public link also called 'public URL'(users public link). According with autoRegister value, if another person uses the link to join the bubble: autoRegister = 'unlock': If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he is automatically included with the status 'accepted' and join the bubble. autoRegister = 'lock': If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he can't access to the bubble. So that he can't join the bubble. autoRegister = 'unlock_ack' (value not authorized yet): If this user is not yet registered inside this bubble, he can't access to the bubble waiting for the bubble's owner acknowledgment. disableTimeStats? optional disableTimeStats: boolean if TRUE, in case of conference in this bubble/bubble, the talking time stats will be disabled includeAllPhoneNumbers? optional includeAllPhoneNumbers: boolean Indicates if user chooses to include all Dial In phone numbers muteUponEntry? optional muteUponEntry: boolean In case of conference in this bubble/bubble, all participants will be muted upon join name? optional name: string Avatar image for the bubble playEntryTone? optional playEntryTone: boolean In case of conference in this bubble/bubble, a local tone should be played when user joins. topic? optional topic: string The bubble description On this pagePropertiesautoAcceptInvitation?autoRegister?disableTimeStats?includeAllPhoneNumbers?muteUponEntry?name?playEntryTone?topic?Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationCreateBubbleDataLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Bubbles / CreateBubbleData Interface: CreateBubbleData The CreateBubbleData interface describes the data that can be send to the create bubble API Example const data = { "topic": "my bubble topic", "createConversation": true, "autoAcceptInvitation": true } createBubble("my bubble name", data); Properties autoAcceptInvitation? optional autoAcceptInvitation: boolean When set to true, allows to automatically add participants in the bubble (default behavior is that participants need to accept the bubble invitation first before being a member of this bubble) Default : FALSE bubbleAvatar? optional bubbleAvatar: any Avatar image for the bubble contacts? optional contacts: Contact[] List of contacts that we want to invite to the bubble disableTimeStats? optional disableTimeStats: boolean If TRUE, in case of conference in this bubble the talking time stats will be disabled Default : FALSE guestEmails? optional guestEmails: string[] List of emails that we want to invite to the bubble (will receive an invitation email) muteUponEntry? optional muteUponEntry: boolean In case of conference in this bubble, all participants will be muted upon join Default : FALSE noConversation? optional noConversation: boolean If TRUE, the server will NOT create a conversation for this bubble Default : FALSE noEntryTone? optional noEntryTone: boolean In case of conference in this bubble, a local tone should be played when user joins. Default : TRUE noHistory? optional noHistory: boolean If TRUE, the old history will NOT be shown to new users Default : FALSE privilege? optional privilege: BubbleUserPrivilege Add optional body parameter privilege ('user', 'moderator'). By default, all users get the simple 'user' privilege. Using 'privilege' parameter all invited users may have the same privilege in this bulk. topic? optional topic: string The bubble description On this pageExamplePropertiesautoAcceptInvitation?bubbleAvatar?contacts?disableTimeStats?guestEmails?muteUponEntry?noConversation?noEntryTone?noHistory?privilege?topic?Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationCallLogServiceEventsLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogServiceEvents Enumeration: CallLogServiceEvents CallLog service events send t
content: DocumentationCallLogServiceEventsLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogServiceEvents Enumeration: CallLogServiceEvents CallLog service events send to other services Can listen to it via CallLogService.subscribe() API Events ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_MISSEDCALLS_COUNTER_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the counter of missed calls has been updated. Event Data counter - The number of missed calls ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_TOTAL_NUMBER_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the total number of call logs for the connected user has been updated. Event Data counter - The total number of call logs ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED: "ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the call log history has been updated in one of the following ways: Reception of a new call log from the server (in the form of a notification, and not in response to an explicit fetch request). User request to delete call logs. This covers cases of deletion of a specific call log, all call logs associated with a user, or the user's entire call log history. This event contains no data, the current call logs history have to be retrieved by using the getCallLogs() API. content: DocumentationCallLogTypeLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogType Enumeration: CallLogType Call type Enumeration Members CONFERENCE CONFERENCE: "conference" A call is considered a "conference" when it involves more than 2 participants. TELEPHONE TELEPHONE: "telephone" A call is considered "telephonic" when the party initiating the call has explicitly used a number (by dialing or selecting it) to reach the other party. WEBRTC WEBRTC: "webrtc" A call is considered "webrtc" when it initiated between 2 users using a Rainbow client (Web, Desktop or Mobile) A "webrtc" call can be considered as an Internet call. content: DocumentationCallLogLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLog Interface: CallLog Properties callSubject? optional readonly callSubject: string The subject of the call calledNumber readonly calledNumber: string The number of the called party date readonly date: Date The date of the call direction readonly direction: CallDirection The call direction duration readonly duration: number The call duration in milliseconds id readonly id: string The unique identifier of the call log read readonly read: boolean The reading status, indicates if the call log has been marked as read or not. state readonly state: string The call state: "answered": Refers to an answered call with a conversation established and this, regardless of direction (Incoming or outgoing). "missed": Refers to an unanswered call, regardless of direction (Incoming or outgoing). "forwarded": Refers to an incoming call which has been forwarded to the connected user (who was not the initial destination). type readonly type: CallLogType The call type user readonly user: User The associated user representing the other party (as caller or callee) of the call userCallbackNumber? optional readonly userCallbackNumber: string The number used to call back a Rainbow user if this one has not shared the private profile fields, including their telephone numbers. As a result, there is no telephone number visible (so usable) in the user's associated contact object. This number has been received as call information and is linked to the current call log only. excerpt: DocumentationCallLogServiceLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogService Interface: CallLogService Methods deleteAllCallLogs() deleteAllCallLogs():
content: DocumentationCallLogServiceLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / CallLog / CallLogService Interface: CallLogService Methods deleteAllCallLogs() deleteAllCallLogs(): Promise<any> Delete all the call logs history of the connected user A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Returns Promise<any> deleteCallLog() deleteCallLog(callLog): Promise<any> Delete the call log specified by its object instance A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Parameters • callLog: CallLog The call log instance to delete Returns Promise<any> deleteCallLogsForUser() deleteCallLogsForUser(user): Promise<any> Delete all call logs associated with a user A ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED event is sent afterwards at the completion of the operation to notify about the call logs history update. Parameters • user: User Returns Promise<any> getCallLogs() getCallLogs(): Promise<CallLog[]> Get the current content of the call logs history. The request can be made at any time to retrieve the call logs already known by the Call Log service. It is also advisable to make this request when an 'ON_CALLLOG_UPDATED' event has been received notifying you that the call logs history has been updated following an operation such as the reception of a brand new call log, the modification (e.g., marking as read) or the deletion of existing call log(s). Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the call logs already known by the Call Log service getCallLogsCounter() getCallLogsCounter(): number Return the number total of call logs available for the connected user Returns number getMissedCallsCounter() getMissedCallsCounter(): number Returns the number total of missed calls. Missed call is a call with the following properties: state is 'missed', direction is 'incoming' and read flag is 'false'. This API can be called before the first call logs are retrieved, i.e. before the initialization step. Returns number getNextCallLogs() getNextCallLogs(number): Promise<CallLog[]> Get additional call logs. The number of additional call logs to be returned can be specified in the request Parameters • number: number (optional) Number of additional call logs to get. This parameter is optional and set by default to 100. The allowed range of values is [1..250]. If the value provided is greater, the maximum value will be used. If the value is 0 or less, the request will be rejected and an error thrown. Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the call logs already known by the Call Log service and the newly retrieved. Throws Error - In the event of the specified parameter is invalid. initCallLogs() initCallLogs(number): Promise<CallLog[]> Initializes the CallLog service for the user by returning the most recent call logs. The number of call logs to be returned can optionnaly be specified in the request Additional call logs have to be retrieved furthermore via the API 'getNextCallLogs'. Parameters • number: number (optional) Number of call logs to retrieve at initialization step. This parameter is optional and set by default to 100. The allowed range of values is [1..250]. If the value provided is greater, the maximum value will be used. If the value is 0 or less, the request will be rejected and an error thrown. Returns Promise<CallLog[]> Returns a Promise with an array of the first retrieved call logs Throws Error - In the event of the specified parameter is invalid. isInitialized() isInitialized(): boolean Indicates whether the CallLog Service has been initialized or not. If this is not the case, no call log has yet been retrieved. Returns boolean True if the CallLog Service has been intitialized; False otherwise. markAllCallsLogsAsRead() markAllCallsLogsAsRead(): void Mark all call logs already known by the Call Log service as read This concerns the call logs fetched from server during the initialization step and through additional fetch requests. Returns void markCallLogAsRead() markCallLogAsRead(callLog): void Mark a call log item specified by its object instance as read Parameters • callLog: CallLog The call log instance to mark as read Returns void subscribe() subscribe(callback, eventNames?): Subscription Subscribe to the CallLog updates, all events are of RBEvent Parameters • callback The callback function that will be called when events are received • eventNames?: CallLogServiceEvents | CallLogServiceEvents[] (optional) array of event to listen Returns Subscription Returns RxJS Subscription On this pageMethodsdeleteAllCallLogs()ReturnsdeleteCallLog()ParametersReturnsdeleteCallLogsForUser()ParametersReturnsgetCallLogs()ReturnsgetCallLogsCounter()ReturnsgetMissedCallsCounter()ReturnsgetNextCallLogs()ParametersReturnsThrowsinitCallLogs()ParametersReturnsThrowsisInitialized()ReturnsmarkAllCallsLogsAsRead()ReturnsmarkCallLogAsRead()Paramete

UNDEFINED UNDEFINED: "" Default initial value. excerpt: DocumentationCallEventsLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallEvents Enumeration: CallEvents Call events send to other services Can listen to it via Call.
content: DocumentationCallEventsLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallEvents Enumeration: CallEvents Call events send to other services Can listen to it via Call.subscribe() API. Events ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED: "ON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when the call capabilities have been updated. The new call capabilities can be retrieved via the 'capabilities' property. ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED: "ON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATED" This RBEvent is sent when there have been changes in the media used by the local or the remote user. By change we mean the addition or removal of a media (Video/Sharing) for the current call. ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when the status of the mute of the call (On or Off) has changed. The new mute status can be retrieved via the 'isMuted' property. ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when during a call, the network quality has changed. Event Data data - The current network quality for the call ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE: "ON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGE" This RBEvent is sent when the status of the call (from a telephone point of view) has changed. The new call status can be retrieved via the 'callStatus' property. ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT: "ON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENT" This RBEvent is sent when when the call has evolved and as a result some of its properties, such as its status, have been updated. On this pageEventsON_CALL_CAPABILITIES_UPDATEDON_CALL_MEDIA_UPDATEDON_CALL_MUTE_CHANGEON_CALL_NETWORK_QUALITY_CHANGEEvent DataON_CALL_STATUS_CHANGEON_CALL_UPDATED_EVENTWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationCallStatusLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallStatus Enumeration: CallStatus The possible status of the call (e.g. dialing, active, releasing...) Enumeration Members ACTIVE ACTIVE: "ACTIVE" Active call ANSWERING ANSWERING: "ANSWERING" Call is being answered CONNECTING CONNECTING: "CONNECTING" Trying to connect / reconnect the call DIALING DIALING: "DIALING" In dialing ENDED ENDED: "ENDED" Call Cleared ERROR ERROR: "ERROR" Call error HOLD HOLD: "HOLD" Call on hold by local party PUT_ON_HOLD PUT_ON_HOLD: "PUT_ON_HOLD" Call put on hold by the distant party QUEUED_INCOMMING QUEUED_INCOMMING: "QUEUED_INCOMMING" In queue (user side) QUEUED_OUTGOING QUEUED_OUTGOING: "QUEUED_OUTGOING" In queue (recipient side) RELEASING RELEASING: "RELEASING" Call is clearing RINGING_INCOMMING RINGING_INCOMMING: "RINGING_INCOMMING" Call in ringing (user side) RINGING_OUTGOING RINGING_OUTGOING: "RINGING_OUTGOING" Call in ringing (recipient side) On this pageEnumeration MembersACTIVEANSWERINGCONNECTINGDIALINGENDEDERRORHOLDPUT_ON_HOLDQUEUED_INCOMMINGQUEUED_OUTGOINGRELEASINGRINGING_INCOMMINGRINGING_OUTGOINGWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationCallLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / Call Interface: Call Properties callStatus readonly callStatus: CallStatus Call telephone status capab
content: DocumentationCallLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / Call Interface: Call Properties callStatus readonly callStatus: CallStatus Call telephone status capabilities readonly capabilities: CallCapabilities Capabilities of the call contact readonly contact: User The user reference representing the other party (as caller or callee) engaged in this call direction direction: CallDirection Call direction This information is relevant only for telephone (PBX) call. For WebRTC call it is undefined. duration readonly duration: number Call duration in seconds localMedias readonly localMedias: CallMediaStreams The local medias currently in the call networkQuality readonly networkQuality: number The current network quality (0 - bad, 1 - medium, 2 - good) for the call remoteMedias readonly remoteMedias: CallMediaStreams The remote medias currently in the call subject readonly subject: string On an incoming call, contains the subject of the call if this has been specified by the caller type readonly type: CallType The type of the call (WebRTC or Telephony) Methods addAudio() addAudio(): Promise<void> Add the AUDIO media to the current call. This feature can be used only if the "addAudio" call capability is 'True' and available only for WebRTC Calls. Returns Promise<void> addParticipantsToCall() addParticipantsToCall(participants): Promise<Conversation> Add participants to the the current call. This feature can be used only if the "addParticipantsToCall" call capability is 'True'. The participants could be other Rainbow users or phone numbers (if the PBX system supports it). This will result in a new conversation being created with web conference inside. The active call will be "transferred" to the bubble conference; Parameters • participants: CallDestination[] The list of participants to be added to the call Returns Promise<Conversation> The new bubble conversation where the web conference is active addSharing() addSharing(): Promise<void> Add the SHARING media to the current call. This feature can be used only if the "addSharing" call capability is 'True' and available only for WebRTC Calls. Returns Promise<void> addVideo() addVideo(): Promise<void> Add the VIDEO media to the current call. This feature can be used only if the "addVideo" call capability is 'True' and available only for WebRTC Calls. Returns Promise<void> answer() answer(withVideo?): Promise<void> Answer the current incoming call. This feature can be used only if the "answer" call capability is 'True'. By default, the answer is done with AUDIO only. If the 'withVideo' option is set to 'True' and the incoming call contains video, the answer will directly be done with audio and video. Parameters • withVideo?: boolean Option to answer the call directly with audio and video. Default value is 'False' Returns Promise<void> attachLocalSharingStream() attachLocalSharingStream(HtmlElementId): void Attach the local sharing stream to a given HTML VIDEO tag element; Parameters • HtmlElementId: string The ID of the HTML VIDEO tag element visible on the page Returns void attachLocalVideoStream() attachLocalVideoStream(HtmlElementId): void Attach the local video stream to a given HTML VIDEO tag element; Parameters • HtmlElementId: string The ID of the HTML VIDEO tag element visible on the page Returns void attachRemoteSharingStream() attachRemoteSharingStream(HtmlElementId): void Attach the remote sharing stream to a given HTML VIDEO tag element; Parameters • HtmlElementId: string The ID of the HTML VIDEO tag element visible on the page Returns void attachRemoteVideoStream() attachRemoteVideoStream(HtmlElementId): void Attach the remote video stream to a given HTML VIDEO tag element; Parameters • HtmlElementId: string The ID of the HTML VIDEO tag element visible on the page Returns void blindTransfer() blindTransfer(destination): Promise<void> Blind transfer the current call another destination which could be any rainbow user or phone number. A blind transfer is when you transfer a call directly to another party without consulting with the person receiving the call. In other words, there is no need to call the other party to make the transfer. This feature is available only if the connected user is behind a Rainbow Hub. Parameters • destination: CallDestination The destination of the blind transfer Returns Promise<void> deflectToPhoneNumber() deflectToPhoneNumber(number): Promise<void> Deflect (redirect) the current incoming call to the specified phone number. This feature can be used only if the "deflectToPhoneNumber" call capability is 'True'. The list of phone numbers where we can deflect the incoming call is available in the 'deflectPhoneNumberDestinations' call capability. Parameters • number: string The phone number the call will be deflected to. Returns Promise<void> deflectToVoicemail() deflectToVoicemail(): Promise<void> Deflect the current incoming call to the voice mail. This feature can be used only if the "deflectTo

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationCallCapabilitiesLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallCapabilities Interface: CallCapabilities Call capabilities representing all the action
content: DocumentationCallCapabilitiesLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallCapabilities Interface: CallCapabilities Call capabilities representing all the actions that could be done for the call given the state Properties addAudio readonly addAudio: boolean Indicates if we can add the audio media to the call. This could happen if there's no audio, for example in case of sharing only call. addParticipantsToCall readonly addParticipantsToCall: boolean Indicates if we can make a conference call from the current call by adding any other contact or number (that we dont have currently call with). This will remove the current call and create a web conference call instead. addSharing readonly addSharing: boolean Indicates if we can add the sharing media to the call. addVideo readonly addVideo: boolean Indicates if we can add the video media to the call. answer readonly answer: boolean Indicates if the incoming call can be answered. blindTransfer readonly blindTransfer: boolean Indicates if we can make a blind transfer of this call (transfer it to some other contact without having a call with them beforehand). This will remove the current call, and the other party will be transferred to the other contact / number. deflectPhoneNumberDestinations readonly deflectPhoneNumberDestinations: [Object?] The list of phone numbers where we can deflect the call deflectToPhoneNumber readonly deflectToPhoneNumber: boolean Indicates if we can deflect the incoming call to a phone number. The possible destinations numbers for call deflection are available in the 'deflectPhoneNumberDestinations' data. deflectToVoicemail readonly deflectToVoicemail: boolean Indicates if we can deflect the incoming call to the VoiceMail. Only available for HYBRID systems (for Cloud telephony, the release action will follow the system/user configuration) dtmf readonly dtmf: boolean Indicates if we can send dtmf for the call. hold readonly hold: boolean Indicates if we can put the call on hold. mergeCalls readonly mergeCalls: boolean Indicates if we can make a conference call from the current call and one other call in progress for the current user (can be used to merge the 2 calls). This will remove the 2 calls and create one single call (for hybride systems) or web conference. mute readonly mute: boolean Indicates if we can mute the call release readonly release: boolean Indicates if the call can be released / ended / declined. removeSharing readonly removeSharing: boolean Indicates if we can remove the sharing media from the call. removeVideo readonly removeVideo: boolean Indicates if we can remove the video media from the call. retrieve readonly retrieve: boolean Indicates if we can retrieve the call (if it is on hold). transferCallDestinations readonly transferCallDestinations: CallRB[] The list of calls where we can transfer this call; transferToOtherCall readonly transferToOtherCall: boolean Indicates if we can transfer the current call to the other call. If the call is on HOLD, then the tranfer is always made towards the ACTIVE call. Otherwise, we can transfer this call to any other call from the transferCallDestinations list. unmute readonly unmute: boolean Indicates if we can unmute the call On this pagePropertiesaddAudioaddParticipantsToCalladdSharingaddVideoanswerblindTransferdeflectPhoneNumberDestinationsdeflectToPhoneNumberdeflectToVoicemaildtmfholdmergeCallsmutereleaseremoveSharingremoveVideoretrievetransferCallDestinationstransferToOtherCallunmuteWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationCallDestinationLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallDestination Interface: CallDestination Data associated with the destination of a call.
content: DocumentationCallDestinationLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallDestination Interface: CallDestination Data associated with the destination of a call. Properties country? optional country: string Phone number country. This information is only relevant if the destination is external. If not indicated, the caller's country is taken into account. phoneNumber? optional phoneNumber: string Phone number to be used for the call destination. This can be a telephone number associated with the Rainbow user profile. Or in the case of an external destination, a public PSTN number. user? optional user: User Peer object related to the Call destination. If the call destination is a Rainbow user, the object is an instance of User. On this pagePropertiescountry?phoneNumber?user?Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationCallServiceLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallService Interface: CallService Description Call Service interface Methods makePhoneCall() m
content: DocumentationCallServiceLTS release 5.0.0Published on 2024-06-22Rainbow SDK • Docs Rainbow SDK / Calls / CallService Interface: CallService Description Call Service interface Methods makePhoneCall() makePhoneCall(number, user?, additionalData?): Promise<void> Make a PBX Phone call towards a number A new conversation will be created if not existing already (even if it's with an external number) Parameters • number: string The number we want to call; The format could be anything the user can type, it will be transformed in E164 format. • user?: User A user to whom this number belongs to (in case of Rainbow User) • additionalData?: PhoneCallAdditionalData An additional data that can be send during the make call Returns Promise<void> makeWebCall() makeWebCall(user, medias?, message?): Promise<void> Make a standard WebRTC call toward a Rainbow user. A new conversation with the user will be created if not existing already. Parameters • user: User The user we want to call • medias?: MediaType[] Array containing the media to be used when setting up the new call By default, only the AUDIO media type will be added to the new call. • message?: string A complementary message send to the remote party informing about the reason of the call Returns Promise<void> mergeCalls() mergeCalls(): Promise<Conversation> Merge the current 2 calls into one single. This feature can be used only if the "mergeCalls" call capability is 'True'. In case of standard HYBRID conference, the return value is null. A new telephony conference (conversation with "conference" call) will be created. Otherwise, the result will be a web conference (in the form of a Rainbow bubble) that will be created in a new bubble conversation. Returns Promise<Conversation> Bubble Conversation with active web conference or null in case of hybrid 3-party conference call. subscribe() subscribe(callback, eventNames?): Subscription Subscribe to updates from the call service, all events are of RBEvent Parameters • callback The callback function that will be called when events are received • eventNames?: CallServiceEvents | CallServiceEvents[] (optional) array of event to listen Returns Subscription Returns RxJS Subscription On this pageDescriptionMethodsmakePhoneCall()ParametersReturnsmakeWebCall()ParametersReturnsmergeCalls()Returnssubscribe()ParametersReturnsWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on
