title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationMessage ServiceMessage Services Preamble The message services module messagesService has all the methods supported by this library. Get All Messages To get all the messages that belong to
content: DocumentationMessage ServiceMessage Services Preamble The message services module messagesService has all the methods supported by this library. Get All Messages To get all the messages that belong to a certain conversation you can call messagesService.getMessages(conversationJid: string), and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const getAllMessages = (conversationJid: string) => { messagesService.getMessages(conversationJid); } // listen to the messages list from the event eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.MessagesUpdated, (eventData: IMessage[]) => { // handle the new updated messages } ); Load More Messages To load more messages when scrolling up in the current conversation, you can use messagesService.loadMore, and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const loadMoreMessages = () => { messagesService.loadMore(); } ... Send Message To send a message whether a text message or a file, you can call messagesService.sendMessage(message: IMessage, urgency: string, attachedFileUri: string[]), where urgency is the message priority and attachedFileUri are the selected files to send and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const sendMyMessage = (IMessage, urgency: string, attachedFileUri: string[]) => { messagesService.sendMessage(message, urgency, attachedFileUri); } Send Message With Additional Content And Urgency To send a message with additional content, you can call messagesService.sendMessageWithAdditionalContentAndUrgency(conversationJid: string,text: string, additionalCont?: string,additionalContType?: string, urgency?: IUrgencyType), where urgency is the message priority and attachedFileUri are the selected files to send and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... messagesService.sendMessage(conversationJid, text, additionalCont, additionalContType, urgency ); Delete Message To delete a sent message, you can call messagesService.deleteMessage(msgID: string), and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const deleteMyMessage = (msgID: string) => { messagesService.deleteMessage(msgID); } Reply Message To reply to a message, you can call messagesService.replyMessage(message: IMessage), and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event, where the replyMessage should be set with the associatedMsgId for the selected replied message as the following. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const replyMessage = (messageToSend: IMessage, repliedMsgId: string) => { messageToSend.associatedMsgId = repliedMsgId; messagesService.replyMessage(messageToSend); } Forward Message To forward a message from a conversation to other conversations, you can call messagesService.forwardMessage(conversationsIds: string[], forwardedMsgId: string,text?: string), and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. Where the conversationsIds is the conversation Id's list that you wanna forward to them, forwardedMsgId is the selected message you wanna forwarded, text is an optional test incase you wanna added. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const forwardMessage = ( conversationsIds: string[], forwardedMsgId: string, text?: string,) => { messagesService.forwardMessage( conversationsIds, forwardedMsgId, text); } Get Messages Marked as Read in Active Conversation To mark incoming messages as read in an active conversation, you can use messagesService.messagesMarkedASReadInActiveConversation(conversationJid: string), and this method will trigger the EventType.MessagesUpdated event. import { messagesService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const markMessagesAsRead = (conversationJid: string) => { messagesService.messagesMarkedASReadInActiveConversation(conversationJid); } On this pageMessage ServicesPreambleGet All MessagesLoad More MessagesSend MessageSend Message With Additional Content And UrgencyDelete MessageReply MessageForward MessageGet Messages Marked as Read in Active ConversationWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationWebrtc call ServicePeer to Peer WebRTC Call Service Preamble The WebRTCService module contains all the webrtc native method that handle the webrtc calls. Switch Camera Switch between the front and the back camera during video call reject Call Reject an incoming webRtc call Take Call Answer an incoming webRTC call Hangup Call Hangup active webRTC call Start Call Start a webRTC call Add LocalVideo to call Add your Local Video to the active webRTC call Remove LocalVideo From Call Remove your localVideo from the active call --- Switch Camera You can use WebRTCService.switchCamera() method to switch between your front and back camera during the video webrtc call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.switchCamera(); ... Reject Incoming Call You can use WebRTCService.rejectCall() method to reject an incoming webRtc call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.rejectCall(); ... takeCall You can use WebRTCService.takeCall() method to answer an incoming webRtc call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.takeCall(); hangupCall You can use WebRTCService.hangupCall() method to end the active webRtc call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.hangupCall(); startCall You can use WebRTCService.startCall() method to initiate a webRtc call towards your contact. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.startCall(); addLocalVideoToCall You can use WebRTCService.addLocalVideoToCall() method to add your video local stream to the active webRTC call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.addLocalVideoToCall(); removeLocalVideoFromCall You can use WebRTCService.removeLocalVideoFromCall() method to remove your video local stream to the active webRTC call. import { WebRTCService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... WebRTCService.removeLocalVideoFromCall(); On this pagePeer to Peer WebRTC Call ServicePreambleSwitch CameraReject Incoming CalltakeCallhangupCallstartCalladdLocalVideoToCallremoveLocalVideoFromCallWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationShared Files ServiceShared Files Services Preamble The message services module sharedFilesService has all the methods supported by this library. The following are all the supported servic
content: DocumentationShared Files ServiceShared Files Services Preamble The message services module sharedFilesService has all the methods supported by this library. The following are all the supported services for the Shared Files: Fetch All Shared Files In Peer fetchAllSharedFilesInPeer(peerJid: string, isBubble: boolean): void Load More Shared Files loadMoreSharedFiles(peerJid: string, isBubble: boolean, numberOfFiles: number = 10): void Fetch File Sent In Bubble fetchFileSentInBubble(bubbleId: string): void Fetch File Received In Bubble fetchFileReceivedInBubble(bubbleId: string): void Fetch File Sent In Conversation fetchFileSentInConversation(convId: string): void Fetch File Received In Conversation fetchFileReceivedInConversation(convId: string): void Download File downloadFile(fileDescriptorId: string): void Delete File deleteFile(fileId: string):void Fetch Files In Peer: To fetch all the shared files in peer (Conversation, Bubble) you can use sharedFilesService.fetchAllSharedFilesInPeer(peerJid: string, isBubble: boolean), where you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... ... sharedFilesService.fetchAllSharedFilesInPeer(peer.jId, isBubble); const sharedFileWithPeerResult = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult, (eventData: IFile[]) => { logger.info(`GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult with file count ${eventData.length}`); // Handle the files result } ); Load More Files: To Fetch more shared files in this peer (Conversation, Bubble), you can call sharedFilesService.loadMoreSharedFiles(peerJid: string, isBubble: boolean, numberOfFiles: number = 10), where the default umber of files to fetch is 10 and you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... ... sharedFilesService.loadMoreSharedFiles(peer.jId, isBubble); const sharedFileWithPeerResult = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult, (eventData: IFile[]) => { logger.info(`GetAllSharedFileWithPeerResult with file count ${eventData.length}`); // Handle the files result } ); Fetch Sent Files In Bubble: To Fetch sent the files in the bubble, you can use sharedFilesService.fetchFileSentInBubble, where you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetSharedFileSentWithBubbleResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const fetchSentFilesInBubble = (bubbleId: string) => { sharedFilesService.fetchFileSentInBubble(bubbleId); } // Listen to fetching file result eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetSharedFileSentWithBubbleResult, (eventData: IFile[] ) => { //handle the shared files } ); Fetch Received Files In Bubble: To Fetch received the files in the bubble, you can use sharedFilesService.fetchFileReceivedInBubble, where you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetSharedFileReceivedWithBubbleResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const fetchFileReceivedInBubble = (bubbleId: string) => { sharedFilesService.fetchFileReceivedInBubble(bubbleId); } // Listen to fetching file result eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetSharedFileReceivedWithBubbleResult, (eventData: IFile[] ) => { //handle the shared files } ); Fetch Sent Files In Conversation: To Fetch sent the files in the conversation, you can use sharedFilesService.fetchFileSentInConversation, where you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetSharedFileSentWithConversationResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const fetchFileSentInConversation = (conversationId: string) => { sharedFilesService.fetchFileSentInConversation(conversationId); } // Listen to fetching file result eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetSharedFileSentWithConversationResult, (eventData: IFile[] ) => { //handle the shared files } ); Fetch Received Files In Conversation: To Fetch received the files in the conversation, you can use sharedFilesService.fetchFileReceivedInConversation, where you can get the files results as array ofIFile type by listening to EventType.GetSharedFileReceivedWithConversationResult. import { sharedFilesService, IFile } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const fetchFileReceivedInConversation = (conversationId: string) => { sharedFilesService.fetchFileReceivedInConversation(conversationId); } // Listen to fetching file result eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetSharedFileReceivedWithConversationResult, (eventData: IFile[] ) => { //handle the shared files } ); Download File: To download a file from a conversation, you can call downloadFile(fileDescriptorId: string), where you can get the file download results by listening to EventType.FileDownloadFinished. Y

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationuseRainbowAuthuseRainbowAuth Hook Overview The useRainbowAuth hook is a custom hook that provides an easy way to access the authentication state and user information from the Redux store
content:
DocumentationuseRainbowAuthuseRainbowAuth Hook Overview The useRainbowAuth hook is a custom hook that provides an easy way to access the authentication state and user information from the Redux store within your React components. This hook simplifies the process of checking if a user is authenticated and retrieving the user's details. Usage To use the useRainbowAuth hook, simply import it into your component and call it. The hook will return an object containing the authentication status and user information. import React from 'react'; import { useRainbowAuth } from 'path-to-hooks'; const UserProfile: React.FC = () => { const { isAuthenticated, user } = useRainbowAuth(); return (
{isAuthenticated ? (

Welcome, {user?.name}!

) : (

Please log in.

)}
); }; Return Value The useRainbowAuth hook returns an object with the following properties: isAuthenticated: A boolean indicating whether the user is authenticated. user: An object containing information about the user, including their name, email, and other details. Error Handling he hook includes error handling to ensure that it can still function correctly even when used outside of the Redux Provider. If the hook is called outside of the provider context, it falls back to accessing the Redux store directly to retrieve the user state. Conclusion The useRainbowAuth hook is a powerful utility for managing authentication state in your React components. By using this hook, you can easily check if a user is authenticated and access their details, streamlining the process of building authentication flows in your application. excerpt: DocumentationUser Profile ServiceConnected User Profile Services Preamble The login user service module userProfileService has all the methods supported by this library. Get Connected User: To fetch t
content: DocumentationUser Profile ServiceConnected User Profile Services Preamble The login user service module userProfileService has all the methods supported by this library. Get Connected User: To fetch the current connect user info, you can call userProfileService.getConnectedUser(), where you can get the user results as object ofIUser type by listening to EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated. The same event EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated you can listen to when ever changes occurred on the connected user for example his presence, name, profile image,...etc. import { userProfileService, IUser } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; ... const getCurrentConnectedUser = () => { userProfileService.getConnectedUser(); } ... // Listen for the getConnectedUser method result, also when ever changes happened on the connected user. const connectedUserUpdated = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated, (eventData: IUser) => { // handle the connected user. } ); Set Connect User Presence To change the current connected user presence status, you can call userProfileService.setPresence(presence: Presence), where the presence is the new presence you want to change to. The presence changes result will trigger the EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated with the updated user object of type IUser. import { userProfileService, IUser } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; ... const changeUserPresence = (newPresence: Presence) => { userProfileService.setPresence(newPresence); } ... // Listen for the getConnectedUser method result, also when ever changes happened on the connected user. const connectedUserUpdated = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated, (eventData: IUser) => { // handle the connected user with his new updated presence. const newPresence = eventData.contact.presence; } ); Update Custom Data: In order to update the customData of the connected user, you have to create a JSONObject, fill it with all your custom data and call the method userProfileService.updateCustomData(customData: {}), where this method will automatically trigger the EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated with the updated user object of type IUser with the updated customData props. import {userProfileService } from 'react-native-rainbow-module' ... const updateConnectedUserCustomData = (customData: {}}) => { // Where data is a json data, for example: { 'key1': value, 'key2': value,... } userProfileService.updateCustomData(customData); } ... // Listen for the getConnectedUser method result, also when ever changes happened on the connected user. const connectedUserUpdated = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.ConnectedUserUpdated, (eventData: IUser) => { // handle the connected user with his new updated presence. const newCustomData = eventData.customData; } ); On this pageConnected User Profile ServicesPreambleGet Connected User:Set Connect User PresenceUpdate Custom Data:Was this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: Rainbow SDK for React Native environmentConnect your mobile application to RainbowReady to get started with Rainbow SDK for React Native ?Everything you need to get started with Rainbow SDK for React Native.First steps with ReactNative SDKDownload ReactNative SDKCheck ReactNative code samplesSDK packaged for React Native environmentThe Rainbow SDK for React Native is delivered as a NPN package that can be deployed easily and used in any mobiles applications.NPM packagePush NotificationsSDK for React Native at a glance.Learn about the main APIs provided by this SDKNative libraryReact Native SDK is built using native and latest technology standard in order to provide a high and efficiency native library for your applications.Contacts, search and presence APIHandle your contact list and know when they are available, busy on the phone or away. Search for users by name or id to extend your network.One-to-one Chat APIExchange messages with your contacts. Be alerted when contacts send you a message. You can retrieve the whole conversation or only the most recent messages.Bubbles groupchat APICreate and invite users, or reuse your bubbles for talking together. In a bubble, everyone can participate to the conversation.WebRTC audio and video APIYou can initiate audio and video calls to your contacts using your mobile throught WebRTC. Escalade from audio to video. Switch from the front to the back camera and control the call (mute/unmute).Interesting linksLearn how to use our SDKsNeed some help?Contact our support teamVisit our homepageFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationChangelogWhat's new Welcome to the new release of the Rainbow SDK for React Native.There are a number of significant updates in this version that we hope you will like,Some of the key hig
content: DocumentationChangelogWhat's new Welcome to the new release of the Rainbow SDK for React Native.There are a number of significant updates in this version that we hope you will like,Some of the key highlights include: SDK for React-Native 1.13.2 - Jan 2026 Bug Fixes: Fixed NullPointerException in native modules Enhanced error handling and null safety across the codebase Improved stability in conference call management Optimized resource cleanup in call termination Example App Improvements: Resolved various development warnings in the sample application Improved code quality and maintainability of example components SDK for React-Native 1.13.1 - Dec 2025 Bug Fixes: Fixed NullPointerException in conference call handling Improved null safety in conference participant management SDK for React-Native 1.13.0 - Dec 2025 New Features: Added headless authentication provider for complete UI control ConnectingToRainbow Simplified connection management with new useRainbowAuth hook Enhancements: Refactored call logs to remove action creator pattern Simplified contact management implementation Improved documentation for better developer experience Updated component interfaces for better type safety Fixes: Fixed date formatting in call history Resolved infinite loop issue in call log actions Improved error handling in contact list updates SDK for React-Native 1.12.1 - Nov 2025 API Changes: export ApplicationInformation component to allow switch between different environments during development. SDK for React-Native 1.12.0 - September 2025 Enhancements: Upgraded React Native version from 0.75.1 to 0.79.0 Enabled support for the new architecture (New Arch). For detailed upgrade instructions, refer to the React Native Upgrade Helper Updated libraries to be compatible with React Native 0.79 and New Architecture Added localization strings for alert messages to support multiple languages Fixes: Resolved issue with icons not displaying after the React Native upgrade. Fixed compatibility issues in Kotlin native modules. Addressed breaking changes introduced in React Native 0.79.0. SDK for React-Native 1.11.1 - July 2025 API Changes: Renamed EventType.missedCallLogsUpdated to EventType.MissedCallLogsUpdated for naming consistency. Updated event documentation to reflect the new event name across the codebase. Fixes: Fixed event name consistency in iOS native code for call logs Updated event listeners to use the new event name in the React Native bridge. Other Changes: Security Updated vulnerable dependencies to their latest secure versions Addressed critical and high severity vulnerabilities in third-party packages. Documentation: Added comprehensive documentation for CallLogsService. Added comprehensive documentation for InvitationsService. Updated API reference with new service documentation. SDK for React-Native 1.11.0 - May 2025 Other Changes: Upgraded iOS Rainbow SDK to version 2.13.0 Upgraded Android Rainbow SDK to version 2.61.0 Resolved compatibility issues with the latest SDK versions Fixes: Enhanced authentication flow stability by resolving login page flickering Fixed iOS message deletion UI issue where the rest of messages are shown as deleted message. Optimized Android WebRTC performance by reducing event emissions during active calls. Resolved Android local video rendering issue for callers. Improved conference call UI by adding missing call action buttons. API Changes: Add event IsNetworkAvailable to Events to handle app state when no internet connection. SDK for React-Native 1.10.4 - Feb 2025 New Features: Authentication Process Refactor Refactored Authentication Process: Improved the authentication flow by integrating the RainbowContainer and SecureContainer components, allowing for better management of authentication states and user sessions. Custom Authentication Navigator: Added the ability to pass a custom authentication stack navigator to the RainbowContainer, providing flexibility for developers to implement their own authentication flows. New useRainbowAuth Hook: Introduced a custom hook that simplifies access to the authentication state and user information from the Redux store, enhancing the ease of use within React components. Fixes: Resolved an issue where the app logo was not displaying on iOS. Invalid Date Rendering: Fixed the issue where dates were rendered as "Invalid Date" inside the chat message container. Fixed Attach File Issue: Resolved the problem where attaching files was not functioning correctly. Addressed Upstream Dependency Conflicts: Ensured that the project's dependencies were in sync with the latest versions. Other Changes: Updated Documentation: Comprehensive updates to the authentication documentation, including: Detailed usage instructions for the useRainbowAuth hook. Enhanced tutorials for integrating the authentication flow using the RainbowContainer. Added links to relevant documentation for better navigation and understanding of authentication components. SDK for React-Native 1.10

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationConnecting to RainbowConnecting to Rainbow & Authentication Preamble After you initialize the SDK, you must connect to the Rainbow server. This SDK provides a headless authentication prov
content: DocumentationConnecting to RainbowConnecting to Rainbow & Authentication Preamble After you initialize the SDK, you must connect to the Rainbow server. This SDK provides a headless authentication provider, giving you full control over your application's UI and navigation flow. The RainbowProvider Component The RainbowProvider is the core component for integrating Rainbow services. It sets up the necessary Redux store, theme, and authentication context for the SDK to function. It does not render any UI itself. To use it, wrap your application's root component with RainbowProvider: // App.tsx import React from 'react'; import { RainbowProvider } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; import { NavigationContainer } from '@react-navigation/native'; import RootNavigator from './RootNavigator'; // Your app's navigator const App = () => { return ( <RainbowProvider> <NavigationContainer> <RootNavigator /> </NavigationContainer> </RainbowProvider> ); }; export default App; The useRainbowAuth Hook To manage the authentication state in your application, the SDK provides the useRainbowAuth hook. This hook gives you access to the user's authentication status, loading state, and user information. The hook returns an object with the following properties: isAuthenticated (boolean): true if the user is logged in, otherwise false. isLoading (boolean): true during the initial authentication check (e.g., silent login). user (IUser): The connected user's information if authenticated, otherwise null. Building Your Authentication Flow With RainbowProvider and useRainbowAuth, you can create a custom authentication flow that fits your application's design. You are responsible for building all the UI components for login, registration, password reset, etc. Here is an example of a RootNavigator that uses the useRainbowAuth hook to conditionally render the authentication screens or the main application screens: // RootNavigator.tsx import React from 'react'; import { useRainbowAuth, Spinner } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; import AuthNavigator from './AuthNavigator'; // Your authentication screens import MainAppNavigator from './MainAppNavigator'; // Your main app screens const RootNavigator = () => { const { isAuthenticated, isLoading } = useRainbowAuth(); if (isLoading) { // Show a loading indicator during the initial auth check return <Spinner spinnerSize={40} />; } return isAuthenticated ? <MainAppNavigator /> : <AuthNavigator />; }; export default RootNavigator; NOTE: You can find a complete implementation of this approach in the example project provided in the SDK repository example link On this pageConnecting to Rainbow & AuthenticationPreambleThe RainbowProvider ComponentThe useRainbowAuth HookBuilding Your Authentication FlowWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

content: DocumentationEnabling push notificationsEnabling push notifications When your application needs to receive notification at any time, you have to implement push notifications. There are few steps you have to do it in iOS/Android app to handle the notification Android setup Step 1 - Set up firebase cloud messaging he first step is setting up the Firebase Cloud Messaging feature. You must follow this Firebase tutorial. At the end of this step, your project should be configured with a google-services.json (in app directory) and all required dependencies. Step 2 - Access the device registration token Create a new service class which extends FirebaseMessagingService and override onNewToken() method to send the token to the Rainbow SDK. In the RN SDk we provided a notificationHandler interface, that handle accessing the registration token and send the received messages to Rainbow SDK. So first you need pass your app context to the notificationHandler class, as on sample code below. all you have to do is calling the onTokenRefresh() to send the refresh token and call onPushMessageReceived() to send the received message [see step 3]. import com.ale.rainbow.rn.notifications.INotificationHandler; import com.ale.rainbow.rn.notifications.NotificationHandler; public class MyNotificationPushService extends FirebaseMessagingService { @Override public void onCreate() { super.onCreate(); notificationHandler = new NotificationHandler(this); } @Override public void onNewToken(String token) { notificationHandler.onTokenRefresh(refreshedToken); } } Declare the service in your app's manifest: <service android:name=".MyNotificationPushService"> <intent-filter> <action android:name="com.google.firebase.MESSAGING_EVENT"/> </intent-filter> </service Step 3 - Handle Messages In your MyNotificationPushService service class, override onMessageReceived() and call to send received message to the Rainbow SDK. public class MyFirebaseMessagingService extends FirebaseMessagingService { @Override public void onMessageReceived(RemoteMessage remoteMessage) { notificationHandler.onPushMessageReceived(remoteMessage, this.getApplication(), MainActivity.Class); super.onMessageReceived(message); } } Step 4 - Set the firebase service key to Rainbow Hub In order to have Rainbow handling push notification, you have to upload the Firebase server key of your application Firebase project to your Rainbow application on the Rainbow hub. 1 - Get the server key on the Firebase site: Go to the Firebase console, click on your project and copy the server key. . 2 - Rainbow hub: Set the server key for Android. Go to the Rainbow hub and set the server key for your Android application. iOS Setup Step 1 - CREATING IOS CERTIFICATES and ENABLE PUSH WITH RAINBOW SDK Please follow this instruction in this link push notification setup. Step 2 - For react-native-rainbow-module >= 1.1.0 Because in this version the remote notification message was encrypted, you need to decrypted by following those steps: add notification services extensions to you project: Select File > New > Target in Xcode > Select the Notification Service Extension target from the iOS > Application section. specify a name for your extension. open Podfile and add the following: target 'YOUR_NOTIFICATION_EXTENSION_NAME' do pod 'react-native-rainbow-module', :path => '../..' end ... target 'YOUR_APP_NAME' do ... then make pod install command. open NotificationService, add the following code: `` import "NotificationService.h" import <RNRainbowRn.h> //<--- add this @interface NotificationService () @property (nonatomic, strong) void (^contentHandler)(UNNotificationContent contentToDeliver); @property (nonatomic, strong) UNMutableNotificationContentbestAttemptContent; @end @implementation NotificationService (void)didReceiveNotificationRequest:(UNNotificationRequest )request withContentHandler:(void (^)(UNNotificationContent _Nonnull))contentHandler { self.contentHandler = contentHandler; self.bestAttemptContent = [request.content mutableCopy]; // Add this following to your file. NSDictionary userInfo = _bestAttemptContent.userInfo; // Check if the notification message is encrypted if ([userInfo valueForKeyPath:@"aps.crypt"]) { NotificationsManagerrainbowNotificationManager = [ServicesManager sharedInstance].notificationsManager; userInfo = [rainbowNotificationManager decryptNotificationContentWithUserInfo:userInfo]; _bestAttemptContent.userInfo = userInfo; // Refill bestAttemptContent with the updated data NSString *title = [userInfo valueForKeyPath:@"aps.alert.title"]; _bestAttemptContent.title = title; NSString *body = [userInfo valueForKeyPath:@"aps.alert.body"]; _bestAttemptContent.body = body; } // Modify the notification content here... self.bestAttemptContent.title = [NSString stringWithFormat:@"%@ [modified]", self.bestAttemptContent.title]; self.contentHandler(self.bestAttemptContent); } (void)serviceExtensionTimeWillExpire { // Called just before the extension will be terminated by the system. // Use

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationGetting startedGetting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow React Native Software Development Kit (SDK)! Preamble The Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise (ALE) Rainbow SDK is a
content: DocumentationGetting startedGetting Started Welcome to the Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise Rainbow React Native Software Development Kit (SDK)! Preamble The Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise (ALE) Rainbow SDK is a React Native library that allows you to connect your native Android and iOS applications to the Rainbow platform. This guide will walk you through setting up your environment and installing the SDK in a modern React Native project. Prerequisites Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed and configured for React Native development: Node.js: Active LTS version recommended. npm or yarn(preferred). React Native CLI. Xcode for iOS development. Android Studio for Android development. For a detailed guide on setting up your development environment, please follow the official React Native documentation. Installation Adding the Rainbow SDK to your project is straightforward. In your React Native project's root directory, run: # Using npm npm install react-native-rainbow-module # Or using yarn yarn add react-native-rainbow-module iOS Installation For iOS, you need to install the native dependencies (Pods): cd ios && pod install Peer Dependencies To function correctly, the Rainbow SDK requires several peer dependencies to be installed in your project. These are libraries that the SDK depends on but does not bundle, giving you greater control over your app's dependency tree. You will need to install the following packages: # Using npm npm install react-native-localize react-native-permissions react-native-vector-icons react-native-keyboard-controller # Or using yarn yarn add react-native-localize react-native-permissions react-native-vector-icons react-native-keyboard-controller After installing, you will need to configure them for each platform. Credential Storage The Rainbow SDK does not handle the storage of user credentials (e.g., email and password). This is the responsibility of the consuming application. We recommend using a secure storage solution like react-native-keychain to store credentials. You will need to install and configure it in your application, then use it to save credentials on successful login and load them for silent login. For an example of how to implement this, please see the LoginForm.tsx and ForgotPassword.tsx components in the example application. iOS Installation For iOS, you need to install the native dependencies (Pods): cd ios && pod install Android Installation For Android, React Native's autolinking feature will handle most of the setup. However, you need to perform the following configuration steps. Android Configuration 1. Set Minimum SDK Version The Rainbow SDK requires a minimum Android SDK version of 26. Open your project's android/app/build.gradle file and set minSdkVersion. // android/app/build.gradle android { defaultConfig { ... minSdkVersion 26 } ... } 2. Add the Rainbow Maven Repository In your project's root android/build.gradle file, add the Open Rainbow maven repository: // android/build.gradle allprojects { repositories { ... maven { url "http://maven.openrainbow.io" } } } 3. Initialize the SDK in MainApplication This is a critical step. You must initialize the Rainbow SDK in your MainApplication file before the React Native application starts. This is done by calling RainbowPackage.setApplication() in the onCreate method. For Kotlin (MainApplication.kt): import com.ale.rainbow.rn.RainbowPackage class MainApplication : Application(), ReactApplication { // ... other code override fun onCreate() { super.onCreate() RainbowPackage.setApplication(this, MainActivity::class.java) SoLoader.init(this, false) // ... other code } } For Java (MainApplication.java): import com.ale.rainbow.rn.RainbowPackage; public class MainApplication extends Application implements ReactApplication { // ... other code @Override public void onCreate() { super.onCreate(); RainbowPackage.setApplication(this, MainActivity.class); SoLoader.init(this, /* native exopackage */ false); // ... other code } } // android/build.gradle allprojects { repositories { ... maven { url "http://maven.openrainbow.io" } } } Initialize the SDK STEP 1 : Create a Rainbow application To initialize the SDK you need an applicationID and a secretKey from the Rainbow Developer Hub. This information allows you to identify your application and allows you to use the Rainbow platform. For more information, see Applications lifecycle which explains what is the purpose, how to create an application, and how to get the application ID and the secret key. STEP 2 : Add Configuration File The Rainbow SDK now uses a platform-specific configuration file for initialization. You need to add a rainbow-config.json file in both iOS and Android projects: Configuration File Structure Your rainbow-config.json should have the following structure: [ { "HOST":"openrainbow.com", "APP_ID":"your app id for .com host", "SEC_KEY":"your secret key" }, { "HOST":"openrainbow.net", "APP_ID":"your app id for .net host", "SEC_KEY":"your secret key" }

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationListen for eventsListening to SDK Events Overview The Rainbow SDK for React Native uses an event-driven architecture to notify your application about various state changes and updates. Th
content: DocumentationListen for eventsListening to SDK Events Overview The Rainbow SDK for React Native uses an event-driven architecture to notify your application about various state changes and updates. This guide explains how to listen and respond to these events in your application. Table of Contents Introduction to Event System Common Event Patterns Event Categories Connection Events Contact Events Call Events Message Events Bubble Events Best Practices Introduction to Event System The SDK's event system allows your application to react to changes in real-time. All events are emitted through the eventEmitter instance, which you can import from the SDK: import { eventEmitter, EventType } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; // Subscribe to an event const subscription = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.ContactsUpdated, (contacts: IContact[]) => { console.log('Contacts updated:', contacts); } ); // Don't forget to clean up // Usually in a useEffect cleanup function subscription.remove(); Common Event Patterns Basic Event Subscription useEffect(() => { const subscription = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.ContactsUpdated, (contacts: IContact[]) => { // Handle updated contacts } ); return () => { // Clean up the subscription subscription.remove(); }; }, []); Multiple Event Subscriptions useEffect(() => { const subscriptions = [ eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.ContactsUpdated, handleContactsUpdate), eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.MessagesUpdated, handleMessagesUpdate), ]; return () => { subscriptions.forEach(sub => sub.remove()); }; }, []); Event Categories Connection Events EventTypeDescription IsNetworkAvailablebooleanFires when network connectivity changes ConnectionStateChangedConnectionStateFires when the connection state changes eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.IsNetworkAvailable, (isAvailable: boolean) => { console.log('Network available:', isAvailable); } ); Contact Events EventTypeDescription ContactsUpdatedIContact[]Fires when the contact list is updated PresenceChanged{ jid: string, presence: string }Fires when a contact's presence changes Call Events EventTypeDescription CallStateChangedCallStateFires when call state changes CallAddedICallFires when a new call is received CallRemovedstringFires when a call ends (callId) Message Events EventTypeDescription MessagesUpdatedIMessage[]Fires when messages are updated IsTyping{ jid: string, isTyping: boolean }Fires when typing status changes Bubble Events EventTypeDescription BubblesListUpdatedIBubble[]Fires when the bubble list is updated OnBubbleUpdatedIBubbleFires when a bubble is updated Best Practices Always Clean Up Remove event listeners when components unmount to prevent memory leaks. Use TypeScript Types Always type your event handlers to get better IDE support and catch errors early. Debounce Rapid Events Some events might fire rapidly (like typing indicators). Consider debouncing the handler if needed. Error Handling Always handle potential errors in your event handlers. Performance For events that might cause expensive re-renders, consider using useCallback for your handlers. Complete Example import React, { useEffect, useCallback } from 'react'; import { eventEmitter, EventType, IContact } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; const MyComponent = () => { const handleContactsUpdate = useCallback((contacts: IContact[]) => { console.log('Contacts updated:', contacts); // Update your component state or perform other actions }, []); useEffect(() => { const subscriptions = [ eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.ContactsUpdated, handleContactsUpdate), eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.IsNetworkAvailable, (isAvailable) => { console.log('Network status:', isAvailable ? 'Online' : 'Offline'); }) ]; return () => { subscriptions.forEach(sub => sub.remove()); }; }, [handleContactsUpdate]); return ( // Your component JSX ); }; export default MyComponent; For a complete list of all available events and their types, please refer to the Events API Reference. On this pageOverviewTable of ContentsIntroduction to Event SystemCommon Event PatternsBasic Event SubscriptionMultiple Event SubscriptionsEvent CategoriesConnection EventsContact EventsCall EventsMessage EventsBubble EventsBest PracticesComplete ExampleWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationMake IM conversationMake an IM Conversation This guide explains how to retrieve messages from a conversation (P2P or Bubble) and how to send new ones using <Messages /> component. Preambl
content: DocumentationMake IM conversationMake an IM Conversation This guide explains how to retrieve messages from a conversation (P2P or Bubble) and how to send new ones using <Messages /> component. Preamble This is the same mechanism for Peer to Peer messages and messages bubbles. All you need to do is import the <Messages /> from the Rainbow RN library as below , Then you will be able to make use of the Following chat feature: Send Message: you can send a new message to another peer to peer or a bubble chat. Load more messages. Reply to a Message: you can reply to a specific message in the chat. listen to the message changes including: EventType.MessagesUpdated, EventType.IsTyping, EventType.FileAttachFinished, EventType.FileDownloadFinished. incase you wanna handle more feature than the default, we already support all the message services that you need, with the customized message props as the following table. Available props #NameTypeDescription 1conversationIPeerthe peer object its could be a conversation type [P2P] or bubble type 2messagesIMessage[]the message list for the the selected peer 3styleViewStylethe container style of the message component 4onMessageLongPressed(context: any, message: IMessage) => void[optional] callback method when long pressed accuses on a message 5renderSendingExtraView() => React.ReactNode[optional] the extra view above the sending view 6renderChatActions() => React.ReactNode[optional] the customized action you wanna add beside the sending action 7renderMessageCustomView(currentMessage: IMessage) => React.ReactNode[optional] Custom view inside the message bubble 8renderSystemMessage(currentMessage: IMessage) => React.ReactNode[optional] the message comes from the system, for example 'Call Ended' ...etc 9onSend(message: IMessage) => void[optional] A callback method when the send button is pressed 10alwaysShowSendboolean[optional] showing the sending button or not? where it's set by default to true 11renderMessageImage(currentMessage: IMessage) => void[optional] customized message image 12renderAvatar(currentMessage: IMessage) => React.ReactNode[optional] customized user avatar inside the messages view 13onInputTextChanged(text: string) => void[optional] callback in case there is changes occurs in the sending text input 13renderSendButton(sendProps: SendProps) => React.ReactNode[optional] function to customize the "Send" text button with an icon or any react element to send messages. How To Use: import React, { Component } from 'react'; import { eventEmitter, EventType, Messages, IPeer, IMessage, messagesService, } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; interface IMessageComponentProps { peer: IPeer, } export const MessageComponent: React.FunctionComponent<IMessageComponentProps> = (props: IMessageComponentProps) => { const [messages, setMessages] = useState<IMessage[]>([]); useEffect(() => { // Listen for the message changes for this peer const onMessagesUpdatedEvent = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.MessagesUpdated, (eventData: IMessage[]) => { setMessages(eventData); // mark as read for any new incoming msg messagesService.messagesMarkedASReadInActiveConversation(props.peer.jId); } ); return () => { onMessagesUpdatedEvent.remove(); } }, [props.peer.jId]); return( <Messages conversation={props.peer} messages={messages} /> ); } You can check this example for more detail about how to use the customize UI props. Customized Message Props: On Message Long Pressed A callback function that called after the user pressed long on any certain message. you can overwrite the onMessageLongPressed by your own customization. import React, { Component } from 'react'; import { eventEmitter, EventType, Messages, IPeer, IMessage, messagesService, } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; interface IMessageComponentProps { peer: IPeer, } export const MessageComponent: React.FunctionComponent<IMessageComponentProps> = (props: IMessageComponentProps) => { const [messages, setMessages] = useState<IMessage[]>([]); useEffect(() => { // Listen for the message changes for this peer const onMessagesUpdatedEvent = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.MessagesUpdated, (eventData: IMessage[]) => { setMessages(eventData); // mark as read for any new incoming msg messagesService.messagesMarkedASReadInActiveConversation(props.peer.jId); } ); return () => { onMessagesUpdatedEvent.remove(); } }, [props.peer.jId]); const onLongPress = (context: any, message: IMessage) => { const options = ["Reply", "Forward", "Copy"]; if (message.isSent) { // Show delete option only for the sent msg options.push("Delete"); } // Make the cancel option the last one options.push(IMessageOption.Cancel); const cancelButtonIndex = options.length - 1; context.actionSheet().showActionSheetWithOptions( { options, cancelButtonIndex, }, (buttonIndex: number) => { switch (options[buttonIndex]) { case "Copy": Clipboard.setString(message.text); break; case "Forward": // handle Forward messagesService.forwardMessage([props.peer.jId], message._id); br

excerpt: DocumentationManage BubblesBubbles Management Overview The Rainbow SDK for React Native provides comprehensive tools for managing bubbles, which are collaborative spaces for group communication. This
content: DocumentationManage BubblesBubbles Management Overview The Rainbow SDK for React Native provides comprehensive tools for managing bubbles, which are collaborative spaces for group communication. This guide covers all aspects of bubble management including retrieval, creation, participant management, and custom data handling. Table of Contents Retrieving Bubbles Bubble Participants Management Bubble Custom Data Retrieving Bubbles Overview To display a list of bubbles, use the <Bubbles /> component from the Rainbow RN library. This component provides a customizable interface for displaying and interacting with bubbles. Component Props #NameTypeDescription 1bubblesIBubble[]Array of bubble objects 2styleIBubbleStylePropsCustom styles for the bubble list view 3refreshControlReact.ReactElementPull-to-refresh functionality 4cellWidthnumberWidth of each row in the bubbles list 5cellHeightnumberHeight of each row in the bubbles list 6renderItems(bubble: IBubble) => React.ReactElementCustom render function for bubble items 7renderListEmpty() => React.ReactElementRendered when the bubbles array is empty Implementation Example import React, { FunctionComponent, useState, useEffect } from 'react'; import { Bubbles, IBubble } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; export const BubblesComponent: FunctionComponent = () => { const [allBubbles, setAllBubbles] = useState<IBubble[]>([]); useEffect(() => { // Fetch bubbles bubblesService.getBubbles(); // Listen for bubble list updates const bubblesListUpdated = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.BubblesListUpdated, (eventData: IBubble[]) => { setAllBubbles(eventData); } ); return () => { bubblesListUpdated.remove(); }; }, []); const renderBubbleItem = (item: IBubble) => { return ( <ListItem avatar={true} style={defaultStyle.listItem}> {/* Custom bubble item rendering */} </ListItem> ); }; return ( <Bubbles bubbles={allBubbles} renderItems={renderBubbleItem} // Add other props as needed /> ); }; Bubble Participants Management The Rainbow SDK allows you to manage participants within your bubbles, including adding, removing, and modifying participant roles. Adding Participants Adding Multiple Participants import { BubbleParticipants } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; const addMultipleParticipants = (bubbleId: string, contactsJid: string[]) => { BubbleParticipants.addParticipants(bubbleId, contactsJid); }; Adding a Single Participant with Options const addParticipant = ( bubbleId: string, contactJid: string, asModerator: boolean = false, withInvitation: boolean = true ) => { BubbleParticipants.inviteParticipantToBubble( bubbleId, contactJid, asModerator, withInvitation ); }; Removing Participants useEffect(() => { // Listen for remove participant result const removeListener = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.RemoveContactFromBubbleResult, (eventData: { members: IContact[], organizers: IContact[] }) => { // Handle participant removal } ); return () => removeListener.remove(); }, []); // To remove a participant BubbleParticipants.removeContactFromBubble(bubbleId, contactJid); Managing Participant Roles Promote to Organizer BubbleParticipants.promoteToOrganizer(bubbleId, contactJid); Demote from Organizer BubbleParticipants.demoteFromOrganizer(bubbleId, contactJid); Transfer Ownership BubbleParticipants.giveOwnership(bubbleId, newOwnerJid); Bubble Custom Data The Rainbow SDK allows you to associate custom JSON data with your bubbles for extended functionality. Adding/Updating Custom Data import { BubbleCustomData } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; const updateBubbleData = (bubbleId: string, data: Record<string, any>) => { BubbleCustomData.updateCustomDataForBubble(bubbleId, data); }; // Example usage updateBubbleData('bubble123', { customField1: 'value1', customField2: 42, customField3: true }); Removing Custom Data BubbleCustomData.deleteCustomDataForBubble(bubbleId); Retrieving Custom Data useEffect(() => { const customDataListener = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetBubbleCustomData, (data: any) => { // Handle retrieved custom data } ); // Request custom data BubbleCustomData.getCustomDataFromBubble(bubbleId, 'yourDataKey'); return () => customDataListener.remove(); }, [bubbleId]); Error Handling Always implement proper error handling for all bubble operations: try { await BubbleParticipants.addParticipants(bubbleId, contactJids); } catch (error) { console.error('Failed to add participants:', error); // Show error to user } Best Practices Always clean up event listeners in the useEffect cleanup function Handle loading states appropriately Implement proper error handling Validate data before sending to the SDK Test thoroughly with different user roles and permissions {item.name} {item.topic} ); }; return ; }; #### Create a new bubble --- To create a new bubble, you have to call the component `<CreateBubble />`with some props are listed on tha table below. |#|Name |Notes |Description| |-|------------------------|-------------------|------------| |1| onBubbleCreationResult

excerpt: DocumentationManage call logsRetrieve Call Logs Overview The Call Logs feature allows you to display and manage call history, including all calls, missed calls, and voicemails. This guide will show yo
content: DocumentationManage call logsRetrieve Call Logs Overview The Call Logs feature allows you to display and manage call history, including all calls, missed calls, and voicemails. This guide will show you how to implement and customize call logs in your application. Features View all call history Filter by missed calls Voicemail integration Customizable actions for each call log item Real-time updates Installation Make sure you have the Rainbow SDK properly installed and configured in your project. Basic Usage Displaying Call Logs import React from 'react'; import { CallLogs } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; export const CallLogsScreen: React.FC = () => { return ( <CallLogs allCallsEnabled={true} missedCallsEnabled={true} voiceMailEnabled={true} /> ); }; Handling Call Log Clicks You can handle when a user clicks on a call log item using the prop:onClickCallLogAction. import React from 'react'; import { CallLogs, ICallLog } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; export const CallLogsScreen: React.FC = () => { const handleCallLogClick = (callLog: ICallLog) => { // Handle the click event console.log('Call log clicked:', callLog); // Example: Navigate to call details // navigation.navigate('CallDetails', { callLog }); }; return ( <CallLogs onClickCallLogAction={handleCallLogClick} /> ); }; Props PropTypeRequiredDescription onClickCallLogAction(callLog: ICallLog) => voidNoCallback when a call log item is clicked Types ICallLog The call log object contains the following properties: interface ICallLog { id: string; contact: IContact; lastCall: { state: CallState; isConference: boolean; date: string; // Unix timestamp in milliseconds duration?: string; }; calls: ICallLogInfo[]; } Events The CallLogs component emits the following events: CallLogsUpdated: When the call logs are updated MissedCallLogsUpdated: When missed calls are updated VoiceMailCapabilityUpdate: When voicemail capabilities change Best Practices Memory Management: Always clean up event listeners when your component unmounts Performance: For large call logs, consider implementing pagination Error Handling: Handle cases where call logs cannot be loaded Permissions: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to access call logs Troubleshooting If call logs are not updating, check your event listeners Ensure proper error handling for network requests Verify that the user has the necessary permissions API Reference For more detailed information about the available props and methods, see the API Reference. On this pageOverviewFeaturesInstallationBasic UsageDisplaying Call LogsHandling Call Log ClicksPropsTypesICallLogEventsBest PracticesTroubleshootingAPI ReferenceWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

excerpt: DocumentationManage InvitationsManaging Invitations Overview The Rainbow SDK allows you to manage social invitations, which are the primary way users connect and build their network. This feature is e
content: DocumentationManage InvitationsManaging Invitations Overview The Rainbow SDK allows you to manage social invitations, which are the primary way users connect and build their network. This feature is essential for creating a collaborative and interactive experience in your application. Core Functionalities The invitation system is built around a few key concepts: Fetching Invitations: You can retrieve lists of both sent and received invitations for the logged-in user. Responding to Received Invitations: When a user receives an invitation from another person, your application can allow them to either accept it, adding the person to their contacts, or decline it. Managing Sent Invitations: For invitations the user has sent, they can choose to cancel the invitation before it's accepted or resend it if needed. Custom UI Components: The SDK provides flexible UI components to display and manage invitations in your app's interface. How It Works Like other features in the SDK, the invitation system is asynchronous. You will dispatch an action (like accepting an invitation) and then listen for events to know when the action is complete and to receive updated lists of invitations. This ensures your app's UI stays fast and responsive. UI Components InvitationCard Component The InvitationCard is a flexible UI component that displays a single invitation with appropriate actions based on the invitation type (received or sent). It's perfect for when you need more control over the invitation UI than what the BubbleInvitations component provides. Props PropTypeRequiredDescription invitationIInvitationYesThe invitation object to display onAccept(invitation: IInvitation) => voidNoCallback when the accept button is pressed (for received invitations) onDecline(invitation: IInvitation) => voidNoCallback when the decline button is pressed (for received invitations) onCancel(invitation: IInvitation) => voidNoCallback when the cancel button is pressed (for sent invitations) onResend(invitation: IInvitation) => voidNoCallback when the resend button is pressed (for sent invitations) Example Usage import { InvitationCard } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; const InvitationList = ({ invitations, onAccept, onDecline, onCancel, onResend }) => { return ( <FlatList data={invitations} keyExtractor={(item) => item.id} renderItem={({ invitation }) => ( <InvitationCard invitation={invitation} onAccept={ onAccept(invitation)} onDecline={onDecline(invitation)} onCancel={onCancel(invitation)} onResend={onResend(invitation)} /> )} /> ); }; BubbleInvitations Component For a complete out-of-the-box solution for managing bubble invitations, you can use the BubbleInvitations component. Implementation import { BubbleInvitations } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; export const BubbleInvitationsComponent: FunctionComponent = () => { return <BubbleInvitations />; } Features View Received Invitations: See all pending bubble invitations in one place Accept/Decline: Easily accept or decline bubble invitations with built-in UI Real-time Updates: The component automatically updates to reflect the current state of invitations Programmatic Invitation Management For more control over the invitation flow, you can use the Invitation Services API directly. This allows you to: Fetch the list of received and sent invitations Accept or decline received invitations Cancel or resend sent invitations Listen for invitation-related events Example: Handling Invitations Programmatically import { InvitationServices } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; // Fetch all invitations const invitations = await InvitationServices.getInvitations(); // Accept an invitation await InvitationServices.acceptInvitation(invitationId); // Listen for invitation updates const subscription = EventEmitter.addListener(EventType.InvitationUpdate, (event) => { console.log('Invitation updated:', event); // Update your UI accordingly }); // Don't forget to clean up subscription.remove(); Next Steps For detailed API reference and additional customization options, please refer to the Invitation Services API Reference. On this pageOverviewCore FunctionalitiesHow It WorksUI ComponentsInvitationCard ComponentPropsExample UsageBubbleInvitations ComponentImplementationFeaturesProgrammatic Invitation ManagementExample: Handling Invitations ProgrammaticallyNext StepsWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationManage ConferencesRetrieve Conference Call Preamble This guide describes how to use SFU which is Rainbow conference service. This conference uses bubbles. In this tutorial we will talking
content: DocumentationManage ConferencesRetrieve Conference Call Preamble This guide describes how to use SFU which is Rainbow conference service. This conference uses bubbles. In this tutorial we will talking bout the following: How to use ConferenceCallComponent. Listen to the Conference event including: EventType.CurrentConferenceUpdated, EventType.GetConferenceScreenSharingUpdate, EventType.ConferenceAttendeesUpdates If you want to know how to use The Conference Services like start conference, join conference ...etc, please check this link for more detail Conference Services. Get more detail bout ConferenceCallView for the conference UI view and how to add your customization to it. Get more detail bout ConferenceScreenSharingView for the conference screen sharing and how to add your customization to it. Get more detail bout ConferenceActionsView for the conference action buttons and how to add your customization to it. How To Use: This example bellow will show to you how to use Conference Call in general and simple way. If you wanna more detail how to use it, you can check the Sample Code. Please Note: in the Sample Code we listen beside the event EventType.CurrentConferenceUpdated we listen to EventType.GetCurrentCall event too. And the reason that we need to get the current call after retrieving the call view, please read this link for more info Retrieve Active Call View. import React, { FunctionComponent, useEffect, useState } from 'react'; import { eventEmitter, EventType, IConference, ConferenceActionsView, ConferenceCallView } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; import { Body, Container, Header, Left, Title, Right, Icon } from 'native-base'; import { StyleSheet, View } from 'react-native'; const ConferenceCallComponent: FunctionComponent = () => { const [conferenceCall, setConferenceCall] = useState<IConference>(); useEffect(() => { // Listen to the conference updated including conference added, updated and removed const currentConferenceUpdatedListener = eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.CurrentConferenceUpdated, (call?: IConference) => { // incase of the removed call, the call event will be `undefined` setConferenceCall(call); }); return () => { currentConferenceUpdatedListener.remove(); } }, [conferenceCall]); // Check if there is a valid Conference Call to show it to the user. if (conferenceCall) { const { name } = conferenceCall.callPeer; return ( <Container > <Header style={defaultStyle.headerColor} hasSegment={true}> <Body> <Title style={defaultStyle.headerTitle}>{name}</Title> </Body> </Header> <View style={defaultStyle.backgroundImage}> <ConferenceCallView conferenceCall={conferenceCall} /> <ConferenceActionsView call={conferenceCall} /> </View> </Container> ); } else { return null; } } Conference Call Screenshot Conference Updated Event: To listen to the conference event changes, you can use EventType.CurrentConferenceUpdated, where the event response will be a conference object of type IConference and the conference object will be as undefined in case of the Call Removed. const currentConferenceUpdatedListener = eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.CurrentConferenceUpdated, (call?: IConference) => { // incase of the removed call, the call event will be `undefined` setConferenceCall(call); }); Conference Attendees Updates Event: To listen to the conference attendees event changes for example when one of the participant joining the conference or leave the conference, you can use EventType.ConferenceAttendeesUpdates, where the event response will be a attendees array of type IConferenceParticipants. const confAttendeesUpdatesListener = eventEmitter.addListener(EventType.ConferenceAttendeesUpdates, (attendees: IConferenceParticipants[]) => { // Check if there is a valid conference call object if (conferenceCall) { // update the conference call attendees with the new updated attendees. setConferenceCall({ ...conferenceCall, attendees }); } }); Conference Screen Sharing Updates Event: To listen to the conference Screen Sharing event changes for example when the screen sharing is enabled/disabled or when the participant who's sharing changed, you can use EventType.GetConferenceScreenSharingUpdate, where the event response will be as ISharingConference type. const getSharingUpdate = eventEmitter.addListener( EventType.GetConferenceScreenSharingUpdate, (eventData: ISharingConference) => { console.log(`conference screen sharing update with isSharingEnabled: ${eventData.isSharingEnabled}`); // handle screen sharing updates } ); Conference Call View: This Component will show to you the conference call view and its have tho following props for your customization: #NameTypeDescription 1conferenceCallIConferenceThe Conference call object 2renderIncomingCallView(conferenceCall: IConference) => React.ReactNode[optional] Incase you wanna override the default view, you can use it to add your own custom view for the Incoming Conference Call 3renderOutgoingCallView(conferenceCall: IConference) => React.ReactNode[opti

title: CPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow
excerpt: DocumentationManage personal profileManaging Personal Profile Preamble Using the Rainbow SDK for react native, you can manage your personal information by getting or updating them. Get The Connected U
content: DocumentationManage personal profileManaging Personal Profile Preamble Using the Rainbow SDK for react native, you can manage your personal information by getting or updating them. Get The Connected User Info You can get the connected user profile information by calling the component <UserProfile /> from react-native-rainbow-module. This component will return the connected user : name company name presence profile picture Change Your Presence You can change your Rainbow presence to Online, Away, Offline or Do not disturb by calling <PresenceList /> from the sdk library. This component will allow you to change your presence and listen of any presence changes. In Addition it allow you to customize the style of the presence icon by pass the optional props presenceIconStyle check code below. You can use the <UserProfile /> and <PresenceList/> as shown in example code below: import { Content, List, View } from 'native-base'; import React from 'react'; import { UserProfile, PresenceList } from 'react-native-rainbow-module'; const presenceIconStyle: ImageStyle = { width: 25, height: 25, }; class AppMenuView extends React.Component<IProps> { constructor(props: IProps) { super(props); } public render() { return ( <SafeAreaView style={defaultStyle.safeArea}> <UserProfile /> <View style={defaultStyle.menuContentContainer}> <Content> <List> <PresenceList presenceIconStyle={presenceIconStyle} /> </List> </Content> </View> </SafeAreaView> ); } } export default AppMenuView; }; Update your personal information You can update you personal information by calling the method updateUserInfo(updateUserRequest: IUpdateUserQuery):void provided in userProfileService. where the IUpdateUserQuery is the query that conation the user info you want to update. Note: please note that not all the connected users have the right to modify the whole of their profile and not only (title, firstName, lastName). to check if the user is allow to change his presence or the information check the two flags in IUser below: isAllowedToChangePresence : Define if a user has the right to changes his Presence manually or only use automatic states. isAllowedToModifyProfileInfo : Define if a user has the right to modify the whole of his profile and not only (title, firstName, lastName). For more details on how you can get and update the connected user info, You can check MyProfile component in our Example code On this pageManaging Personal ProfilePreambleGet The Connected User InfoChange Your PresenceUpdate your personal informationWas this content helpful to you?YesNoFeedback© Copyright - 2022 | ALE InternationalCPaaS SDK for business communication solutions | Rainbow v2.31.0ProductsWebNodeAndroidiOSReact NativeCSharpAPIsUseful linksDocumentationStoreSupportPricingHomeExploreLegal informationsServices AgreementDeveloper AgreementCookie policyThird party softwareCompanyPartnerVisit usRainbowContact usFollow us on
